PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Scholes, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCHOLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Terri- tories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Madam Speaker, this is an historic occasion. The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the introduction of a democratic, responsible form of government for the Australian Capital Territory. The population of the Australian Capital Territory has been without an effective and representative form of government for over 70 years. It stands as the last remaining significant community in the Western world having no form of local or State administration answerable directly to its people.

The Australian Capital Territory was conceived amidst the squabbling between Sydney and Melbourne in the Constitutional Conventions staged in the 1880s and 1890s. A reading of debates of the time the Australian Capital Territory was excised from New South Wales and the historic records show Canberra was not readily accepted, and probably still has not been accepted, as the nation's capital in all parts of Australia. To indicate the depth of feeling, I refer honourable members to the following excerpt from an editorial in the Melbourne Argus newspaper in 1910. It states:

Canberra is in a dip subject to intense heat, having a soil too poor for herbage and with no adequate source of water supply . . . The facts suggest that Yass-Canberra is very near to being `no man's land' and no sane people would expend treasure and labour in trying to make a modern city in such surroundings.

Canberra is now regarded as one of the best planned cities in the world that all Australians can be proud of. It has a thriving economy and a growing population of over 250,000 people. After the Seat of Government Acceptance Act was passed in 1909 the then residents were struck off the electoral rolls for both State and Federal voting. It has only been in the last 20 years that the people of the Australian Capital Territory were given the right to elect a member with full voting rights in the Federal Parliament. Canberra has always had a battle to gain democratic rights-the opposition reached a peak in 1974 when certain State governments and the conservative parties in this Parliament opposed the Australian Capital Territory's having the right to elect senators. The Bill was taken to a double dissolution; a joint sitting of both Houses and subsequently to the High Court of Australia. `Taxation without representation' is a long-heard and valid catchcry. The people of Canberra have a right and indeed a responsibility, to elect representatives to oversee the spending of the revenue raised in the Australian Capital Territory. The Federal Parliament cannot reasonably provide a forum for decisions which affect the residents of the Territory. Canberra has had a fully elected House of Assembly since 1974, but that Assembly has only advisory powers. It lacks legislative, executive and financial control and accountability. Despite the efforts of the Assembly members-and I note that some former members are now sitting in this Parliament, like my colleague, the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Ros Kelly and both Australian Capital Territory senators-the Assembly cannot fully represent the Australian Capital Territory community. This Bill will ensure the Australian Capital Territory is properly represented by fully elected representatives of that area.

In 1982 the Australian Labor Party made an electoral commitment to bring self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. The Government is now introducing a form of government which allows Canberra's citizens to manage their local affairs while the Commonwealth retains management of the national interests. It is a commitment to an appropriate sharing of functions and responsibilities. The Council will have a wide range of municipal and territorial functions and powers, including welfare, housing, tourism, the environment, water, gas and electricity, public safety, transport, taxation and a range of municipal powers.

The Government has taken significant steps to prepare for self-government. We have initiated an integrated budget process to set priorities and allocate resources. We have asked the Commonwealth Grants Commission to conduct an inquiry into the financing of Government services in the Australian Capital Territory for 1985-86. The Council can decide to instigate regular reviews by the Grants Commission.

Instead of the past situation of an administration divided among a number of Commonwealth departments, there will now be a single, effective administration, in the Council, delivering a wide range of municipal and territorial services. In addition, most remaining Commonwealth functions of a local nature in the national capital have been consolidated in the one portfolio. This will provide for economy in administration and for efficient co-ordination with the Council's activities. The Council will consist of 13 members, 12 part time and a full time chairperson elected at the first meeting. The Government will review the part time status of members at the time it considers the transfer of additional responsibilities to the Council. Members will be elected for a four-year fixed term from single-member electorates by optional preference voting. Honourable members will be aware that this appears to be the main cause of concern voiced against this Bill. The criticism is misguided and underestimates the intelligence of the Australian Capital Territory community. Surely honourable members can recall members from both sides of this House being voted out by the electorate of Canberra in recent times. Single-member electorates will ensure that the duly elected Council members perform and if they do not they will not be re-elected.

The system the Government is proposing is the most democratic system for the Australian Capital Territory. It is consistent with the position taken by the Government and the Joint Select Committee on the type of electoral system most suited to elections to the House of Representatives. It accords with the practice in all mainland State lower Houses or single chambers. It allows the electorate to select its representatives in the most direct way, avoiding the complications and uncertainties of other systems. It provides for stable government, yet allows change in voting patterns to be directly reflected in the Council's composition. It provides for small electorates where members' performance can be subject to close scrutiny by the local community. The Bill also provides for public funding for political parties for the first election. The Council will decide its own policy on public funding for subsequent elections.

There are also provisions in the Bill dealing with the holding of early elections in extraordinary circumstances. There is provision for an early election in the event of a deadlock being unresolved within 30 days by the Council. There is also provision for the Governor-General to dismiss the Council. This is a power to be used only in an extreme situation-for example, if the Council was unable to govern. The system of government has been designed for the particular requirements of the Australian Capital Territory and therefore has no direct parallel elsewhere in Australia. It protects both local interests and the national interests in the Federal capital. As well as legislative and executive authority for a range of prescribed matters, the Council will exercise executive powers under various Commonwealth laws and through agency and other arrangements made with the Commonwealth.

In all the years of debate about self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, the greatest myths have revolved around the question of finances. Canberrans believed they would pay more while the States believed that they were paying for the facilities in the Australian Capital Territory. The studies leading up to the Government's decision have, I hope, exploded most of those myths. The financial aspects of self-government will be satisfactory for both the residents of the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth Government and thus the taxpayer. Commonwealth funding will be guaranteed for the first two years to maintain per capita real standards at the time of transfer, provided the Australian Capital Territory maintains its per capita real revenue effort at the time of transfer. For the following three years funding levels will be agreed with the Australian Capital Territory Council to smooth the transition to financial arrangements consistent with Commonwealth, State and local government financial arrangements and principles of fiscal equalisation. The Commonwealth-Australian Capital Territory financial arrangements will also recognise the unique circumstances prevailing in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Council will have the right to apply to the Commonwealth Grants Commission for periodic reviews of its financial arrangements with the Commonwealth. These arrangements will ensure that in financial matters the Australian Capital Territory will be treated as fairly and equitably as any other part of Australia. Most State-type taxes and charges are already levied in the Australian Capital Territory. Revenue-raising powers of this kind will be passed to the new Council.

The opportunity is being taken by the Government to rationalise Australian Capital Territory public finance. The co-ordination and integration of the processes of budgeting of Territorial expenditure and receipts which we began last year will continue and be further refined. The Parliament, the Council and the Australian Capital Territory will, as a result, then have information available to assess the efficiency and effectiveness of government in the Australian Capital Territory. While there will be initial costs to be met by the Commonwealth for the establishment and election of the Council, as well as short-term increases in recurrent costs until administrative and staffing arrangements are integrated, these will be kept to a minimum.

The Government has taken the opportunity of rationalising planning, development, lease administration and land management. The changed arrangements provide that the Commonwealth and the Council work in partnership. Planning and development will be undertaken by the National Capital Development Commission which will be restructured consistent with this Bill. Parliamentary oversight of the planning of Canberra will remain. However, the newly constituted Commission will be the servant of both the Commonwealth and the Council. The Commission will be required to reach agreement with the Council before proceeding with planning and development proposals.

The Bill provides that the Council will not be able to pass laws with respect to the planning of land use or for the development of land, except as may be prescribed by Commonwealth regulation. For efficiency and effectiveness the Government has decided to integrate lease administration with planning. This will be accompanied by changes to planning controls. Land use classifications will be broadened, lease conditions will be standardised and in only a limited number of cases will special lease conditions be applied.

Land development and lease marketing will be undertaken by the Commission on a commercial basis-subject to Commonwealth policy directives. Land will be provided to the Commission as equity capital at valuation with development funds being provided from borrowings and sales revenue. These changes will remove this activity from budget cycles, making it more responsive to demand and ending the swings in supply of land to which Canberra has been subject. The question of recognition of the Council's lack of access to, or control over, land revenues will be taken up in the negotiation of the financial agreement with the Council. Details of the Government's approach are contained in a paper entitled `Planning, Development, Lease Marketing and Lease Management'. I seek leave to table this paper and have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The paper read as follows-
PLANNING, DEVELOPMENT, LEASE MARKETING AND LEASE MANAGEMENT
RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THE COMMONWEALTH AND THE A.C.T. COUNCIL
Objectives

This paper addresses the relationships that are to apply between the Commonwealth and the ACT Council (the Council) in respect of planning and development and the marketing and management of leases. The underlying objective has been to develop arrangements that are soundly based administratively, which are efficient and which provide appropriate processes of consultation and agreement among the parties with mechanisms for the settlement of disagreement.
Propositions

To assist in this consideration certain propositions have been identified. This has been on the basis that there will be no change to the existing ACT boundaries, that the Commonwealth and Council will need to establish consultative arrangements with NSW authorities and that the NCDC will need to be restructured.
Relevant functions have been defined anew and analysed in the context of:
Canberra's role as the National Capital and Seat of Government;
the Government's decisions on the functions of the Council; and
the needs of clients.
The propositions are:
1. To retain the integration of planning and development which has been achieved in the ACT.
2. To have arrangements for consultation and agreement on planning and development between the restructured NCDC (the Commission) and the Council.
3. To establish arrangements for the appropriate setting of priorities and allocation of resources.
4. To integrate land administration with planning and development.
5. To undertake the development and marketing of land on a commercial basis, free from day to day political control but subject to Commonwealth Government policy directives.
6. To provide that the Council is to agree proposals for which it has responsibility for funding, including any capital works undertaken by the Commission on the Council's behalf.
7. To continue Parliamentary oversight of the planning and development of Canberra subject to changes in procedure to take account of the Council's responsibilities.
Consideration of Issues
1. Relationship between the Commission and the Council in respect of planning functions to be carried out by the Commission.

The existing NCDC Plans System is based on Policy Plans and Development Plans. The System is implemented in several ways including the application of Design and Siting Policies and Development Conditions. Policy Plans comprise statements of objectives with respect to future land use intentions. Development Plans are concerned with implementation, including co-ordination of works and staging, so as to be consistent with Policy Plans.

The present structure of the Plans System will need to be changed to reflect the need for the Council to be involved in formulating planning policy. The range of both Policy Plans and Development Plans prepared by the NCDC now extends from an ACT-wide scale to a single block within the City of Canberra. It will not be appropriate after the advent of the Council for Policy Plans to extend to the present level of detail. Policy Plans will be altered to provide clear statements of Commission policy in order that the community would know not only what the policies are but be informed about, and thus understand, their basis.

The preparation and presentation of Policy Plans to meet these needs will require two changes. The first is that they will apply only to large scale areas in future. Policy Plans will be prepared to encompass the following:
the ACT
the Metropolitan Area
the Districts (eg Inner Canberra, Belconnen etc)
the Neighbourhoods (eg Isabella Plains)
The second change to present practice will be to broaden the land use classifications used in Policy Plans.

Together these changes will ensure that the format of Policy Plans is appropriate to their purpose, which is to offer clear guidance without unnecessary prescription. In this form, Policy Plans will be clearly distinguished from implementation, which is the function of Development Plans and Development Conditions.

It is intended that the preparation and operation of Policy Plans would continue to be the responsibility of the Commission. In order to provide effective participation by the Council in the formulation of planning policy all Policy Plans would become operative only after the agreement of the Council to the Plan.

The purpose of Development Plans is to show how the works intended to be undertaken by the Commonwealth, the Council or private enterprise will be constructed in such a way as to be consistent with Policy Plans.
Responsibility for the preparation of Development Plans would rest with the Commission. The Development Plans would be the basis of agreement to be reached between the Commission and the Council.

Development Plans would be prepared in consultation with the Council to ensure that works proposed by the Council or the Commission on behalf of Commonwealth authorities or private enterprise are properly co-ordinated and their consequences understood. The Development Plan would become the basis of agreements between the Commission and the Council regarding the works for which each accepts responsibility and for the reciprocal consequences of such works including the consequences of works intended to be undertaken by the private sector.

Development Plans could cover a wide range of development proposals. Arising from the Plans the precise form of the agreements between the Commission and the Council with regard to these proposals would vary. In some cases agreements on schedules and staging of works may be all that is necessary. In other cases the Development Plan itself may need to be the document which is the subject of agreement. The intention in all cases would be to ensure that the Commission and the Council are aware of the consequences of development actions upon each other's responsibilities and that any conflicts are satisfactorily resolved by consultation. It follows that where significant changes occurred in proposals which had been the subject of a Development Plan then further consultation and agreements would be necessary.

Development Plans would be prepared in all cases where the subdivision and servicing of land for urban development is intended. In these cases Development Plans would show the intended sub-divisional layout and the mix and types of housing as well as the layouts of roads and prospective works. These Development Plans would be submitted to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the ACT when the Committee is considering Variations to the Plan of Canberra in order to gazette the relevant roads.

There would be a standard form of lease conditions attaching to all leases, specifying such things as duration of lease, land rent and so on; these would be agreed between the Council and the Commission. As well there would be Development Conditions which would be tailored for particular leases and would supplement Design and Siting Policies. In that limited number of cases arising when the general Design and Siting Policies would be inadequate or inappropriate Development Conditions would be used. Development Conditions would be specific to a particular lease and could be either more restrictive or more liberal than general Design and Siting Policies. They would attach to the relevant leases and be prepared by the Commission. Certain classes of development to which Development Conditions would attach such as large scale projects or those of unusual sensitivity would be the subject of a Development Plan and subject to the approval of the Commonwealth and the Council in the light of the impact on each of them.

The preparation of Design and Siting policies would remain a responsibility of the Commission but the policies would become operative only after the agreement of the Council. The administration of these policies would continue to be undertaken by the Commission.

All development will be subject to building, engineering and environmental standards. At present the NCDC, the Department of Territories, the Department of Housing and Construction and other authorities involved in development, such as ACTEA, construct according to accepted standards. These standards will need to be consolidated and agreed between the Commission and the Council so as to provide the basis of proper co-ordination of the different works responsibilities and a uniform guide to private enterprise.

Building Approvals would be the responsibility of the Council. Continuation of the close measure of co-ordination that now exists between the NCDC and the Department of Territories in respect of the application of Design and Siting Policies and Building Approvals would need to carry over to the relationship between the Commission and the Council.
2. Relationship in respect of marketing and management of business and residential leases.

For efficiency and effectiveness the Government has decided to integrate lease administration with planning. This will be accompanied by changes to planning. Land use classifications will be broadened, lease conditions will be standardised and only in a limited number of cases will special lease conditions be applied.

It was concluded that the functions of lease administration and planning should be collocated in the Commission. The consequences of this collocation are consistency of application and a feed-back from the practical consequences of enforcing conditions to the process of formulating them.

The sale of leases and their variation would be undertaken by the Commission with the development and marketing of new estates to be accounted for on a commercial basis subject to policy directives; with land being provided as equity capital at valuation, and funding for development to be obtained from borrowings and sales revenue. The extent to which any development would vary from agreed standards would primarily be a commercial judgment. Where standards were altered, and consequentially affected Council's responsibilities adversely, then full recognition would be given by the Commonwealth to the financial and social impacts on the Council.
Redevelopment should also be undertaken on a commercial basis but with accounts separate from those for the development of estates.
3. Related Issues
Headworks

Water, sewerage and stormwater Headworks (for example, water supply, dams and sewerage treatment works, etc.) are those facilities which will continue to be provided by the Commission as part of land development but whose costs cannot be reasonably recovered from the sale of leases and, as a result, are ultimately recouped from rates. Because the Council is to be responsible for the determination and collection of rates, the Commission will obtain the agreement of the Council for such Headworks and negotiate an appropriate capital contribution from it for capital funding.
Consultation
Appropriate formal inter-governmental consultative mechanisms will need to be established between the Commission and the Council to facilitate co-ordination and the resolution of disputes.

The resolution of disputes will rest with a nominated Commonwealth Minister who, after consultation with the Chairperson of the Council, will either issue a direction to the Commission or go through a formal process of consultation with the Council, depending on his or her judgment as to which course is to be taken. The Minister will be provided with information enabling him or her to have full regard for financial aspects in reaching a judgment.

Additional processes of consultation will be necessary so that the views of the Commonwealth, through the Commission or other federal authorities, are fully taken into account by the Council in its actions, including the passage of legislation, that may cause the Commonwealth to incur additional costs (e.g. a Noise Ordinance may add considerably to the costs of construction).
Timing
It is proposed that arrangements approved by the Government be in place before 1 July 1987 and be reviewed no later than 1 July 1992.
Planning Appeals Mechanisms
The report of the Administrative Review Council on planning appeals would need to be considered for implementation when decisions on planning responsibilities are made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill now before the Senate to amend the National Capital Development Commission Act 1957 was drafted before the form of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory was decided. The Government will withdraw that Bill. A new Bill to amend the National Capital Development Commission Act 1957, will be brought before the House shortly. It will make changes to the corporate structure of the National Capital Development Commission and to its powers and functions, consistent with the changes I have outlined. Management of all land, with the exception of lease administration, will be undertaken by the Council. The Commonwealth has defined nationally significant areas in which it will set the standards and bear the associated costs. In addition, the Commonwealth, for national capital purposes, may desire a higher quality of land management in other designated areas and in such cases will negotiate with the Council on standards and financial responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I now address individual Parts of the Bill. Part I provides for the usual preliminary matters of commencement and interpretation. Honourable members should note that the Jervis Bay Territory is a separate Commonwealth Territory and is not affected by the Bill. Part II establishes the Council and covers the range of procedural matters necessary for the conduct of the Council's business and proceedings. Part III deals with the election of the Council and redistribution processes. These are consistent with the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The Council will not have legislative power to change the electoral system.

Part IV covers the Council's legislative heads of power and provides for specific Commonwealth laws, listed in schedules 1 and 2, to be transferred to the Council. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) shall decide whether the Council has power to make a proposed law. This will be a technical, legal decision. The Attorney will not be second guessing the Council's decisions as a government. Members should note that the Council will not be able to establish its own courts but, with the approval of the Commonwealth Attorney-General, can vest jurisdiction in existing courts. Part V will permit the Council to implement its own administration, management and staffing. The Council may establish standing and ad hoc committees to conduct its business. The Council will appoint its most senior executives and provision is made for their remuneration and allowances to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. The head of administration will be responsible to the Chairperson for the business of the Council and the general conduct of the Council's administration.

The Council will be able to make laws determining the conditions of employment of its employees or those of its authorities. The establishment of separate staffing legislation for the Council will be a very significant task requiring extensive consultation with the Commonwealth and staff organisations. The Commonwealth expects to reach agreement with the Council before it enacts that legislation. To this end, the Bill provides for consultation on staffing, terms and conditions of employment, and industrial questions relating to employees, to take place between the Commonwealth and the Council. In the longer term these consultative arrangements will also ensure that the Council will have regard to the effect of its decisions on the Commonwealth's interests as an employer operating side by side with the Council in the Australian Capital Territory. The Government is concerned to ensure that national wages and industrial relations policies, and its commitment to the prices and incomes accord, are kept clearly in consideration through this consultative mechanism.

The Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act will continue to apply in the Australian Capital Territory. Accordingly, the Council will not have legislative power in industrial relations matters except in relation to its own staff and as may be prescribed. In view of the Council's responsibilities, however, it will be necessary to develop arrangements to ensure that its views on Australian Capital Territory industrial relations issues are taken into account. The Government will be giving further consideration to the appropriate arrangements.

Financial and audit provisions are covered in Part VI. The Council will operate its own treasury and accounting system. All Council borrowings will be subject to the Commonwealth's approval. Borrowings may be guaranteed by the Commonwealth and any financial guarantees given by the Council will require Commonwealth approval. The Council can make its own audit law. The Commonwealth would expect this law to be consistent with the high standards of accountability required of the public sector. The Commonwealth Auditor-General shall be the Auditor-General of the Australian Capital Territory Council. The Commonwealth will be able to protect its unique national interests through a variety of mechanisms. If the Attorney-General certifies that in his opinion the Council does not have the power to make a proposed law, it will not come into operation. Commonwealth law is, of course, supreme in those cases where there is an inconsistency between Council and Commonwealth law. The Governor-General will have power to disallow any Council law or bylaw within six months after the law is made. Council law will not bind the Crown unless the Commonwealth so provides by regulation. These protections are essential in the national capital. It is the Government's intention, however, that any potential conflicts between the Council and the Commonwealth be resolved as far as is possible by consultation rather than by legal process.

Part VII attends to miscellaneous provisions and constitutional guarantees. The Australian Capital Territory will be brought into line with the States and the Northern Territory by applying the provisions of section 92 of the Constitution, guaranteeing free trade. This will not bind the Commonwealth. Transitional provisions and consequential amendments contained in the Australian Capital Territory Council (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 will ensure a smooth transfer of powers and functions to the incoming Council. Until the Council enacts its own staffing legislation, the Bill provides for staff involved in functions transferred to the Council's administration to be employed under existing Commonwealth legislation and existing awards. The staff therefore retain the normal Public Service conditions of service during this period, including the right to seek promotion or transfer to other Australian Public Service departments and authorities.

The Government proposes that the Consequential Provisions Bill and the Australian Capital Territory Council Bill be considered in cognate debate. The Commonwealth will negotiate with the Council on arrangements for transfer of functions; application of administrative law; the financial agreement including budgetary arrangements for the remainder of 1986-87; formal consultative procedures; and establishment action. The Commonwealth will also discuss with the States the status of the Council in Commonwealth-State forums and agreements. Following enactment of this Bill the Australian Electoral Commission will initiate the established process of electoral distribution, including public participation, to permit the first Council election to be held in September of this year. It is most important that we adhere to this timetable to give the Council time to complete negotiations with the Commonwealth, take up administrative responsibility, and formulate and introduce its Budget for 1987-88.

It will be clear to honourable members that this legislation is both comprehensive and well conceived. It provides for a most democratic, practical and economic form of government for the Australian Capital Territory; it provides an electoral system the same as that available at the Commonwealth and State level; it provides the incoming Council with a wide range of powers and functions; it safeguards the Commonwealth's interest in the national capital; it provides for an efficient and effective administration; it puts the Australian Capital Territory on a proper financial basis, and it protects the interests of those staff who are to be transferred. In short, the residents of the Australian Capital Territory will now be properly and effectively represented in the management of their affairs. The Commonwealth and the Council will work in partnership in the administration and management of the Australian Capital Territory. This is indeed a milestone in public administration in this country. I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY COUNCIL (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Scholes, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCHOLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides essential transitional and consequential amendments relating to the establishment of the Australian Capital Territory Council. The provisions of this Bill are largely of a technical nature and are designed to ensure a smooth transition of responsibilities to the incoming Council. Part I deals with commencement and interpretation. Part II deals with transitional matters. It provides for the Minister to convene the Council's first meeting; the Council's law making power during the period between the first election and the formal transfer of functions to the Council; the Council's interim staffing arrangements under the Australian Capital Territory Council Bill and the Public Service Act 1922; the status of the nominee of the House of Assembly on the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority following the abolition of that Assembly; the transfer of contracts from the Commonwealth to the Council; Commonwealth indemnification of the Council; exemption from stamp duty on land transferred from the Commonwealth to the Council; and application of the Commonwealth Audit Act 1901. The Commonwealth Audit Act, with appropriate modifications and adaptations, will apply to the Council until its own audit law comes into effect, consistent with the high standards of accountability required of the public sector. Part III effects consequential amendments to the various Commonwealth Acts specified in the Schedule. The amendments principally relate to references to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly.

The Bill provides for the Council's administration to be part of the Australian Public Service until the Council passes its own staffing legislation. Staff will therefore retain their existing rights and entitlements during this interim period. It provides for consultation with the Commonwealth before the Council enacts its own staffing legislation. The Commonwealth expects to reach agreement with the Council before it enacts its own staffing legislation, and appropriate provisions on this matter are included in the Australian Capital Territory Council Bill. Unions and staff associations will also be consulted. I table the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to express my thanks to those honourable members who participated in the debate on this Bill last evening. A number of matters were raised during the course of discussion. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) made some comments about the search for and recovery of the Pel-Air aircraft off Sydney. That matter is still being investigated by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. The Bureau's report is not complete. In addition, a coronial inquiry is still under way. In these circumstances, I do not believe it is appropriate to comment on some of the matters that were raised. I can assure the House that when these processes have been completed the Government will be looking at the results very carefully with a view to determining what follow-up action, if any, is required. I am able to say in response to the question that was raised about the expertise of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation that the Bureau is not a salvage authority. Its function is to inquire into the causes of the and to try to ascertain the circumstances leading up to air crashes with a view to preventing a recurrence of such accidents. In essence, its task is to make air travel and the operation of aircraft safe in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Murray will recall that on 17 January he said that there were alleged statements by departmental officials that there was a budget limitation on the search. He said that this was unacceptable and that I must guarantee that an unrestricted recovery effort would be undertaken. At the time I did not think that that was a very responsible statement to make. It is certainly not a practice that was followed by the honourable member or his colleagues when they were in government. What he said did not add anything of merit or worth to the task that was at hand. I noticed that now the task has been completed successfully he still has some complaint. I think there is very little credibility in the comments that he made, given his comments earlier in the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the crash boats?

—I will come to the crash boats, if the honourable member will be a little patient. The Pel-Air crash was unusual and, understandably, the Bureau had to bring in salvage expertise as was determined appropriate. This was necessary because of the nature of the crash and, as subsequent events will show-from the nature of the fragmentation of the aircraft-the sonar detection equipment that was here in Australia did not have the capacity to pick up the kind of wreckage in question. But these are all matters that will be dealt with in detail when the Bureau completes its investigation and when the coroner completes his inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also commented on the failure of the emergency position indicating radio beacon-the EPIRB. EPIRBs are carried by light aircraft which do not have high frequency radio. The Pel-Air aricraft was a sophisticated jet aircraft which was not required to carry an EPIRB. I think the honourable member has confused EPIRBs with what are called underwater locator devices or ULDs, which are fitted on to the flight data recorder. Honourable members will be aware that the flight data recorder was recovered along with the wreckage. The function of that device is to emit a ping to assist in location of the recorders. In the case of the Pel-Air crash, the recorder had a ULD fitted. However, it was not working after the crash and preliminary investigation indicates that it sustained some damage at the time of impact. But again they are matters that will be looked at and dealt with in detail when the coronial inquiry is completed and when the Bureau's task is completed and reported upon.

In respect of the crash boats referred to by the honourable member for Murray, my recollection is that last evening he asserted that there were two crash boats-one under the control of the Department of Aviation. His information was that one of the crash boats was having an engine refit and on the second the engine would not start. I have to say to him that we do not have two crash boats; there is only one crash boat, the Trident, which is owned by the Department of Aviation. The crash boat is located at Mascot. It covers regular public transport passenger movements between the hours of 6 a.m. and 11 p.m. As the crash occurred just after midnight, the Trident crew had been stood down in the normal course of their duties and were not available. In the event, given that the crash had occurred and the emergency had arisen, the crew were turned out in approximately one hour and participated in the search. I am at a loss to understand the point about the two crash boats. I suggest to the honourable member that, before he makes those kinds of statements in future, it might help if he were to check, as he said last night, on the source of his information. That is as best as I can relate it to him.

Another matter that was raised during the debate was the response of the International Civil Aviation Organisation, ICAO, following the Air India and other incidents that occurred. I can say to the chamber that in 1985 ICAO convened a group of experts in aviation security to conduct a thorough investigation of the annex to the Convention on International Civil Aviation that deals with aviation security. Many of the recommendations of the annex have been upgraded to international standards, which will place an obligation on ICAO member states to implement these standards. Australia, for its part, participated in the ICAO review and strongly supported ICAO's work in this area. ICAO has recently notified all its members of these new provisions. However, Australia has already taken steps to tighten our own security at airports in an endeavour to avoid repetition of the incidents to which speakers last evening referred. With those concluding remarks, I thank the honourable members who participated in the discussion last evening and commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
