DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March 1986, on motion by Mr Cohen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill has the support of the Opposition. The Bill before the House makes amendments to legislation introduced initially by the Fraser Government which then had, as it does now, the full support of Parliament. The purpose of the proposed amendments and of the Bill in general is to strengthen arrangements for the protection of Australia's fauna and flora and world wildlife generally by improving the effectiveness of our import and export controls. These controls, as proposed in the amendments, cover four main categories. Firstly, it is proposed to make controls on exports and imports of certain specimens more appropriate to their status and circumstances under which they enter trade, such as bringing conditions relating to the export of invertebrates into line with those applying to fish, and providing transitional arrangements in respect of household pets and certain birds acquired before the commencement of the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, it is proposed to simplify and improve administrative procedures where it has been established that this will not weaken the protection afforded to wildlife, such as allowing permits to be issued for the importation under certain circumstances of specimens acquired by individuals before the application of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of wild fauna and flora. It will also allow multiple transactions, and authorities in certain circumstances may allow an individual to apply for a permit in respect of a specimen surrendered by that person which otherwise would have been forfeited. Thirdly, it is proposed to clarify certain enforcement provisions such as ensuring beyond doubt that an inspector may search all goods on a vessel, unaccompanied or otherwise, and that an inspector may seize an article which includes specimens. Fourthly, it is proposed to provide for increased protection for witnesses involved in proceedings under the Act.

The coalition parties have a record of significant legislative achievement in this area of nature conservation. In 1980 we introduced the Whale Protection Act, which prohibits the taking of cetaceans in Australian waters or by Australians elsewhere. We ratified the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources. We have promised in our policy when in government to support the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of wild fauna and flora, which is the CITES Convention and further, we will co-operate with TRAFFIC, which is the trade records analysis of flora and fauna in commerce. We also support the migratory birds agreement with Japan which provides for the protection of many species of migratory birds, and associated research.

Australia has traditionally set high standards of protection. In some respects, we have provided world leadership. Unfortunately, because of the sheer size of our continent and the numerous points both of entry and exit, it has been very difficult to police the laws appropriately as they stand from time to time. Despite the efforts of successive Australian governments to eliminate the illegal trade in endangered species, it still continues. This trade in wildlife is a particularly lucrative business. It has been claimed that it is as lucrative as drug trafficking. In fact, both smuggling operations tend to go hand in hand, with the same Asian traffic routes being used to smuggle birds and other wildlife out of Australia and to bring in drugs on the return journey.

Each year countless thousands of Australian birds, reptiles and other protected species, including koalas and kangaroos, are being smuggled out of Australia through the Asian points of entry, often to wealthy buyers in the United States of America, Europe and elsewhere. It has been estimated that the annual turnover of this illicit trade is of the order of $40m a year. In the United States, for example, a pair of rare parrots can fetch up to $40,000. Even the common galah, destroyed as a pest on many outback properties of Australia, can sell elsewhere for up to $1,700. One plane load of smuggled birds can be exchanged in Bangkok for a consignment of heroin worth millions of dollars in street value when imported into Australia.

In one smuggling operation, which was smashed by the then Australian Customs Bureau, a syndicate netted between $250,000 and $310,000 from birds taken out of the country and $60,000 from a back load of exotic Asian parrots. No one knows the extent of wildlife smuggling out of or into Australia, but clearly it is extensive. As I said earlier it is equally as lucrative as drug smuggling. Only five actual cases of wildlife smuggling have been brought to court since the Act came into force in 1984. That demonstrates quite conclusively the difficulties which we are facing in this country in being able to apply the law. While Customs authorities are responsible for the enforcement of the Act, wildlife is not seen by them as a major search priority. The question therefore has to be asked whether this adequately represents government policy. If it does, clearly, there is little point in the Government claiming to be concerned about the illegal export of Australian animals unless it is prepared to provide adequate resources to ensure that the Act is properly policed.

As I said, the reality is that, because of the sheer size of the Australian continent and the many points of entry and exit, this is a difficult function to perform. For example, in the north of Australia we have airport facilities on virtually every outback station. In addition to that, a large number of wartime strips are still serviceable in the Northern Territory, Western Australia and north Queensland. Many of these are in areas where the population density is extremely low. It is a fact that many of these wartime strips in particular are being used for the export of Australian animals and wildlife and, consequently, probably for the import of drugs on a plane's return journey.

The difficulties in controlling that number of airport facilities are extreme. Nevertheless, there is no point in simply bringing into this Parliament new sets of amendments to laws unless an equal level of financial and technological skills is to be allocated towards solving or reducing this problem. I shall give one example from the Sydney Morning Herald of the cost or the values of exporting birds, which was demonstrated in an operation smashed by the Customs Bureau, as I have already mentioned. A rather amusing sideline to this event is demonstrated by the fact that the article states:
One man was fined in Darwin for attempting to smuggle five live pythons-four of which were found in cloth pouches strapped to his legs and the fifth snake hidden in his underpants.
The article continues:

Testifying to the scale of money available to bird smugglers, police in Queensland in 1980 were said to be hunting a smuggling ring suspected of having buried $1 million in cash on an island after a boat they had been using got into difficulties. Fearing detection the gang members had reportedly taken the money ashore and hidden it, while releasing their cargo of native birds.

With profits from wildlife smuggling almost as lucrative as the drug trade, more smugglers are likely to confine themselves to wildlife, particularly in view of stepped-up Federal and State efforts to combat drug trafficking.
In effect, a continuation of lighter penalties for wildlife smuggling amounts to a virtual invitation to entrenched smugglers to make it a growth industry.

I am afraid that, at the end of the road, this Parliament and the government of the day have to face the facts that merely amending the law, in cases such as this, will not be an adequate protective device. One has to be prepared to apply levels of sentence which simply make it not worthwhile for those who openly breach the law to run the risk of being caught. While the risks at this stage appear to be extremely low, quite clearly, the law will continue to be breached. The cross-reference therefore between the risk factor as distinct from the size of the profits from breaking the law must be at the basis of determining what level of penalty should be applied. There is absolutely no doubt that the current level of penalties on the export of Australian native birds and wildlife is simply inadequate to act as a serious deterrent to those who wish to make money out of the destruction and massive pain which are being caused to so many Australian animals because of those people who are greedy enough to try to make money at the expense of others. Those people not only are greedy but also are prepared to have young Australians die in their many hundreds because of the importing of drugs on their return journey into this country and the impact that that has not only on the lives of those young Australians but also on the lives of their friends, their families and society as a whole. The need to link the exporting of wildlife on the one hand with the smuggling of drugs on the other is self evident. One cannot be dealt with without the other. The response which the country, and the Government in particular must make, must therefore be correlated to some extent.

As I said initially, we do acknowledge the difficulty in the detection of smuggling operations. We recognise the importance of informants to the Australian Customs Service. Therefore, we welcome the amendment to the Bill which provides some anonymity for informants and the protection of witnesses involved in proceedings under the Act. The cases in recent months of people who have been murdered by drug-running operations of the Mr Asia type demonstrate the fact that we are dealing with a type of criminal element which simply goes for the ultimate solution-and the ultimate solution is death. That is what such people are prepared to apply to those who breach their code of ethics. The question is: What are we prepared to do in using the law to defend the community on the one hand and apply the law as the basis of our code of ethics on the other? There is a conflict there, but let it be one which we win because the costs of failure are too grotesque to consider seriously.

The amended Bill further simplifies and improves the administrative procedures for the leg- itimate trade in wildlife and at present the procedure for the legitimate transfer of wildlife between designated authorities is tedious, probably unnecessary and does nothing to further the protection of wild species. The amendments liberalise the transfer provisions between zoos and research establishments and allow for multiple import certificates in line with quarantine certificates. This will improve conditions for those who are running long term research programs and give them the convenience of not having to apply for permits for each batch of imports. While these amendments have been described as purely machinery, nevertheless, they give us the opportunity in this Parliament to refer briefly to what is, as I said, a very serious and potentially growing problem. It is a problem of which the nation must be aware and about which the Government of the day must be prepared to use all the strength at its command to stamp out. If we fail to do so, we will see a steady diminution in the quality of Australian wildlife. As I pointed out earlier, the link between drug smuggling into Australia and the illegal export of Australian species of wildlife is too clear and it is not a link which we can watch with equanimity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the amendments to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, I wish to say how glad I am that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has taken the opportunity in this Bill to strengthen the powers of the officials engaged in detecting and prosecuting wildlife trafficking offences. There have been a number of criticisms from various bodies that amendments to existing regulations prevented Customs officers from using the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act to protect the community in matters relating to wildlife. The Minister has made it clear that the amendments would clarify the powers of inspectors in searching baggage and seizing personal property which the inspectors believed was used in an offence. The amendments would ensure that in future the illegal trafficking in fauna would be more liable than at present to prosecution and would increase protection for people who provided information leading to a prosecution.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to remember that the wildlife protection legislation, amongst other things, regulates the import and export of live animals other than domestic animals in order to protect endangered species. Penalties of up to $5,000 were imposed on people who were successfully prosecuted under the Act. In an eight month period from May to December 1984, for example, there were 207 seizures of people who were attempting to export fauna. Of these, four were attempting to export live birds. One was attempting to export a live crocodile and one a live lizard. The remaining 201 fauna seizures were non-living. I was interested to note that, of the non-living products, 36 were elephants. Presumably they were not adults, as the mind boggles as to how even a non-living adult elephant could be smuggled through Customs. However, I find myself in agreement with the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) in that I believe that a fine of $5,000 is not a sufficient deterrent for the callous smugglers of Australian wildlife.

As the Minister has indicated, the main purpose of the Act is to regulate legitimate trade in wildlife and to combat illicit trafficking, particularly of endangered species. I am pleased to note that the Minister has not acceded to the request from traders and farmers to alter existing Government policy on the export of Australian native birds. I am aware of arguments which suggest that controlled legal export would undermine and destroy the illegal trade, that the farmers' problems of crop damage would be alleviated, that export is more humane than current methods of control by shooting or poisoning and that it would prevent the cruelty involved in the smuggling racket. Such arguments may appear superficially attractive, but a more careful examination of the export case reveals severe defects. The present widespread controls are reasonably easy to enforce as opposed to the permitted export of certain species. The checking of consignments would require specialist know- ledge and would be extremely costly to administer. Without such specialist checking it would be relatively easy for a rare and endangered species to be made to look like a common bird species and substituted for export purposes. It also must be said that the argument that we could solve the farmer's pest problem is ridiculous because it would be necessary to export hundreds of thousands of birds to achieve that.

We need to undertake more research into avian pests in order to find alternative methods of control to shooting or poisoning. The export of the birds is no realistic solution to the pest problem. In addition, it must not be forgotten that the export of birds considered by farmers to be pests in Australia could be considered irresponsible overseas in view of the possibility that such species would become pests in overseas countries. It has been argued that a charge on the cost of export of birds and other animals could be used to fund animal conservation research. I find this argument particularly weak as there would be little revenue to be gained from such a source and, in my view, it would be the dealers who would gain from the export of wild animals, and not the conservation movement.

I agree with the Minister that this Bill is an important piece of legislation as it will help to protect Australian wildlife, particularly the endangered species. Unfortunately, the resources available for the conservation of Australia's wildlife are extremely limited and there are problems in the priorities for the allocation of resources. Endangered species, as well as all other species of native wildlife, are part of our natural heritage. In my view it is necessary to prepare a framework for endangered species' habitat protection. I would hope that the Minister would consider the preparation of such legislation to compliment the present Bill. I am pleased to support the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the first speaker from the bush to rise to address the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill, I would like to emphasise the need to create another export industry for our brothers on the farm. Australia is blessed with many unusual species of flora and fauna not found in any other parts of the world. As we have seen with the popularity of the koala and the frill-necked lizard in Japan, our native animals are keenly sought by zoos all over the world. Our Western Australian wildflowers are a thriving export industry, creating wealth and jobs for the growers as well as for the economy of the State. Butterflies are being cultivated and exported from northern Queensland, a unique and enterprising venture. Why, I ask myself, cannot other species so uncommon to other parts of the world, be harvested in a sense for the world market?

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill mentions that the export of cultivated giant clam spats will be allowed to other countries in the Indo-Pacific region. This is to allow them to re-establish their seriously depleted stocks. I commend this move as the clams will offer the people of this region a rich source of vital food and nutrition. However, I can see other possibilities for enterprising individuals who are willing to take a risk and create new industries for our export markets. In my electorate of Groom, at a place called Murphys Creek, outside Toowoomba, there is a thriving business in the cultivation of the native flora Geraldton Wax. For many years this species was confined to the narrow region of Western Australia, but now it is growing prolifically in many other areas of the country and currently it is being exported to the United States of America. It is highly prized as a decorative ornament in the homes of many Americans.

The freshwater crocodile was placed under protection in 1974 by the Commonwealth. As a result of this protection the number of crocodiles has increased to the point where commercial farms are now operating in the far north of Queensland. The strict control and proper management of this species played a positive role in the total conservation strategy which allowed this export market to be reopened. I do not want to see our native flora and fauna overexploited for the purposes of international trade. I do want, however, to see our endangered, vulnerable and rare species encouraged to survive and to proliferate to the point where they are no longer in danger of extinction. The awareness of the need for a delicate balance in nature has come too late for six species of wallabys which have disappeared since 1875, with the last sighting of one of the species being in 1935. There are two species of bandicoots which have not been sighted since 1926 and 1931 respectively. The thylacine-the Tasmanian tiger-was last seen authentically in 1933. Closer to home, the Darling Downs hopping mouse has not been seen since the Leslies settled the Downs in 1840. This shows that species do become lost. Several of our flora are also on the endangered list of the world wildlife fund. The Monterey cypress is on the rare list, while the Norfolk Island pine and the dragon's tree are on the vulnerable list. The honey myrtle is not technically endangered, except in areas of Western Australia where the wheat belt extends into the State.

There is encouraging news coming out of botanical gardens right around the world. The Kew Gardens horticulturalists have collated a list of rare and endangered plants now in cultivation in the major international botanical gardens, so encouraging the maintenance and exchange of genetic material. Australian botanical gardens are also making their contribution to this work. It is my view that individuals could also help to contribute to the program, not only for plants but also for the birds and reptiles so unique to our island continent.

I take the opportunity of paying tribute to a great Australian and a great Australian family. I refer to Lance Cockburn and his family of Brookvale Park outside Oakey on the Darling Downs. They come from a long line of pioneering families from the Darling Downs. They have a most valuable piece of real estate, worth, I suspect, well over half a million dollars. They gave in trust the total land in Brookvale Park, where they are propagating native plants and native trees and preserving endangered species. It is not very often in this modern society that we see people who are prepared to give generously of their resources and their material benefits to ensure that endangered species continue to live. I have been present at Brookvale Park on many occasions and I am always enlightened and always proud to note their many splendid achievements. They have propagated many hundreds of species of plants and trees. We must realise that already 500 species of trees in Australia have been lost. There are 2,000 species on the endangered list.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—Two thousand species on the endangered list and 500 species have already been lost. Lance Cockburn quite often goes all over Australia, camping out in the desert, to get rare seeds and plants, which he propagates. It is a most beautiful sight to see a species such as the chinchilla white gum, which had been virtually lost for 40 years, now thriving because of the care and attention of Lance Cockburn and his family. I think it is about time that fellow Australians took time to acknowledge people such as the Cockburn family for their interest, their concern and their feeling that we should preserve forever our beautiful native flora and fauna. Lance Cockburn is not only an expert on trees but also an authority on koalas and their feeding habits. Most people think that the koalas live only on a certain type of tree. Cockburn has proved that that is a fallacy. He knows the breeding habits and the eating habits of wallabies and kangaroos. These are the types of people that we should be paying tribute to. I am quite proud and happy to take up a few minutes of the time of this national Parliament to have recorded indelibly in Hansard, never to be erased, the contribution of Lance Cockburn and his family and those many other splendid people who make up what is called the Brookvale Park Trust.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to instance the need to preserve the tulip oak and rose mahogany. The new Parliament House, which is rapidly taking shape, is to have tulip oak in its chamber for the use of honourable members. This rare species of tree, tulip oak, which is grown on the Great Dividing Range outside Killarney-which was represented for some years by myself-and which is rapidly becoming extinct. Whoever the next Prime Minister of Australia might be-and I would not want to pass any comment on that at this stage-will have a desk carved out of rose mahogany wood, a very rare species at present being milled in the saw mills of Killarney. The wood will be coming here to make up the desk for the Prime Minister. Rose mahogany wood grew prolifically in the Darling Downs area 40 years ago; now the Department of Forestry in Queensland is refusing to allow any more of that magnificent wood to be cut down. You will be delighted to know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the saw millers at Killarney saw fit to give to me, so that I can have it polished and preserved as part of my treasured memories, a piece of the tree which is to be used to make the desk for the Prime Minister of Australia. Cedar, which is probably a better wood than rose mahogany, could not be used. That is always under debate by amateurs and others who seek to use great timbers for their carving. Some people say that cedar has a nicer red grain than rose mahogany, but it is soft and more easily injured. Rose mahogany, probably like the good residents of the Darling Downs, is made of tougher and sterner stuff; it is a bit harder to dent. I pass those things on because of the fact that these are rare species; they are endangered species and, unless we take positive moves like the Cockburn family and others, these species will disappear. Whilst it would be great for all Australians to have the opportunity of coming into Parliament House and seeing the beautiful rose mahogany of the Prime Minister's desk-timber grown on the magnificent part of the world called the Darling Downs-I suspect the Prime Minister of the day might not have enough time to ensure that the 16 million people of Australia have the opportunity of seeing this beautiful timber. Alternatively, they can come to my office in Toowoomba and see a very small piece of it polished, and it will be polished and cut by me.

We have some of the most unusual and beautiful birds in the world. The budgerigar, a humble household pet prized for its colourful feathers, would be an attractive export, given the proper circumstances. I congratulate the Government on the sense of warmth that it has shown in this amending legislation to allow people who have got these pets to export and import them, just as I fully appreciate and support its sense of interested concern about people who have family heirlooms made out of the skins of rare and endangered animals which have been handed down by generations, and who, up to the present, have not been allowed to bring them in. I fully congratulate and support that type of thinking.

The cockatoo is a pest in our agricultural areas, but a prime illegal export commodity for smugglers. There is an opportunity for people to export cockatoos providing the birds are bred in captivity. I support the previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who said that we do not overcome the problem of plagues in mammoth proportions by saying that we are going to export cockatoos. It is said that the rare peregrine falcon could fetch up to $60,000 on the black market in the Middle East. I suspect that it is a lot better for us legally to be getting $60,000 from an Arab sheik rather than having someone smuggling that rare bird overseas.

These are just a few examples of the potential we have here for a thriving new industry. I reject totally the rather innocuous interruption made earlier by those who sit on the Government benches temporarily who said that they do not believe in encouraging the export of cockatoos. I believe that there is absolutely nothing wrong with encouraging the export of native fauna and flora, provided that they are bred or grown in the right environment and provided, most importantly, that they are exported under such conditions that they will not be dead when they arrive on the other side of the globe. The survival rate of smuggled birds is alarmingly low. Estimates put the death rate as high as 90 per cent. That is particularly unacceptable to me, and I suspect that it is unacceptable to all members of the Parliament.

The trapping and shipping of live species contribute to the extinction of many rare species. The penalties as set out in the Bill are sufficiently high, I believe, to discourage some smuggling. But this does not save our endangered species. We need to look at encouraging farmers and businessmen with a sense of enterprise to see the cultivation and breeding of our native flora and fauna as a potential export industry. We need the Government to take a fresh look at the situation in two areas. The first is to allow the commercial propagation of endangered, rare and vulnerable native species. As I said initially, this has been done with the Geraldton wax, the Cooktown orchid and, of course, the freshwater crocodile. When such an industry is firmly established, a levy could be placed on all exports to advance the natural re-establishment of our endangered species into their native areas. Of course, as is the case with research into wheat or any of the other research programs in Australia, there should be a balancing Federal Government contribution. Maybe it would even encourage the States to get involved.

It is terribly important that these endangered species are allowed to be re-established in their natural environment. We have not achieved any- thing if we believe that we can preserve endangered species wholly in hothouses or in gardens in the suburbs or on farms. All of these things need to be re-established in their natural environment from which man has plundered them and taken them away for the last several decades. We need to realise that what may be this country's pest is another country's rarity.

However, words and legislation are simply not enough. It seems to me that if we are fair dinkum about preserving our endangered species we need to institute an education program aimed at informing the general populace about which of our species are endangered. The best place for this to begin is in our schools, with lectures on which animals are on the endangered list, those that are dangerous and should be left alone under any or all circumstances, and those that are harmless. The proper identification of such species by the individual is important. We would not like to see the wilful destruction of harmless creatures because of ignorance. Let us be honest and frank: Those of us who have experience with animals, and maybe a certain concern for them, know full well that no animal or reptile will attack unless the animal or reptile is provoked. People need to be aware of this fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the crocodile?

—It is all right for the honourable member to come up with that type of interjection. He obviously does not know what he is talking about. The simple fact is that, if one invades the crocodile's territory, it will attack. It is an act of provocation. I feel very strongly about these types of issues. Many people start to make rather stupid interjections which bear no relation to the facts and which do not stand up to the facts. I think it is about time that some of those people woke up to themselves and at least approached them on a fair basis.
—Does that extend to your side, Tom? He's leaving you.

—He should stay and learn a bit. People need to be aware of the fact that invasion of its territory is an act of provocation and could result in tragedy, as we have seen recently in northern Queensland. If people do not understand that, quite frankly I do not think we have much hope of preserving our endangered species. Therefore, I call upon this Government, in association with all people in Australia, on a total support basis, to take positive action towards controlling the destruction of our native flora and fauna.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that national pride concerns not only our country and our flag. If we truly believe in national pride, we must have national pride in our native flora and fauna. That is of great importance. It appears to me that we must begin to instil this pride in our children. Our children, in fact, all of us, must have a respect for our native animals and flowers for what they are-our national symbols. We should instil a philosophy of preservation and not destruction, of caring and not neglect. This can begin with the implementation of legislation which encourages our countrymen to take greater care to preserve their heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986. As the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) said in his second reading speech, the purpose of the Bill is to address legal and administrative needs which have become evident in the operation of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. I congratulate the Minister for drawing the attention of honourable members to the necessity for these amendments and for his support for the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Wildlife Protection Act 1982 enabled Australia to meet international obligations for the protection and conservation of the world's wildlife, fauna and flora, under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, that is, CITES. In 1973, Australia and about 70 other countries negotiated the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. The Convention, as I have already said, is commonly known as CITES. It arose from world-wide concern about the adverse effects of unregulated trade on the world's wildlife. Australia ratified CITES in 1976 upon promulgation of the Customs regulations. Those regulations and the prohibited imports and prohibited exports regulations under the Customs Act and various Acts and ordinances relating to Australia's external territories provided the then legislative basis for the control of overseas trade in wildlife. It is pleasing to note that when the Wildlife Protection Act 1982 was introduced in this place on 18 August 1982, it received bipartisan support. I know that this amendment Bill will likewise receive support from honourable members opposite.

The concept of conservation on a world scale is indeed a very worthwhile concept. Protection of and concern for an endangered species should not be left to individual countries to determine. It is a matter of great concern to communities across the globe. People from different regions often have valuable contributions to make towards conservation of the flora and fauna of other nations. A fine example of this can be gleaned from the speech of the honourable member for Robertson, the present Minister, in this place on 18 August 1982, when he drew the attention of honourable members to the fact that, had it not been for President Hoover, who lived here for some years in the latter part of the last century and who developed an affection for the Australian koala, it is likely that there would be no koalas left in Australia today. It was President Hoover who in the 1930s banned the import of koala fur by the United States and thus ended the devastation of Australia's koalas by not providing a market.

The amendments proposed in this Bill can be grouped into four categories. Specifically, they are: To make controls on export and import of certain wildlife more appropriate to their status and the circumstances under which they enter trade; to simplify and improve administrative procedures which have already proved in practice to be unnecessarily complex; to clarify and tighten certain enforcement provisions; and to increase protection for those who provide information leading to the institution of proceedings under the Act. I will refrain from going through each of those points as they have been well canvassed by previous speakers. However, I am compelled to comment on recent reports I have read concerning the illegal trafficking and smuggling of wildlife. I draw the attention of honourable members to an article by Mr Bob Bottom which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 22 July 1985. It referred to Vincent `Big Vinnie' Theresa, a New York Mafia boss turned FBI informer, who took it upon himself to warn that bird smuggling from Australia was getting bigger and bigger in the midst of organised crime. In a telephone interview in 1979, Theresa said bird smuggling from Australia had become interlinked with drug trafficking involving United States Mafia interests. Bird smuggling is a big business involving millions of dollars of illicit profits and pitiful treatment of captured wildlife. Smuggling of birds and other wildlife can be as lucrative as drug trafficking. Each year countless thousands of birds, reptiles and other protected species, including the koala and kangaroo, are smuggled out of Australia through Asia for sale to wealthy buyers in the United States of America and Europe. The annual turnover has been estimated at about $40m.

I am sure honourable members can appreciate the enormity of an illicit industry that has an estimated annual turnover of $40m. According to Mr Bottom, Theresa was named as the American connection for Australian bird smuggling and in December 1984 was indicted in Philadelphia on charges of conspiracy to smuggle rare birds to the United States. It has been stated that the Bill provides severe penalties which are appropriate to the high potential rewards involved in wildlife trafficking. I believe that the penalties do not go far enough. I draw the attention of the House to an article in the West Australian of 22 September 1985 by Mr Alex Harris. Mr Harris writes that the professional smuggler on the other hand can operate the year round, mostly trafficking in adult birds. He buys them through normal channels or traps them himself and then sells them. Again, the losses of animal life are high, but the profits make it worthwhile. Mr Harris informs us that the going rate for a pair of eastern States palm cockatoos, Eclectus parrots or Western Australian red tailed black cockatoos is said to be about $17,000 and for a single corella about $3,000. According to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service annual report for 1984-85, successful prosecutions relating to the illegal export of Australian native fauna were initiated during the year. Two of those prosecutions were heard as indictable offences, related to the attempt to export Australian native birds and Australian native reptiles. Penalties of up to $5,000 were imposed. When one compares the value of a pair of cockatoos or parrots at $17,000 with, firstly, the chance of being caught and, secondly, being fined only $5,000, one sees that this hardly acts as a deterrent. I would like to see a toughening up of the provisions in the Bill relating to the prosecution of illegal wildlife traffickers. These smugglers must be stopped before endangered species are completely gone.

The plight of the endangered orange bellied parrot deserves a mention here. The orange bellied parrot is one of Australia's rarest and most endangered birds, with less than 200 individuals now surviving. Across Port Phillip Bay from my electorate of Dunkley, the area of Swan Island and Swan Bay is one of the habitats of the orange bellied parrots. The urgent need to ensure the protection of this habitat is paramount. We must make certain that these birds cannot be plundered by illegal traffickers in wildlife. If we do not have legislation, these endangered species will be lost forever; a loss not only to us in Australia but to the whole world.

I was shocked and amazed recently to read in the Canberra Times of 3 March 1986 a statement by the Opposition spokesman on trade, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). He is attributed as supporting a statement that the Government should lift bans on the export of non-endangered native bird species. The honourable member for Dawson went on to say:

Such a move would also help eliminate cruel trapping and shipping practices which occurred when birds were smuggled . . . The controlled export of species which were in plague proportions would also help reduce crop damage and thereby aid another export industry.
The honourable member for Dawson said also that it was unfortunate that the Government remained firmly committed to a policy of almost total prohibition of native bird exports. He said:
. . . this dogmatic and blinkered ideological persistence with a non-export policy is only resulting in the capture and wanton killing of species which are agricultural pests . . .

I find it quite sad that the honourable member for Dawson has to resort to the use of such antiquated and emotive terms as `dogmatic' and `blinkered ideological persistence'. I find it difficult to understand why the Opposition, especially in view of its recent introduction of waste watching, would encourage the Government to introduce measures that would be extremely costly to administer. As the Minister has clearly stated on this matter, the Government would have to train staff so that it could station bird identification experts at international airports to prevent rare and endangered species, which may be difficult for a non-expert to tell apart from common species, being taken out under some cover or guise. The honourable member's proposal could open a Pandora's box of new opportunities for organised crime to take advantage of and misuse legal trade. Apart from this, I fail to see how the honourable member could contemplate that the Government should do anything contrary to the spirit of CITES to which, as I have already stated, Australia is a signatory. I am sure that all honourable members are aware that CITES prohibits its signatory countries from exporting and importing threatened species and also discourages any trade in wild animals, except for scientific, zoological and other specific purposes.

I was interested to hear the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) mention education in our schools. I take this opportunity to mention the excellent work that is being done in our schools in educating young people on the benefits of our unique flora and fauna. My daughter Jane attends the Frankston Heights Primary School. Last year, her fourth year at school, one of the projects she did was on endangered species, the endangered bilby. It has inculcated in her and her fellow classmates an appreciation for endangered animals. I publicly thank the teachers of Frankston Heights Primary School for making those who will take over the stewardship of Australia aware of this problem. I am sure that what Jane has learnt in her formative years at that school will be passed on to her children in time and gradually the majority of Australians will appreciate our animals.

I applaud the honourable member for Groom for his statements on the problem of crocodiles in North Queensland. On Sunday night I happened to see part of a show called 60 Minutes. During that show there was a segment on a person who has some very blinkered and bigoted views as to what should happen to crocodiles in that area. I believe that crocodiles are an endangered species which should be looked after in Australia. We have a great opportunity here, as the rest of the world is exploiting its animals, not to exploit these animals. We are a wealthy country; we can set aside areas for crocodiles and they should be left in peace. If their numbers do increase greatly, maybe then they can be shifted to various parts of Queensland but they should not be shot out indiscriminately, as some people in Queensland are advocating at the moment.

I am extremely pleased that this Government takes the issue of the protection of wildlife with regard to import and export regulations so seriously. I congratulate and applaud the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment for the steps he has taken through these amendments to tighten up existing problem areas. I am sure that these measures will do much to enhance the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act and I trust that the Government will continue to address the problems of wildlife protection, of exports and imports, as the need arises. I commend the Bill to the House.

wild trapped common and pest species of birds provided that

There is reference to the fact that 12 crates of animals were loaded into a container at Sydney Airport. The article further suggests that a shipment was foiled just prior to its proposed date of departure from Cairns. That demonstrates quite clearly that a large illegal industry is operating out of this country and it is up to the Government to recognise that fact and move to rectify the problem.

We have exotic and not so exotic animals and birds in this country that are widely sought after by overseas collectors. In the inquiry undertaken into the trafficking in fauna in Australia many witnesses talked of the stamp collectors syndrome-in other words, many people throughout the world want to get these exotic species of Australian wildlife and they will pay very high prices for them. They are connoisseurs of the exotic and, as I said, it was often stated that the stamp collectors syndrome persists in many people. They will obtain those birds and animals regardless of whether we have an export policy. I suggest to the Government and to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), who I know has a deep interest in this subject, that if we allow controlled export we will certainly reduce the number of illegal rackets taking place.

How do these smugglers operate? They operate by conventional methods; that is, through Australian airports. There are plenty of examples of false compartments in suitcases and the like, of people taking out numbers of birds and animals in large overcoats and so forth. The death rate of birds and animals being carried out in those circumstances is very high.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you see the film Gorky Park?

—I cannot say I did. But that is the small-time operation where people carry birds and animals on their person from the country. I am more concerned about the large scale operations that happen in northern Australia. We have 20,000 kilometres of coastline and it is impossible to increase surveillance to an effective level. One would have to give credit to the present Government for at least increasing the surveillance in northern Australia. This was one of the recommendations that came out of the Committee report. Gradually over the years we have seen an improvement in the surveillance of Australia's coastline. Many people in this country do not understand that there are more than 800 airfields in a line between Gladstone in Queensland and Geraldton in Western Australia on which light aircraft can land quite safely and take off again for overseas destinations. SPEECH.PARA: It is very easy for smugglers to use light aircraft to come to Australia's northern shores in particular or to use sea-going craft to enter the thousands of bays and inlets that afford them easy protection and allow them to load birds and animals for transport to overseas destinations and at the same time backload with drugs and illegal immigrants. There is plenty of evidence over many decades of the activities of these people.

Many of the previous speakers in this debate have talked about the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species which is abbreviated to CITES. I suggest to the House that apart from Appendix 1 of the Convention, which talks about endangered species, there ought to be provision in other appendices for the taking of categorised species from the wild. Of course, some of those species are in pest proportions. There is no logic in the argument that there would be difficulties in exporting animals and birds from our airports. We could use the existing facilities that we have in the national parks and wildlife services of the States. The individuals who take species from the wild could be registered and all birds and animals that are to be exported could be handled through State national parks and wildlife services.

Thousands of people around this nation breed many of the sought after birds and animals in captivity. I see no reason why the species that are bred in captivity could not be exported under control. In my view this Government could meet the conditions of CITES in relation to endangered species. It could provide a service to overseas people who desire these birds and animals. It could provide some income for people of this country. It could also direct income, or part of the income, towards nature conservation right across the nation. The Government could alleviate some of the problems that have built up in respect of pest species. After all, many of the species that are sought after by people overseas and for which fairly substantial prices are paid are just pest species that many farmers and graziers throughout this country would like to see reduced substantially. Just as I believe that the Government has adopted a sensible approach in relation to the culling of certain species of kangaroos, I believe it would be possible to adopt a sensible approach in the culling of some pest species.

It is interesting to read a Press statement that was put out by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) on behalf of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers, or CONCOM as it is known. The statement points out that the Council reaffirmed its ban on the live export of Australian fauna, including aviary bred and pest species of birds. It talks about insurmountable problems that would confront any attempt to open an export trade. I suggest to the House that there are no insurmountable problems in relation to the implementation of an export trade. The Press release talks about prohibitive administrative costs. This is not so. It talks about an unacceptably high mortality rate of up to 80 per cent of native birds exported. Once again, I would suggest to the House that, under proper conditions, this is not an argument against the relaxation of our policy. So, all in all, I believe that a lot of illogical arguments were put forward in that Press release. It is also interesting to note that the conservation Ministers from Queensland and the Northern Territory rejected the motion which came from the Commonwealth and the remaining States. So, there is no unanimity of view on this subject from Ministers or, obviously, their departments right throughout the country.

Finally, I would like to reiterate what I said earlier about the failure of the Government to allow the controlled export of certain of our species. It is my view that the Government is aiding and abetting the smuggling of birds from this country. But worse than that, one has to consider the cruelty to the animals that are being smuggled. I am sure that all people concerned about cruelty to animals will realise what I am talking about when I refer to the known death rates associated with the illegal export of birds and animals from Australia.

Apart from that aspect, which is very important, I want to emphasise that there are greater dangers in the importation or the backloading of many hard drugs and, of course, the undesirable practice of bringing in illegal immigrants. That point cannot be stated too strongly. So I call on the Government to review its policy in regard to CITES and the export of non-endangered species. I believe that not to do so would be doing a great service to the smugglers and a great disservice to the vast majority of people who could gain some income and some benefit from the controlled export of so many of our species.

SPEECH.PARA: So I find it quite disturbing to have heard the honourable member for Petrie advocate that we ought to cast aside the real protections that exist in this Act and allow the commercial exploitation of rare species of flora and fauna.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole purpose of the legislation before the House is to regulate legitimate trade in wildlife and to combat illicit trafficking in wildlife, particularly endangered wildlife species. We know that it is a profitable industry and that Queensland has suffered greatly. The honourable member for Dunkley put a figure on it, he quantified it, and said that the illicit trade is worth approximately $40m. He also went on to explain that there were criminality links-that criminal organisations on a world-wide basis had a direct link with the exploitation of wildlife. Again, both the honourable member for Petrie and the honourable member for Dunkley raised the link with drugs. This has also been brought to my attention. For this reason we ought to get tougher, not soften the approach of the legislation before us or pursue the Petrie line. Instead, we ought be saying that we are going to get tougher. What is rare and unique to Australia ought to be kept just that way. To achieve this we not only need law, tough penalties and deterrents, but we certainly need to increase the risk of apprehension. This whole matter concerns me.

We do have State, Federal and local government co-operation and support, but it is my opinion that we will have to intensify this co-operation and the monitoring and policing because, despite the law that exists, despite its upgrading and despite the link that it has internationally, we still have a problem, certainly in country areas of Queensland. I spoke to some National Park and Wildlife and Primary Industry personnel today and it was pointed out to me that the hooded parrot of Queensland and the gang-gang cockatoo are still at risk. The Major Mitchell cockatoo is, again, at risk, as are crocodiles and snakes. It is so simple to export Australian snakes by putting them in Australia Post padded bags.

To come to the aspects of flora, apparently the Cooktown orchid again is at risk. Let us get tougher. Let us not reduce and soften the approach. This cannot be done merely by having laws on the statute books. It is not good enough just to have deterrents by way of penalties; we need to have a community involvement. It amazes me that we can have trafficking going on, but no one seems to notice. It amazes me that people can go through country areas trapping birds and animals, but no one seems to notice. It amazes me that these animals and birds can be kept near ports in major cities for a time and no one seems to notice. I suggest that, if anything, we need to develop a major community awareness. We need to awaken people to what the laws and rules are and to the importance of protecting Australian flora and fauna. We need to promote a community alertness, especially in rural areas, whereby members of the community keep a watchful eye. I am not saying that they should become dobbers, although in these instances I do not think the community would mind if these types of criminals were dobbed in. If a person in a rural area sees someone trapping cockatoos, the local law officer ought to be told, the police ought to be warned. If it is known that someone is keeping unprecedented numbers of birds in a suburb of a city, the authorities should be told. It is not happening. It is no wonder that thousands of Australian birds go overseas illegally year by year. It is no wonder that the trafficking continues.

If the points raised by the honourable member for Petrie would work, I would join him in saying: `Let us do something about it. Let us look at the idea of the export of certain species'. But I do not think it will work. I think we have to get tougher, and we need to call on the community generally and say: `This is your responsibility'. It is not just the responsibility of the politician, the legislator, the police officer or the bureaucrat; it is the responsibility of every person to ensure that we protect what we have. That only comes about by public awareness and I suppose that public awareness only comes through an ongoing education program starting with our young. I have noticed a greater interest amongst young Australians in protecting what belongs to Australia. I notice that this interest is growing. I congratulate State governments for the programs they are adopting in their schools, but we also need to aim our program and our awareness education at the total community. It is a complete community responsibility to protect our flora and fauna from exploitation. Whilst this law has to be commended and the amendments being brought forward by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) are welcomed, the laws and agreements, whilst necessary internationally and nationally, are simply not enough. The Government can achieve its objectives only if it has community support.

I ask that those who consider this question reject the proposition put forward by the honourable member for Petrie. Instead, we should toughen up on what we can export. More importantly, we should increase our apprehension tactics and improve the risk of being caught. That is what it is all about. If that were to happen, truly we would make some major inroads against the criminals who are destroying and devastating Australia's natural resources.
