Let me tell the House a true story, to which I have referred in another place as the case of the galloping budgerigar. This case involved a family in Australia. The father was transferred to New Zealand. He was not transferred in a private capacity; he was attached to the Department of Trade of the Commonwealth of Australia and he was to go to New Zealand in pursuance of his duties. I was the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce at that time. It was a sad time because it was about the time that Sir Phillip Lynch became sick and eventually had to resign. As we all know, he died tragically two years thereafter. The present shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), was the Minister for Industry and Commerce at that time. The case of a little boy in Sydney came across my desk. He was confronted with a situation that his family had to move to New Zealand, which is not really far away. The Minister at the table knows how proud we all are of the links between Hobart and Christchurch and between Hobart and Auckland. Flying to those places is almost like taking an interstate trip.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about comrade Lange.

—That is another story. But those trips are shorter than going to Western Australia. The authorities of the Commonwealth, with the best will in the world, said that the family could go to New Zealand but the budgie could not. The little boy faced the traumatic situation of having to leave behind this pet to which he was very deeply attached. Fortunately, in those days of enlightened government, we had a thing called ministerial discretion, something which disappeared under the totalitarian authoritarianism of the socialist Government which currently occupies the Treasury benches. After accumulating something like 30 pages of submissions, letters and representations, the honourable member for Kooyong, the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, was prepared to approve the flight of the budgie. It went with the rest of the family to New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not just a funny little story. Let me tell the House why it was so critical that a discretion be exercised in this case. The little boy was so distressed about losing his pet, which would have to have been put down by a veterinary surgeon, that he attempted suicide. I give this example not to denigrate the officials of the time who were simply doing their duty but to make a point that when we talk about improving administrative procedures we ought to recognise that in some cases following them can work an injustice.

I note that presently if one wants to take a pet outside Australia one has to have been resident in Australia for four years and the period of ownership of the pet now has to be three years. If my memory is correct it previously used to be at least two years. What does one do with a budgerigar in the situation that I mentioned which has been owned for two years and nine months? What discretion does the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act give to a Minister? Will a family have to be deprived of a pet because of the accident of a few weeks difference in the date of its birth? The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, who is in charge of this Bill, is a very humane person. He is one of the most likable Ministers in the Hawke socialist Government. I am always reluctant to praise publicly any member of the Hawke socialist Government because members tell me it does them no good in the Caucus, but that is another matter.

I hope that this is one aspect which can be looked at. Whilst it has often been said that hard laws make bad cases, I think governments and Ministers are there sometimes to handle 5 per cent of the cases. If they were dealt with strictly according to the administrative procedures, an injustice would occur. Governments and Ministers are there to exercise a proper discretion and, indeed, a touch of humanity.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are the insulation between the people and the bureaucracy.

—The honourable member for O'Connor once again trumps my humble words, because he has just put the issue in a nutshell. The Parliament is indeed the insulation between the people and the bureaucracy. I put to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in most ministerial offices 95 per cent of the decisions made are not difficult; they can be made straight down the line. A Minister can say: `There is the Government policy; there is the legislation; there is the decision'. In the 5 per cent of cases I mentioned ministerial discretion needs to be exercised.
—You need compassion.
—We need compassion. I come to the crux of the Bill, which is the first category. The Bill proposes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to make controls on export and import of certain wildlife more appropriate to their status and the circumstances under which they enter trade.

It will not take me very long to say that as an Australian proud of my nationality, proud of Australia and proud of its fauna and flora, I do not believe that it would be the end of the world if some of our fauna which is in abundance were to be made available in proper circumstances and under proper conditions to other countries. I have seen with my own eyes the joy and excitement in the United States brought about by the arrival of the koalas. Those animals are an enormous attraction. I know that there have been problems with koalas going to Japan and these are matters which must be attended to. However, can anybody really strongly argue that it is the end of the world if, under appropriate circumstances, Australian koalas, which are in abundance, or Australian kangaroos, which are in even more abundance, should be allowed to leave this country? The sulphur crested cockatoo and the galah are also examples. One could hardly say there was a national shortage of those birds and one would be hard pressed to argue that it was the end of the world if a few of them were permitted to display their beauty and charm in places outside Australia. I would like to propose that, in appropriate circumstances, the animals of Australia would be much better diplomats for this country than some of the humans who currently represent us. We have a tremendously abundant natural wealth which we should share with the rest of the world.

As my final point, I take the thoughts of the honourable member for Petrie because he is a very thoughtful, sincere and humane member of of this Parliament. He is also a hard worker and, therefore, is in fact a first rate member of Parliament. What is so wrong with the Government applying its mind and exercising some of the energies which we are told abound in the greatest Ministry since World War II, in coming up with a plan whereby, for example, the export of Australian fauna could be handled through the zoos and universities of this country, particularly the zoos? The cost of running zoos is an ever-increasing burden. Zoos must be run properly or I would rather not have them at all. Why could not someone have the wit to come up with the proposal that this whole matter is handled through non-profit organisations, such as the zoos of Australia, and that the matter is placed in their hands and no others. I do not like the feeling of trade in Australian fauna. It rubs me the wrong way. The honourable member for Petrie and I are ad idem on that. The idea of pieces of silver for Australian fauna is just not my cup of tea. What about the proposition that the zoos of Australia be given exclusive rights to handle the export of Australian fauna under proper controls and conditions? I welcome back the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. I will probably shock him by telling him that in his absence I complimented him. I hope that that does him no harm in Caucus.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had better check up. If you are saying nice things about me, I am in trouble.

—I was about to say `in a spirit of Christian charity'-I think that I had better rephrase that too. My compliments were given across the chamber on a bipartisan basis. However, the Minister is now back. I know that he has been detained by the Government, wracked as it is with problems which have had the Minister in the Cabinet room trying to sort out the economy of Australia and how to prevent this nation from going bankrupt under the policies of the Hawke socialist Government. Could I ask the Minister to look at my proposal that this matter be put into the hands of reputable, recognised non-profit public institutions? I have mentioned the zoos of Australia and I also mention, perhaps, the universities. I suggest that they be given a monopoly-and this suggestion comes from a Liberal-on the export of Australian fauna. I have said that I do not like the talk of Australian trade in fauna; I deplore the monsters-they are not even worthy to be called humans-who are engaged in this multi-million dollar racket whereby Australian birds are carted out of this country in deplorable conditions and die horrible deaths. I am completely with the Minister on that point and I have said that I support the strongest possible protection to those who provide information which will lead to the prosecution, conviction and punishment of these monsters and beasts. I further commended the Minister on the moves that he has made in relation to administrative procedures, but I have asked that he should still retain and exercise a ministerial discretion. My colleague and friend, the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), will tell the Minister at some time of the case of the budgerigar which finally got to New Zealand because of a compassionate and kind Minister at that time, the honourable member for Kooyong.

SPEECH.PARA: Across party lines, I say that the Bill is worthy of support. I commend the Minister for the way in which he has approached the performance of his ministerial duties. He has not been seduced, misled or conned by some of those who use the name of conservation for the purpose of pursuing political objectives which have nothing to do with conservation at all. I am proud that we have a Minister who is prepared to say when statements are made which are not true that they are not true. Other Ministers might think it easier to just go ahead quietly and ignore the radical conservationists who are prepared to twist the truth for political purposes. This Minister, to his great credit, has not done that and I hope that he never will. This Government, to its credit so far, has shown that it is not prepared to be the victim of what I would call bluntly intellectual blackmail of the lowest order. For those reasons, in supporting the Bill, I commend the Government to read the speech of the honourable member for Petrie, take note of its wisdom and act upon it at the earliest opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill when it came into the House in 1982. I expressed some reservations about it then. I support the amendments contained in the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill because I think they are an improvement to the existing legislation. I am afraid that that is about the limit of my support. Faced with the bunkum and ill-informed emotionalism that I have heard in the House today-a discourse which held up a mirror to my own hypocrisy-I am afraid that I will not now deliver the 20 minutes of conventional wisdom which I had compiled. Unlike most people in this House, I have had experience in this trade because I used to trap animals for export to zoos. It was an industry that flourished in South Australia in the 1950s and I might add that in the last year that kangaroos were exported from this country alive-in 1958-59-the company I worked for shipped out something more than 7,000 kangaroos. Those animals were shipped without insurance and were delivered in New York with a very high survival rate. We consistently expected better than 99 per cent live deliveries, a figure which was achieved. Those animals fetched #125 each in New York, and those who remember pounds, shillings and pence will know that in those days one could do a lot with ten bob. Within 18 months of that industry being stopped, we were right in the middle of the export of kangaroo meat, which was sent to West Germany as a replacement for venison. That was a very lucrative market and one which I am ashamed to say was outrageously abused by this country. I have never ever been able to work out why it was so depleting of the fauna of this country to sell animals which were alive, but apparently it was quite okay to sell them as meat. That situation is a monument to the hypocrisy and stupidity of the various conservation groups that abounded in Sydney and Melbourne in those days. Today I am afraid they are all over the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing that must be considered when one looks at this legislation is its impact on Third World countries. There is no doubt that this Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species legislation throughout the world is the forum of the developed, affluent nations. One of the unfortunate things about rare animals is that they mostly choose to live in poor countries. There are conservationists in other parts of the world who take a more realistic view. Today they are looking at the economic rather than the moral imperatives. Last year Zimbabwe earned $US6.5m from hunting rights that were extended to tourists in that country. If the tourists paid about $US500 a day they were allowed to go out and hunt. For every animal they shot they paid a premium-something like $3,000 for an elephant and $780 for a buffalo. There was a bag limit and this provided very valuable assistance to a country that was looking for foreign exchange. I might also add that, while the purists may hate it, a scheme like this is an awfully big incentive to preserve a country's fauna, especially if a government can get that sort of deal for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does that conserve them?

—As a matter of fact, Zimbabwe's record of conservation has improved dramatically in recent times. Let us look at the swallowtail butterfly. There is a $100m trade annually in Australian swallowtail butterflies. Good specimens fetch up to $2,000 each. There has been massive exploitation of the rarer species, such as the Queen Alexandra bird tail butterfly which comes from Papua New Guinea. This exploitation is being supported by unscrupulous dealers. The Papua New Guinea answer to this is to go into butterfly ranching. The people there simply fence off a piece of jungle to keep the goats out, tend flowers that the butterflies like, collect the chrysalides and hatch the pristine butterfly, which fetches the biggest price. Papua New Guinea is falling down here because the European Community, which is the biggest market, has put a ban on the importation of this butterfly because it says that it is endangered. This ban is endangering the industry in Papua New Guinea. If the industry dies it will once more go back into the hands of unscrupulous dealers. The business in Papua New Guinea, supported by the Government there, undoubtedly will ensure the survival of that species.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that there are rare species which are under threat. The crocodile is certainly under threat. Caymans generally are under threat. The rhee bird in South America is under threat-it may even be too late for that bird. There is no doubt that husbanding these animals is a solution there. If we were to look at farming these species we could preserve them. It is something we have to look at. Last year, Japan imported in round figures $US4.5m worth of musk which came from the glands of 11,000 musk deer slaughtered mainly in the Himalayas and China. I do not believe the musk deer can stand that sort of attention. It certainly would be in the musk deer's interests if China took to farming these animals to supply the wants and needs of the Japanese.

Australia is one of the few countries in the world which are not poor and which have some rare and interesting animals. I can tell honourable members that it is not hunting or harvesting that depletes fauna; it is habitat. Destroy the habitat and one destroys the fauna. Let us look at the situation in Australia with the kangaroo. In recent times we have enhanced its habitat. We have put water into areas where kangaroos could not live before because there was no water, just as there are no sacred site claims for Aborigines on the Nullarbor because there was no water and therefore there were no Aborigines there. When I and a few other people pioneered the development on the Nullarbor in 1960 there were no kangaroos there except in exceptionally good seasons when there were a few reds there-a few meglia rufa. Today, kangaroos of all the major species abound on the Nullarbor simply because man has provided a habitat in which they can live. That has happened not just in that area but throughout many vast areas of Australia. It is a nonsense to say that the kangaroo is under threat. I commend the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) for the excellent work that he has done in this regard. I think the publication that he has just commissioned should be distributed widely throughout the world. I would certainly like to help with that distribution.

I would also like to look at a couple of other aspects. I support emu farming in Australia because I believe it is the only project which has economic viability for Aboriginals in remote areas. It has a product of sufficiently high value to counter the distances involved. It needs relatively little capital to get started and it would be supplying a market which is enormous. When I did some promotion of this in Wiluna, Western Australia, I immediately got some very hostile letters, including one from a school teacher in Victoria who is the president of some conservation foundation. I ignored his letter, so he followed it up with a phone call. His observation to me was: `How dare you commercialise half Australia's coat of arms'. The truth is, of course, that we have been feeding the other half to dogs for centuries. That is the city perspective, the ill-informed emotionalism which I find so depressing in this country today. What we need to do, if we really care, to make Aboriginals self-sufficient in remote areas is to provide and develop industries that will give them the economic clout to be proud and independent. Emu farming is one of those industries. It is one that we should be encouraging in Australia. The emu's hide happens to make the finest book binding leather in the world and there is virtually an open-ended market for it. The same can certainly be said of crocodile farming.

Honourable members may recall the headline in the papers in November 1985 that 200,000 budgerigars had perished at Laverton. They drank cyanide water from one of the tailing dams. There was a lot of alarm about this, and it was certainly sad. The truth is that those budgerigars were looking for water in a remote and inhospitable area and if they had not found the cyanide water they would probably have died of thirst anyway. On the Nullarbor in 1982 I saw 20,000 gallon tanks full to the brim with drowned budgerigars-yet the budgerigar abounds. We have listened to the emotional plight of the little boy with his budgerigar. I believe that if that budgerigar was any colour but green the Commonwealth had no right to ban its export because only green budgerigars are found in the wild in Australia; in fact, in the world because Australia is the only country that has budgerigars.

We have heard a lot of talk about organised crime. I can tell honourable members this: If we want to enhance or encourage organised crime we should make products hard to get. If we really wanted to combat organised crime we would license dealers and people to catch these birds. If we had licensed dealers in the field they would be the first people to tell when illegal operations were taking place because it is their industry and their livelihood that is at threat, and if we are serious about it we must consider that. It worked well in Australia during the 1950s. From my experience there was no attempt to sell the rare species that were protected then, such as Naretha parrots and the Princess parrot, polytelis alexandrae. The trade was not in those birds; it was in the basic ones that abounded.

I mentioned habitat a little while ago but let us consider what has happened in Australia. We have destroyed the habitat of the cockatoo but increased its source of food. We have planted millions of acres of wheat and other grains which feed the cockatoos, but we have chopped down the trees in which it used to nest. One of the strategies of the cockatoo when it nests is to find a hole in a tree and use its beak to cut the bark from around that hole and leave it hard and shiny. The reason for this is quite simple; it is to deter goannas, the only predator that that bird faced until we introduced the cat. That was all very well in the days when we had plenty of trees, but now those trees are under pressure because so much bark has come off them. In some areas in which we have the joint problem of rising ground water and the over-population of cockatoos; we are putting enormous stress on the trees. It is quite legal to go out and shoot the cockatoos, but it is illegal to export them. I believe that the Government should consider the organised exploitation of these birds and the taxing of profits at a suitable rate. A 50 per cent tax would be quite equitable. If 50,000 birds were exported from Australia at $1,000 apiece-and I suspect that 50,000 cockatoos is a sustainable figure in world terms-that would bring to Australia a return of something like $50m. Honourable members might just ponder that: If $50m were applied to a 60 per cent interest subsidy it would service a loan of $833m. These are the sorts of things we have to look at. This country abounds with national parks which are national parks in name only. They are not managed and there is no attempt made by State governments to put in any facilities. What happens is that fauna leave these national parks and tend to cause problems in the surrounding properties. If we were to have an industry which was sustainable and giving returns, we could perhaps afford to invest in our national parks and make our national parks more than mere lines on a map. It is something which Australia, if we are truly proud of this country, should be considering.

I would like to pay tribute to the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges). I sat in this House and listened to the debate and I was impressed by his contribution. It was considered and informed. I just want to place on the record the fact that I appreciated what he had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keith Wright didn't.

—I can speak only for my faction. We must look at the real problems of conservation and not let ourselves be blinded by what I call an affluent urban perspective, because the real world is often not as it seems. The danger here is if one goes out and attacks the world as it seems that one often does the very thing one does not want to do. I do not believe that any of these environmentalists or conservationist groups set out to destroy the fauna. But that will be the result of what they do.

SPEECH.PARA: In the pastoral industry, if there is no culling of the kangaroo, there will be wholesale slaughter. I am reminded of a time when I was catching kangaroos for urgent shipment at a place called Boorungie station which is not far from Broken Hill. All night long the locals were out shooting with .303s. It is rather disconcerting to try to catch live kangaroos when spent .303 shells are whistling around one's head. At the end of the night we caught our usual tally of 20 live kangaroos. The locals said: `How did you go?' We said: `We got 20, which is pretty good'. They said: `We shot 800'. That was the sort of situation that was occurring. There was no doubt that the country literally stank because of the dead kangaroo carcases, and foxes abounded. I have always made a habit of shooting foxes because I see them as anathema to the Australian environment. The locals asked me not to shoot the foxes because they helped to eat the carrion. Of course, they would eventually help to eat their lambs at a later date and they would certainly play havoc with a lot of Australian fauna.

With regard to the turtle, there is a total ban on the export of all Australian turtles. There is no doubt that at one time the industry flourished and there was absolutely no management at all. I am prepared to admit that it was a deplorable situation. But there is no real shortage of turtles. They are products which fetch a premium price and the harvesting of them would be well within the bounds of a policy of conservation. The real threat to the turtle is probably when it is nesting and is most vulnerable. On the north-west coast of Australia I have seen foxes waiting on the beaches for the turtles to lay their eggs so that they can dig them up and eat them. Efforts to control foxes in that area would do far more to preserve the turtle than the bans which we impose on their export, piously thinking that we have done our bit.

This story, sadly for Australia, is repeated over and again. In Wyndham-a town in the north-west extremity of this great country, a town facing enormous economic problems, a town in which the abattoirs have closed and there is really no other industry-bird catching was, in my opinion, an honourable profession. It was carried out by people for whom I have the highest regard, many of whom were of Aboriginal descent, who knew and understood the environment and were very careful with the birds that they collected. We have put enormous restraints on that trade. One of life's little ironies that I discovered there was that, while we were banning the catching of a certain species, we were murdering them in great numbers by putting poisoned grain around the Ord irrigation projects to deter invasions of rats. I often think we could have done more to preserve that species had it been living and thriving in zoos throughout the United States and Europe.

We really must consider our priorities in this matter. I think there is room in Australia for a rational program of management. I think that this is the real way in which to combat crime in Australia. I believe that the preservation of species and enhancement of the environment will fit much better in the scenario I have outlined than some of the proposals I have heard in this House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Fisher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleagues for their support. I am very pleased to address the House on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill before the House today. I am particularly pleased to follow that breath of fresh air in this chamber, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). It was interesting that he mentioned that he could speak only for his faction. I recall that recently he mentioned that faction power plays a tremendous role in the Australian Labor Party. I did not agree with everything that the honourable member said in his speech, but at one stage I expected him to declare an open season on the greatest pest confronting Australia today, the Hawke who resides in the Lodge. But I notice that he did not do that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the House today amends the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, legislation introduced with the support of all parties. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has stated that it addresses certain legal and administrative constraints which have become apparent. The Bill tries to address matters in four categories. It seeks to make controls on the export and import of certain wildlife more appropriate to their status and the circumstances under which they enter trade. It seeks to simplify and improve administrative procedures which have proved in practice to be unnecessarily complex. It seeks to clarify and tighten certain enforcement provisions, and it seeks to increase protection for those who provide information leading to the institution of proceedings under the Act.

As members on both sides of the House would be aware, the Opposition does not oppose this Bill. I was pleased to see in the Minister's explanatory memorandum that there are no financial implications emanating from this legislation. No extra costs will be placed on the already heavily overburdened shoulders of the Australian taxpayer. I was pleased to see that the Opposition has set up its Waste Watch Committee which will seek out areas of government mismanagement and areas of government waste. It was interesting to note in its first report that quite a few of those areas have already been identified.

The original Act, which came into effect in 1984, brought together various pieces of legislation which provided conservation controls on the import and export of Australian plants and animals. The Minister claimed that the principal Act enables Australia to meet international obligations for the protection and conservation of the world's wildlife listed in the appendices to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, known as CITES. It also controls the export of native Australian plants and animals and their products and the import of live animals, other than some aquarium fish and domestic stock. I wish to concentrate, as did some other members on this side of the House, on the question of the export of non-endangered native birds. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) raised the question of the approach of the shadow Minister for Trade, that excellent member, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who is now at the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—It is interesting to see that the shadow Minister agrees with my description of him. I have had the benefit of looking at a Press release issued by the honourable member for Dawson and I think that the House is entitled to know exactly what that very effective honourable member said. He issued the Press release on 2 March 1986 at Toowoomba in the great State of Queensland. It is entitled `Bird export ban should be lifted'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Shadow Trade Minister, Ray Braithwaite, said today the ban on commercial export of non-endangered native birds should be lifted in favour of carefully regulated and humane export.
``Recently, a Government sponsored study found that such a move would result in the development of a potentially substantial and economically important export industry,'' Mr Braithwaite said.
``Properly regulated exports would avoid cruel trapping and shipping practices which occur when birds are smuggled, and help eliminate smuggling.''
``Moreover the controlled export of species, which are in plague proportions, would reduce crop damage and so aid another export industry.''

Mr Braithwaite said it was unfortunate the Government remained firmly committed to a policy of almost total prohibition of native bird exports, despite the completion of a study calling for restrictions to be lifted.
``This dogmatic and blinkered ideological persistence with a non-export policy is only resulting in the capture and wanton killing of species which are agricultural pests.''
``With our trade position the way it is, we can't afford to overlook a rural export for which there is world demand and domestic oversupply,'' Mr Braithwaite said.

That is the effect and the wording of the Press release of the honourable member for Dawson. The Minister in his response epitomised the Government's dogmatic and blinkered persistence with its attitude. The Minister denied the claims of the honourable member for Dawson that a Government sponsored report had recommended the lifting of the prohibition to allow export of non-endangered birds. I stress those words `non-endangered birds'. I refer to an article in the Australian of 10 January 1986 under a headline `Government urged to lift export bans on merinos, birds'. I will concentrate only on those aspects of the report which relate to birds; I will leave the discussion on merino sheep for another occasion. The first sentence of the article states:
A report commissioned by the Federal Government has recommended that export restrictions on merino sheep and native birds be lifted.
The article continues:

The report, Import Export Programs for Animals and Animal Products in Australia, was written by W. S. Bulmer, of the Canadian Agriculture Department, and commissioned by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin.
Dr Bulmer found that `the ban on commercial export of non-endangered species--
those words again-
of Australian birds should be lifted in favour of carefully regulated humane export'.
He said strong arguments had been put to support a change of policy. These included:
THERE was a potentially substantial and economically important export industry, given Australia's abundance of birds.
PROPERLY regulated export would avoid cruel trapping and shipping practices which occurred when birds were smuggled.
CONTROLLED reduction of certain species, considered pests in Australia, would reduce crop damage.
BECAUSE of the excellent health of Australian birds, health test requirements would not be restrictive.
Dr Bulmer concluded `the prohibition on the export of native birds is a restrictive policy which favours the capture and killing of the species which are agricultural pests'.

The report completely verifies and supports the attitude of the honourable member for Dawson. His attitude is fully in line with that report, and it is interesting to note that the shadow Minister, who will soon be the Minister, has made a statement which is in line with the report commissioned by the Federal Government. The Minister claimed in his Press release that the report had been prepared by an officer of Agriculture Canada who had been in Australia as part of an exchange of officers earlier this year. I reiterate the words contained in the Australian; `a report commissioned by the Federal Government'. The article goes on to state:

The report, Import Export Programs for Animals and Animal Products in Australia, was written by Dr W. S. Bulmer, of the Canadian Agriculture Department, and commissioned by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin.

I believe that the Minister should explain the discrepancy between the report in the Australian and the report in his Press release. I think that this matter should be looked at. The Minister went on in his Press release to state:
. . . allowing export of the birds would be extremely costly to administer.

The Government would have to train staff so that it could station bird-identification experts at international airports to prevent rare and endangered species, which may be difficult to tell apart from common species, from being taken out under cover.

Surely we already should have at airports people who are able to stop the export of those birds. How much would it cost to educate someone to tell the difference between a cockatoo and a galah, or some of the more exotic species of birds mentioned by honourable members opposite? What about the farmers and rural producers of Australia, who already have high export charges imposed upon them? The Minister has claimed that the Government will have to charge a high fee per bird to offset those costs. I believe that when our Waste Watch Committee is finished with the Minister's Department, we would eliminate a lot of wasteful expenditure and the high fee per bird would not be too bad after all. What is wrong with a person who wants to export--

—I refer the Minister for Housing and Construction to his unequivocal assurance of as recently as a week ago, and repeated yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald, that there was no possibility of the Government removing or lifting the ceiling on home loan interest rates. Does the Minister still stand by this promise?

—The whole question of the housing industry will be considered by Cabinet next week. I conclude my answer by saying that the Government remains committed to the retention of the ceiling on housing interest rates.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. In view of some reports that have appeared in newspapers this week concerning possible decisions or announcements by the Northern Territory Government in connection with the Chamberlain case, has the Attorney been advised or received any information at all concerning any decision that may have been made about the appointment of any type of commission and the terms of reference with which that commission would be charged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I received advice from the Attorney-General in the Northern Territory that he had introduced a Bill this morning to establish a royal commission, or a commission of inquiry, into the Chamberlain case. The Attorney-General did have discussions with me last week, and in turn had discussions with the Chief Justice of the Federal Court of Australia, as to whether a Federal Court judge could be made available to conduct the inquiry. The Commonwealth has all the time been pleased to co-operate, and Mr Justice Morling of the Federal Court will be available for that commission.

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of today's statement in the Northern Territory House of Assembly the Attorney-General was able to inform the Assembly that Mr Justice Morling would be requested to take up that commission as and when the legislation was passed. The legislation was only introduced into the Northern Territory this day and I understand it will take approximately one week before it is likely to be passed. It is certainly not opposed in the Northern Territory. The commission will then take effect in the Northern Territory. It is important, because evidence obviously will be taken from outside the Northern Territory, that there also be a Commonwealth commission. Cabinet has agreed that, following the appointment of the Northern Territory commission, the Commonwealth will make representations to His Excellency the Governor-General requesting that a similar commission be appointed in the Commonwealth of Australia's province. That means that Mr Justice Morling will have two commissions-a commission from the Northern Territory and one from the Commonwealth of Australia.

The terms of reference are wide-ranging. They virtually encompass the provisions of section 475 of the New South Wales Crimes Act, which provides that any doubt or question whatsoever relating to the guilt of a person can be the subject of an inquiry. The Attorney-General in the Northern Territory has made it very clear that it would relate not only to matters subsequent to the trial but also to matters that might well have taken place before the trial. In other words, it will be a very wide-ranging inquiry. I also understand from the Attorney-General in the Northern Territory, so as to clearly indicate the impartial aspect of this inquiry, that solicitors in Sydney, Dawson Waldron, have been instructed to engage counsel to assist the commissioner. I understand Mr Chester Porter, Queen's Counsel of the Sydney Bar, has accepted those instructions and that appointment. I am sure that everybody will be satisfied that this commission will be as impartial and wide-ranging as can be envisaged. The evidence will be of a substantial nature and, accordingly, it might take some time before the commissioner is able to bring in a finding. I would not want to foreshadow when that could be but it will be as early as possible within the limitations of having perhaps to bring evidence from overseas. The terms of reference provide that on the completion of the inquiry and the taking of evidence the commissioner will be able to report on his conclusions. That is the relevant point. On that basis we will be able to advise the Parliament further on the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the frequent assurances given by him and the Treasurer that the Government would not remove or increase the present 13.5 per cent ceiling on home loan interest rates. Will the Prime Minister tell the House today that he still stands by the precise terms of that promise?

—As is so often the case, the admirable Minister for Housing and Construction has given a succinct answer to this question. I can do no better than call upon the words he used, so I do. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that the Government will be considering the whole question of the housing industry in Cabinet next week and say to him, as the Minister for Housing and Construction did, that the Government remains committed to the retention of the ceiling on housing interest rates.

—Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of the claims made by the Opposition spokesmen, notably Senator Chaney and Senator Peter Baume, that the Government has generated racial tension within the community by pursuing a policy designed to meet the land needs of Aboriginal Australians? Is there any substance to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. Yes, I am aware of the criticisms made on a variety of occasions, mainly by Senator Chaney, in which it has been alleged that during the period of the Fraser Government there was a broad consensus between the major political parties on the question of Aboriginal aspirations in respect of land rights. The suggestion is that with the election of the Hawke Government all changed. Of course, the political record shows that it really takes two parties to produce any level of consensus. During the period of the Fraser Government, Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs were in the position whereby members of the Opposition broadly supported the whole thrust of the Woodward recommendations and the criticism of the government of the day was that it was not doing enough, that it was not proceeding quickly enough, but basically there was an approach of general support. When the Hawke Government came to office, while we were still in a process of consultation, still endeavouring to formulate the details of land rights legislation, Senator Chaney and Mr Viner, both former Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs, found that their own Liberal Party State Conference overwhelmingly rejected their pleas for support for the maintenance of a policy of land rights. There is no way that it could be said that I, or any member on this side of the House, could possibly have had any influence in the decisions then being made by that Liberal Party State Conference. Following the rejection of the views of two former Ministers, the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia, Mr Hassell, embarked upon a nationwide visit to his colleagues in each State. Having visited Sydney, he participated in a television program with the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Greiner, on 10 July 1984. What was their position? Let me quote Mr Greiner:

ANSWER.PARA: We do not believe in New South Wales that there is a legitimate case for Aboriginal land rights.
Mr Hassell, on the same program, said:
Land rights is a racist policy and a serious threat to the security and future welfare of Australia.

He visited Melbourne where he was again supported by the Leader of the Liberal Party. Honourable members opposite do not like the political record; that is their problem. This is what he had to say in Melbourne:
People in the suburbs of Melbourne have got to understand that it is their backyards which could be affected as much as anyone in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a humbug and a hypocrite.
—I ask for that to be withdrawn.
—The honourable member will withdraw.
—If the Minister finds that-
—The honourable member will withdraw.
—If the Minister finds that unpalatable, I will withdraw.
—Thank you.
—It is interesting to see that, when confronted with their own political record, the unctuous hypocrisy of Senator Chaney is self-evident. I would simply conclude by saying this: On the issue-
—On a point of order, I ask that the Minister withdraw the suggestion that Senator Chaney was a hypocrite.
—The Minister will withdraw.
—I am happy to withdraw that. I am happy to let Senator Chaney be judged by the political record, and that is essentially what honourable members are complaining about. This House will recall-
—I take a point of order. Madam Speaker, I ask that the remarks about Senator Chaney be withdrawn.
—Order! There is nothing unparliamentary about the remarks. I call the Minister.

—I ask honourable members to recall that when the question of immigration was being debated in this House the gentlemen opposite, just as they were prepared on the issue of Aboriginal land rights, were perfectly happy on the question of racial tensions in the community to act as kinds of political scavengers, up to their armpits in the political dunghill of racial tensions, in order to secure any level of political support for an ailing and failing leadership. When the record is examined, there ought to be a profound sense of shame on the other side of the House for their destruction of consensus, in the area of immigration and certainly in the area of Aboriginal hopes and aspirations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister no doubt recalls coming to my electorate during the last election campaign and at Armidale on 18 November 1984 making the following comment in the course of his rural policy speech:

QUESTION.PARA: No sector stands to gain more from the reduction in interest rates we have achieved. Every one percentage point drop in interest rates means a cut of $35m in farmers' interest bills.

In the light of the seven percentage points increase in interest rates since then and the demonstrable additional costs of $245m to farmers as a result of this Government's high interest rate policy, what advice will he today give farmers, small businessmen and home owners plagued by his Government's continuing high interest rate policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think anyone who understands the issues of macroeconomic policy will see that monetary policy is an indispensable part of our overall economic policy which has been successful in securing sustained economic growth in output and in employment and without debilitating inflation. It is also necessary to pursue a monetary policy in terms of protecting our balance of payments situation. It is so obvious that it is hardly necessary to say it, but everyone in this country would like to see lower interest rates. Of course, what we are about is to secure a situation in which we will be able to enjoy permanently lower interest rates. The macro- economic policy of this Government is set to achieve that position.

ANSWER.PARA: I will continue through the mindless cacophony opposite to point out that, if we want to look at the record of costs as far as the rural sector is concerned, this Government is more than happy to compare its record of achievement against that of our predecessor. In fact, under the previous Government costs to farmers increased on average by over 12 per cent per annum-as I recall, by 12.2 per cent per annum. That was a record of cost increases inflicted upon the rural community by the Government of honourable members opposite-an increase of over 12 per cent per annum, namely, 12.2 per cent per annum. When this Government came in and we got responsible economic management we had a dramatic reduction in the rate of cost increases faced by farmers in this country. Instead of 12.2 per cent per annum which honourable members opposite inflicted upon them, we brought it down to less than 8 per cent. It is because we have been so singularly more successful than honourable members opposite were in government that we will continue to receive the support of the overwhelming majority of the Australian community on this issue.

As well as what we have been able to do in reducing the overall level of cost increase which the mob opposite inflicted upon farmers during their tenure of office-of course in this period it is true that the rural sector as well as the rest of the Australian community has been suffering from high interest rates which have been the unfortunate but necessary concomitant of a tight monetary policy to protect our external situation-it is as well to notice what the benefit of the movement in the external situation has been for the rural sector. The depreciation has been of very considerable significance to the rural sector. Of course, in the period honourable members opposite were in office the rural sector suffered very significantly from the artificially high level of the exchange rate which the mob opposite foisted upon it because they had neither the wit nor the understanding to follow a comprehensive macroeconomic policy which would address the interests of the rural sector as well as the rest of Australia. We have brought about a situation where, in a comprehensive and intelligent macroeconomic policy, the rural sector, about which those opposite bleat so much but did so damn little to help, has been very significantly advantaged by the bringing down of the exchange rate from the artificially high level at which their incompetent economic policies maintained it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Has the Minister noted that the self-styled Wilderness Society has signed a three-year lease for a complete floor in the plush new 22-storey Waldorf Hotel in Sydney at well over $1,000 a week? Can he assure the House that there is no direct Commonwealth grant being used for this? Will he have discussions with the Treasurer to prevent this organisation taking advantage of the taxation rip-off by individuals and corporations in giving normally non-tax deductible donations via the tax exempt Australian Conservation Foundation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Prospect for the question without notice. First of all, I am not quite sure what the honourable member means when he says it is a `self-styled Wilderness Society'. I thought it was the Wilderness Society, self-styled or otherwise. I thought the honourable member for Prospect was a bit more numerate than that because it is under $1,000 a week, not over $1,000 a week.
—It is $55,000 a year.
—No. It is a three-year period, as I understand it.

ANSWER.PARA: Any decisions about the office space accommodation are the Wilderness Society's decisions alone. We provide grants of about $1m per year to conservation bodies in Australia. This year the Wilderness Society received a grant of $40,000. It was a considerable increase on its previous grants because there has been change over the years in the work that is done by different groups. The Wilderness Society has increasingly taken a higher profile and the amount of money does vary from time to time. However, I understand the Society is establishing a retail shop in the city. I am sure that the honourable member, who is a regular visitor to conservation group offices, would be aware that most of these bodies have their offices in grotty little back rooms in back alleys in Sydney and cannot afford prominent space to compete with some of the people in the publicity stakes on a lot of these conservation issues. I think it is good that a conservation group has a prominent site where it can operate a retail shop, sell its wares and distribute information regarding the issues of the day in conservation. I commend it for its initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I remind the Minister that the Prime Minister stated last week that Australia is part of the fastest growing region in the world. It should also be noted that Australia has the lowest growth rate in that area. Given the above, is it true that retailers in Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore are leading a boycott of Australian goods? Is this boycott related to adverse publicity Australia has received in these countries emanating from the Government's implicit support for communist Vietnam? Does the Minister believe it is beneficial for Australia's trading position and for the future of the nation for the Labor socialist Government to continue to pursue a policy towards communist Vietnam which is neither understood nor supported by the majority of Australians and which is implicitly or explicitly opposed by our South East Asian trading partners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure that I followed all the drift of the honourable member's question, but the burden of it seemed to be: Is it the case that some of our important trading partners in our region are taking retaliatory action against Australia in relation to some of our foreign affairs stances to countries in the region, particularly Vietnam? If that is the case, I am certainly not aware of it. At this stage-I am not sure whether they have arrived or whether they are about to arrive-a mission of sellers is coming from South Korea to talk to retailers for the purposes of expanding the range of opportunities for Korean products in this country. As the honourable member would be aware, there is a very heavy imbalance in Australia's favour and the Government has been taking some actions to try to ensure that our long term relationship with Korea, which is a very important one, is underpinned by the progressive development of a more balanced situation of trade between the two countries. Korea has very different political outlooks on a number of questions. It has certainly not tried to use those political differences to disadvantage us at all.

ANSWER.PARA: I think we have been very successful in maintaining a very strong and important relationship with the countries of our region. Indeed, the initiative which the Prime Minister took a couple of years ago in establishing an ongoing dialogue with the Association of South East Asian Nations countries, plus Korea, Japan, New Zealand and so on, has been very important in strengthening trading and other economic relationships which exist between Australia and the other countries of the region-relationships which will be extraordinarily useful to us as we approach the new round of multilateral trade negotiations where we have been able to encourage a greater unanimity of view between Australia and the other countries of the region in relation to these important issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. In my question, I specifically mentioned the countries of Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore, not South Korea.
—There is no point of order.
—Can the Minister for Communications inform the House of the latest developments in the Government's approach to regional broadcasting, both radio and television?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. In relation to regional tele- vision, as is known to the House, the desire of the Government is to bring, as quickly as possible, equalisation of television services to as much of Australia as possible within the shortest period. This is a complicated issue. One of the matters to which the Government had to give a lot of consideration was to balance the position of existing operators and, at the same time, to bring competition into areas where it was possible to do so. That matter was considered last year by the Government and it was considered necessary for more detailed consideration to be given to the proposals that I had put forward. One of the reasons for that was that one of our colleagues described my proposals in relation to competition as being Sunday Too Far Away.
—Was that the Prime Minister?
—No, it was not the Prime Minister. It was, in fact, Senator the Hon. J. N. Button.
—He knows about the J-curve, too.

—It is J. N. Button-J for John is this context, not J for the J-curve. Having regard to that concern, a very highly qualified committee of Cabinet was set up to examine the matter. The study of that committee is now well advanced. I hope that the proposals, on an agreed basis, will go back to Cabinet within the next month or thereabouts.
—Who is on this committee?

—The members of the committee are the most popular Prime Minister in the history of this country; the world's leading Treasurer; Senator Button; and one of the longest serving Ministers for Communications in this place. That is the highly qualified committee to which I have referred.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to radio, as the honourable member will be aware, the forward development unit within the Department of Communications was set up to conduct a study into the future directions of commercial radio. One of the issues raised during that study by the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters was the availability of FM frequencies for new services. In my view, that matter had to be looked at in the context of the whole study of the future directions of commercial radio. Therefore, the FDU was requested to report on an interim basis on that matter by 31 March. The interim report should be available by about that date.

While recognising the concerns of AM operators that they are locked out of the FM mode, I should reiterate that, where possible, an extra independent commercial service remains the first and preferred option of the Government in line with our desire to bring diversity of choice in radio. However, I recognise also that other sections of the broadcasting industry, such as existing FM operators, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and public broadcasters as well as independent applicants for FM licences, have an interest in this matter, and the FDU will take their interest into account in considering the matters put before it and before it reports to me. Finally, I just emphasise that that report will, of course, identify options and will not include recommendations to the Government. It will be along the lines of the report into television which will lay out all of the matters and, in fact, will suggest options for the Government and not recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. In view of the overwhelming and extraordinary growth of public interest in and opposition to the Bill of Rights legislative package and the Government's obvious reluctance to heed the National Party's call for it to withdraw the legislation, will the Attorney-General give the people of Australia the opportunity to express their opinion of this vital and dangerous legislation at a referendum? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only people who seem to be very concerned about the Bill of Rights are the members of the National Party. It is interesting that the National Party appears to have persuaded the Liberal Party that it should now oppose the Bill, because the Liberal Party, when in government of which the National Party was the rump at the time, agreed to set up the Human Rights Commission. That was done under the Fraser Government. I am astounded now to find that, despite the fact that the Commission has been in existence for some years, all of a sudden, because we are giving some teeth by way of legislation and looking at its being able to implement the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, this outburst has come from the honourable member.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it very clear that if governments in Australia, both State and Federal, act in accordance with the International Covenant, they will have nothing at all to fear. I am amazed to think that so much anxiety has been caused by false propaganda. It is just incredible to think that the honourable member's Party so belittles the intelligence of the Australian people that it suggests to them that their property will be taken, that there will be some problems in their being able to conduct their businesses and that people will be affected by an International Covenant adopted by the world and adopted by us as defining human rights for the average Australian. Let me make it very clear: I think the only countries that would be worried about the problems mentioned by honourable members opposite would be those that have dictatorships. That is the real issue. The issue with human rights-

TALK.START.PARA: —You are putting yourself in the same category as Gareth Evans.
—Human rights are ignored.

—Those interjections show that honourable members opposite do not want to hear any answer. The aim of the Bill of Rights is to protect the citizen against the excesses of governments. That is the real issue. Honourable members opposite have nothing to be worried about. If they want fair electoral boundaries, for example, on the basis of equal adult suffrage why are they worried? If honourable members opposite are interested in preventing discrimination whether it be on the grounds of sex, race or equal opportunity of employment, they will find that not one Australian worthy of that name would in any way decry the principles set out in that Covenant.

ANSWER.PARA: The Covenant provides for equality of opportunity. It recognises the dignity of the human being and the rights of a person as against those of the state and that there has to be a principle of justice to guarantee that those rights are adhered to.

The only reason this Bill is being opposed is that honourable members opposite have a fear complex. Basically, that fear complex relates to the gerrymander in Queensland, where the Government of that State is afraid of allowing Queenslanders to exercise their vote on an equal adult suffrage basis because it might affect that Government's opportunity to remain in office. If that is the only criterion on which the honourable gentleman is prepared to support his argument, he should not be prepared to decry the fact that perhaps there ought to be a referendum in Queensland on whether the people agree with the gerrymander. I am very anxious to encourage my Party in Queensland, at a State level, to suggest that at the next State election there be a referendum among Queenslanders as to whether they think that some electorates should be weighted by a figure of four to one. How could any Australian worthy of the name hold his head up in that case and say that he was endorsing the human rights principle of universal suffrage? It is about time that the honourable gentleman woke up to the fact that he is in the National Parliament. Australia has national obligations. We have to set an example to those around us. That cannot be done if we follow what the honourable gentleman has suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce advise the House of government progress aimed at achieving increasing development of locally designed motor vehicles and automotive components for Australia's automotive industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for his question. His knowledge in this area and his concern for the future of the Australian motor industry is well known here. An advertisement for automotive industry grants was recently put in the papers by the Automotive Industry Authority, which was set up as a result of the Button car plan. Sixty-nine applications for grants have been received, covering a diversity of projects from passenger motor vehicles to component parts. A number of projects are being considered by the Authority since the issuing of ministerial directions on the operating of the motor vehicles and components development grants scheme in September last year.

ANSWER.PARA: So far, the Authority has entered into contractual arrangements with three companies. The largest grant by far has been one of $26,460,000 awarded to the Ford Motor Company of Australia Ltd for the design and development of the Falcon replacement car. That is a car which it is hoped will have a significant export income, something that we have not experienced in the motor industry before. To put it in perspective that sum, which sounds an extraordinarily large sum, is in fact only 8 per cent of the overall investment in the development of the new Falcon of $333m by Ford Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly as good as the Magna.

—That car was also from South Australia. A grant of $671,000 was awarded to James N. Kirby Pty Ltd for the design and development of both manual and power variable ratio rack and pinion steering systems to be incorporated in future locally produced vehicles. The Authority is in the final stages of negotiations with five other companies for grant assistance totalling about $7m. Details are not yet available because the negotiations have not yet finished. The number of applications at such an early stage in the scheme's operation indicates that firms are taking advantage of government encouragement for Australian design of vehicles and components in the automotive industry. In the component parts sector applications reflect not only an increase in design input from that sector in response to requests from motor vehicle producers but also an increasing commitment to initiating design changes that develop products salable on both domestic and export markets. I can say that at this early stage the future looks very good indeed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. In view of the fact that today's housing finance statistics reveal, first, that in January new loans made for the purchase of new houses were at the lowest level on record; and, secondly, that finance for housing in January fell by 14.3 per cent compared with December, which is a fall of 35.5 per cent in the last six months, will the Minister admit that the Government's high interest rate policy has created a crisis in the housing industry? If not, will he kindly tell us why this catastrophic fall has occurred?

—The figures released today for the month of January for all significant lenders showed that a total of $784m was lent for housing. Savings banks loans for housing reached a figure of $411m. The main component of that was the Commonwealth Bank's lending figure of $135m and I understand that it will maintain that effort. The State Bank of Victoria is also doing very well. It lent $125m for the month. The fundamental point I wish to make is one which can be made by examining the figures for the December quarter of 1985-86 when all significant lenders reached a total of $2.9 billion for housing loans. That compares with a figure for the same quarter just three years ago of $1.6 billion. Honourable members can see to what extent housing lending has accelerated under this Government. Of course we are not happy with the present level of general interest rates and the Government is making every effort, by switching some emphasis from monetary policy to fiscal policy, to bring general interest rates down. As the Indicative Planning Council says, we believe that will happen during 1986. As to any extra measures that may be necessary, both I and the Prime Minister said at the outset of today's Question Time that we would be examining such measures next week.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. Is it true that Australia Post's letter delivery rate in Sydney has been most satisfactory for some time? Will the Minister kindly confirm this high standard of service by this important government instrumentality?

—I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his question and for his long and continuing interest in Australia Post. It may have been preferable, so that I could give him the sort of detail that he may require in answer to the question, for him to have written one more of his numerous letters relating to this matter. However, as the honourable member for Lowe and other honourable members are aware, last year there was an industrial dispute in New South Wales which caused enormous difficulties to the systems. In fact, the information that the honourable member for Lowe has relayed to the House in his question is correct; there has been a considerable improvement in the performance of Australia Post in New South Wales. On the basis of that improvement, I can tell the honourable member for Lowe that I am confident that that very difficult period we went through last year with Australia Post in New South Wales is probably now over.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Is the non-departmental person who accompanied the Minister on a trip to Italy in October 1985, after which means were contrived to prematurely recall Thomas Walton, Australia's Senior Trade Commissioner and Consul-General in Milan, the same person who has been under final consideration for appointment to Mr Walton's position? If not, why did the Minister contrive to prematurely recall Mr Walton?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Mr Walton's tenure of the position in Milan is being considered by the Australian Trade Commission; it is not something for me to determine.
—Why did you sack him?
—I would be only too happy to go into the details of this case if honourable members would like me to do so.
—Please proceed.

—The fact is that this matter has been the subject of some actions in the court and in fact the proceedings were not continued with because the powers under which I required Mr Walton's recall were transferred to the Australian Trade Commission early in January. The matter is before the Australian Trade Commission and indeed I am not sure about the decisions that the Board of the Commission has made in relation to this matter. It is something about which presumably the Board will report to me when it has made its decision. At the time when I made my decision, the matter was clearly one for ministerial determination. The time for which a person occupies a particular post is a matter for the Minister for Trade to determine under the old Trade Commissioners Act. I determined that the work of the person in question was such that his tenure of the position up to the time when his term would have expired would have left us in a difficult situation in an important year for our trade relations with Italy.
—Because he disagreed with you.
—He told the truth. That is his sin.
—Order! A question has been asked and an answer is being given. Honourable members will not interject.
—Of course there was no disagreement about the facts. Let me not go into the details except to say-
—No, don't do that; it would reveal you.
—I am perfectly happy to provide a proper and full response to this question.
—On oath?

—It is quite clear that the interjecting Deputy Leader of the Opposition has been grievously misinformed about this matter. If he would like to have a look at all the details, I would be perfectly happy to provide them.
—All right. I accept that. Did all the honourable members hear that?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will heed the Chair.

—There is no mystery about this matter. As I said, I would be perfectly happy to provide all the information to the honourable member. As far as I am concerned, our relations with Italy at this time are extraordinarily important for two particular reasons. One is that we have just established a working group to expand trading opportunities between Australia and Italy and one of the emerging outcomes of that is that the Australian motor vehicle industry may indeed begin to provide components to the Italian motor industry which would be a demonstration of the very great success of our motor vehicle industry under this Government, as the Minister for Science revealed earlier today. The second reason is this: In the context of the America's Cup, with two Italian syndicates participating and with the enormous interest about Australia that exists in Italy, it was important that we maximise our opportunities to expand further commercial relations between Australia and Italy. As far as I was concerned, it was important in that context to ensure that our representation in Milan and Rome was of the highest possible standard. That is why I took the action I did.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the second part of the honourable member's question is concerned, any decision that is taken over the appointment of a successor to Mr Walton in Milan is entirely for the Board of the Australian Trade Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a small correction to an answer I gave earlier. I said that the honourable member for Prospect was not numerate in his calculations on the rent. In fact, I was wrong. Confess all is my policy. It was a three-year lease but it was $55,000 a year. I apologise to the honourable member; he is not often right but this time he is very right.
