DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The implications for rural and urban Australians of the Government's economic policies, particularly damaging high interest rates.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Australian Labor Party was first established it arose out of the cries of a significant section of Australia that they were in some way oppressed. That Party, in government, has now translated those cries, with a manner and an array of policies, to ensure that the average Australian-not just the Australian in rural areas, but the Australian in urban areas-is progressively more and more disadvantaged against his colleagues who are members of the trade union movement. I find it interesting that in this debate today those Cabinet Ministers who are responsible for setting Government policy are absenting themselves from the debate. I greatly respect the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) who is at the table. But unfortunately, within the array of government decisions that emerged yesterday in a debate when we looked at the degree to which the housing policies of this Government have fallen amuck, those who take the policy decisions are not prepared to come into this place to debate them.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important that the people of Australia know that at this stage the crisis point in Labor's administration has been reached. We all know that if one embarks on a journey, be it by plane, car, train or, for that matter, any mode of transport, there is what is called a point of no return. The point of no return means that a person has embarked on a journey with the hope of reaching a destination. He has traversed some part of that journey and at that point of the journey when it is a matter no longer of returning to one's origins but of working out whether one will reach one's destination, one must make some very difficult decisions. There is little doubt that the Labor Party is past the point of no return. It is past the point of no return, firstly, because it has forgotten its original charter. Secondly, by ruse and subterfuge it has persisted in policies which are progressively leading to the destruction of the average Australian, and is pursuing policies which, by virtue of their direct application, are removing the ability of productive Australia to pay our way out of the appalling increase in indebtedness with which the Government is burdening us.

Two matters happened today that illustrate the degree to which in this country, in urban and rural Australia, we are rapidly falling into the same quandary. Those of us who represent rural Australia have been saying for a long time in this Parliament that the Government does not understand what is happening. The Government was elected. The breaking of the drought gave it such euphoria and contentment that it thought that, no matter what it did, the rural sector would survive. That was not so and, demonstrably, it is not so. Unless the Government changes its economic direction, thousands upon thousands of those in rural Australia today will be forced off their holdings.

It is not just in rural Australian that this acute pressure is being felt. Yesterday we had a debate about housing. Today we had the release of the housing finance statistics. Honourable members will recall that during Question Time the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) referred to the fact that in January new loans made for the purchase of new houses were the lowest on record-not just the lowest in recent years, but the lowest on record-that finance for housing in January fell by 15.7 per cent to the lowest monthly level in over three years, and that the total decline in housing finance in the last six months is over 30 per cent. In spite of repeated attempts by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) to produce statistics to show how great things are in the housing area, the present forecast is that the commencements of housing in this financial year will fall to about 110,000, which is 20,000 below the average level set by the Fraser-Anthony coalition prior to 1983.

The point is that members of the Government still have not registered what is wrong. If they had listened to AM this morning they would have understood that in a country which has a conservative government there is another way. Peter Birch, the Chief Executive of England's Abbey National Building Society, commenting about home loans and their availability in the United Kingdom, stated:

It's very easy. Money is freely available, rates are coming down and an individual today buying a house shall we say for Australian dollars 100,000 would have no difficulty in getting a loan of three times annual salary for himself and one times annual salary for a wife. So if there is a joint income shall we say of $40 or $50,000, say $40,000 they would have no difficulty in raising up to $160,000. So no problem whatsoever.

That is in a country ruled by a conservative government which cares for people and is concerned to redress the problems of society. What is happening in Australia? Interest rates are going up. Taxes are going up. Inflation is going up. Industrial disputations are going up. And the Government is making a mess of it. In not one area has it addressed the fundamental problems that affect the average Australian. It is a big government for big unions. It is not a good government for little people.

During Question Time I referred to the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on rural matters which was delivered in my electorate on 18 November 1984. Not only because the Prime Minister is inclined to resort to subterfuge but also because his memory is notably short and his ability to control his emotions is equally brief, I think it might be worth while to refer to some of his remarks. He stated:
Sustained economic growth is a fundamental condition for maintaining the strength and prosperity of the Australian rural economy.

He referred to `sustained economic growth'. Let us look at what is happening in Australia. Let us start with the `sustained economic growth' bit. Let us look at our overseas debt. Our total gross external debt as at 30 June 1985 was about $68,500m. Since then it has increased to over $70 billion. My colleague the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), in an excellent speech on the adjournment the other night, assessed the figure at about $75,000m or $20,000 per Australian family, or more than double the 1982 level. So much for the Prime Minister's undertaking that the Government's economic policies would provide strength and prosperity for the Australian rural economy. Our total gross external debt is going up and is more than twice the level it was three years ago.

If that is not bad enough, it coincides with a record in regard to the balance of payments. All members of this place know that the balance of payments is the difference between what one earns and what one buys. This Government, month by month, is finding that the record is running at an average of about $1,000m a month. That $1,000m a month adverse balance of payments-we are spending more than we are getting-is adding to that external debt. The combination of those two factors means that our standards of living are falling. In light of that, the Government, of course, has seen itself totally hamstrung by a prices and incomes accord and a relationship with the trade union movement which means that if Simon calls Bob answers, and if Bill cries Paul says yes. The combination of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-Government drag on this Australian community has meant that the accord has imposed an interest rate regime which denies any business, any export industry, any opportunity of contributing to a redress of that adverse balance of payments problem. So we have an external debt and a continuing adverse balance of payments problem. We have a government that is persisting with a domestic economic policy that has induced a level of interest rates that is absolutely impossible for productive industry. If honourable members on the other side feel that this is all emotion, let me turn their attention to a letter in the Weekend Australian last Saturday, written by a solicitor in a small town in western New South Wales, which states:
. . . for the first time in my working life I advised clients to walk off their farming properties.
I recommend this story to those honourable members who pretend to be concerned about the problems with which people have been faced as a result of the policies of this Government. He said:
Four years ago I acted for them when they . . . borrowed an additional amount from a bank to improve the property.

He mentions that as a result of their hard work and diligence they have fallen further and further behind. They were able to get funds from a government agency for drought relief, but they now owe more than the property is worth. That is not a unique case, but a case that is reflected, sadly, in thousands of households in the western suburbs of Sydney, in the sandbelt country of Melbourne and in every regional and rural town around Australia. The level of debt is rising and the ability of those people to face tomorrow is lessening.
In a climate where the future is uncertain, the inevitable consequence is not just on the breadwinner; it is on the wives and children of those who are there.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should find out what the Fraser Government did to change things.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the current level of interest rates, let me outline the correct position rather than the view we heard today from the Leader of the National Party. If the Opposition wants a realistic assessment of current economic events it should look at the markets, which is what I will do when I return to talk about interest rates. Instead of that we heard from the Leader of the National Party today the incredible concept that we should look to Thatcher's Great Britain for the answers to our economic problems. If ever there is a country in a sad mess, it is Great Britain. Just look at its level of unemployment for a start. I suppose that members of the Opposition do not worry about unemployment; they certainly did not worry about it last time they were in government. If they were in government now we would have another bout of slashing of government spending in the current year, in a quick and untried way, so much so that many more thousands would be thrown into unemployment.

Before I return to interest rates and the market, it is necessary to say that the Australian economy has enjoyed almost three years of strong growth the like of which we have not seen for many years. It is also necessary for me to remind the House that this growth arose out of the National Economic Summit Conference when there was broad community support for the economic strategy of fighting inflation and unemployment simultaneously. The plan was to get economic growth up to a rate of 5 per cent a year, and we have done so; it was to reduce the high level of inflation that we inherited, and we have reduced that high level of inflation; and it was to create jobs, and we have created 600,000 or so jobs. It is a strategy which has been enormously successful and we on this side of the House are proud, as are most people in this country, that the consensus that arose out of the Economic Summit in April 1983 led to these sorts of results. It is a strategy which gave us the prices and incomes accord, and thanks to that accord not only has the inflation rate come down but also industrial disputation has come down.

It is true that there was a need to slow down the economy, and that need arose because we had a balance of payments problem. The balance of payments problem was not anything to do with the volume of our exports; it was not anything to do with the volume of our imports, for the most part. The balance of payments and balance of trade problem we have at present is due to the terms of trade, and that was something that could not have been foretold. In every other instance of economic recovery in the world the terms of trade turned in favour of this country, but unexpected factors have led to the terms of trade turning against us. That is why there has been a balance of payments problem, a problem that now has to be addressed by the present Government and is being addressed by it. I repeat that at the heart of the difficulties with the dollar, and the dollar difficulties resulted from the balance of payments problem and the terms of trade closing against us, was the deterioration in the prices we received for our exports compared with the prices we paid for our imports. They turned against us. The problem has arisen from falls in the prices we receive for many of our rural and mineral commodities. We need only go through some of them. Wheat prices are an obvious problem area. Since December they have fallen by over 4 per cent, and seem sure to fall further, sadly for this country. Between June and December last year wool prices also fell by 5.5 per cent.

These are the facts that we have to face-facts which on no account we could have foretold. This did lead to the necessity for a slowing down in the economy, and that slowing down has been achieved by an increase in interest rates. No one likes the increase in interest rates; nobody pretends that the high level of interest rates is not a political burden, let alone an economic burden. But the Opposition would be far more credible if it put forward its alternative instead of coming forth with all these expenditure measures. It should be saying where it would cut government spending because, true to form, that is what the Fraser Government would have been doing. It would have been slashing government spending right now, throwing more and more people onto the economic scrapheap, throwing them into unemployment and into dole queues. Okay, we have had these high interest rates and they have caused us discomfort, but there are now many signs on the horizon that those difficult days are over. It is a pleasure to say not only politically but also from the point of view of those who have, sadly, been suffering because of high interest rates. After peaking in November-December, professional interest rates eased in the early months of 1986. Ninety-day bank bill yields, after averaging around 19 1/2 per cent in December, have now moved to 17 per cent-still too high, but on the way down. Longer term bond yields have also moved down, with the 10-year yield now at around 13 1/2 per cent after averaging in excess of 15 per cent in November-December.

It is clear that the market does not share the Opposition's deliberately gloomy assessment of the economy. I said I would return to what the market is saying, and that is what it is saying-there is hope on the horizon that there will be some alleviation of the inevitable burdens due to high interest rates. Against that background and increasing signs that tight financial conditions are having an impact on demand, we have taken the view that monetary policy should not stand in the way of any natural fall in market interest rates. The Government considers this validation of the falls in market rates not as a weakening of the stance of monetary policy but as an appropriate response to an easing in the demand for credit and domestic spending. We are conscious of the dangers of allowing monetary policy to carry too much of the burden in the current policy mix. Monetary conditions will continue to be adjusted in line with underlying economic developments. However, attempts to bring interest rates down ahead of market judgment would be counter-productive. So the answer is in the sorts of policies that we have been carrying through. Given the interest rates that the Leader of the National Party has drawn attention to in the rural sector, despite the fact that his constituency has totally lost confidence in his Party-one wonders who the National Party now represents-I want to say something about the things he has raised. He tries to sell the line that this Government is responsible for the difficulties being encountered. I wanted in the last minute available to me to do the Leader of the National Party the courtesy of referring to some of the things he mentioned in his speech, but unfortunately I have not the time to do so.

I think I need to make my main point again. The problems of this country are very much the direct result of the terms of trade. The terms of trade, which turned against us, have led to balance of payments problems which in turn have led to dollar exchange problems. We have addressed those problems in the most appropriate way. Unfortunately that has meant suffering in some quarters in this country due to high interest rates. As I have indicated in my speech, those interest rates are now on the way down. I am looking forward to the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who will speak for the Government in this debate, pointing out the way in which this country is on that growth path which has led on the one hand to a reduction in the rate of inflation and on the other to the growth of jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest rates have gone up in this country by about 7 per cent since the December 1984 election when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that in fact they would be reduced. This has been as a direct result of deliberate Government policy, particularly since last November when, of course, the world's greatest Treasurer opted to push up interest rates rather than take a responsible position and adjust wages policy by renegotiation of the accord, cutting government spending and the deficit. As I said, high interest rates are due at least in part to the high Government deficit. The Hawke Government has run cumulative Budget deficits of $20 billion in the three Keating Budgets-a greater deficit than that in seven Fraser Government Budgets.

The Prime Minister told us during Question Time today to look at his Government's record. Well, let us look at his Government's record. The Hawke Government is the biggest spending government in Australian history, as a proportion of gross domestic product, and has the biggest deficits on record. The current annual rate of deficit is running at $14.4 billion, a blowout of $3 billion on the Budget forecast. There is absolutely no sign of any J curve that we have heard so much about 12 months after devaluation. Wages are pushing up inflation and labour costs by comparison with our trading partners. The level of unemployment is 7.8 per cent and is running higher than for all but five months of the 86 full months of the Fraser Government. The number of business failures has jumped sharply in the past six weeks as high interest rates begin to take their toll.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 244th report of the Committee entitled `Munitions Production Trust Account' and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This brief inquiry by the Committee into the Munitions Production Trust Account was initiated following unfavourable comments made by the Auditor-General in his September 1984 report. The Committee examined the operation of the Munitions Production Trust Account and found that it exists in addition to each of the trust accounts used to operate the Government-owned munitions factories. This trust account was established on 17 February 1956 under section 62a of the Audit Act 1901 to replace the Manufacture of Munitions Trust Account which had operated since 1940.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Munitions Production Trust Account as defined at the time of its creation was to finance the manufacture of munitions in government factories, annexes and industry for departments of the Commonwealth and other governments and authorities; and any other approved service of a munitions factory or annex. The Munitions Production Trust Account can be described as a holding account, financing the production of munitions. It enables factories to obtain reimbursement for production, undertaken in advance of payment, from the Department of Defence or overseas customers. I can see how riveted the honourable members present in the Parliament are by the topic of this report.

Over recent years responsibility for the trust account has been variously with the Department of Industry and Commerce, the Department of Productivity, the Department of Defence Support and most recently, from December 1984, the Department of Defence. The Auditor-General suggested that a separate trust account could be established if necessary to handle overseas transactions where munitions are sold to overseas countries. The Committee discovered that an existing trust account could quite adequately handle overseas munitions transactions; namely, the more general trust account called the Defence-Projects for Other Governments and International Bodies Trust Account. The Committee questions why this trust account and the Munitions Production Trust Account, with their overlapping functions, have not been rationalised.

The Committee concluded that the Munitions Production Trust Account has not been managed well over recent years, with financial records being lost, important procedures not followed and a lack of appropriate control documents. The Committee believes that many of these problems may have arisen because of the form and nature of this trust account, and that such an arrangement may leave itself open to inefficient accounting and management, together with a lack of direct responsibility or an interest in the efficient operation of the trust account. The Committee is also concerned that the Department of Finance has not taken more interest in the operation of the Munitions Production Trust Account and has not become more involved in resolving important problems with this trust account.

The Committee noted that the Munitions Production Trust Account causes the factories to carry out double accounting with increased administrative costs. It concluded that the munitions factories' financial statements would be more accurate, informative and be consistent with accepted accounting standards without this device. The Committee concluded that there could be no cogent reasons for continuing to maintain the Munitions Production Trust Account. I commend the report to honourable members.

This Bill reintroduces into the Parliament the bulk of the provisions of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 that were debated in the Senate but then blocked on 8 October 1985. It does not contain those provisions concerning the structure and composition of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust which were rejected by the Senate. The Bill includes a number of new amendments that are not related to the Trust amendments which are necessary to ensure that aspects of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme operate in an appropriate manner. It is because some of these new amendments are likely to affect an ongoing appropriation that the Bill must originate in this House.

The primary function of the Bill is, as it was of the 1985 Bill, to implement essential reforms relating to the Trust. These reforms are intended to define clearly the Trust's objectives and duties: to strengthen the Trust's ability to manage and invest the superannuation fund in the most effective and efficient manner; to enhance its accountability both to the Parliament and the contributors; and to enable it to operate in competitive financial markets with a degree of freedom and flexibility in investment no less than that afforded the larger private sector superannuation funds. I should make it clear to honourable members that the pressing necessity for reform, the general thrust of this legislation, and its urgency, were matters that were recognised and supported by all the parties when the 1985 Bill was debated in the Senate.

That previous Bill was the culmination of a comprehensive process of review by this Government of the operations of the Trust; a review process which included an inquiry into the management and operations of the Trust by the now Auditor-General, Mr J. V. Monaghan, and an examination of a number of matters associated with the conclusions and recommendations of Mr Monaghan's report by a working party. In addition, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations examined and reported on the 1985 Bill. While approving generally of the provisions and welcoming the Government's prompt action in introducing the Bill, the Standing Committee made four recommendations proposing the insertion of additional material. On behalf of the Government, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) accepted three of the Standing Committee's recommendations. The relevant amendments were incorporated in the previous Bill in the Committee stage of its consideration in the Senate. Of the three amendments, that relating to the method of selection of Trust members is no longer relevant because this Bill does not seek to alter the existing basic structure of the Trust or the existing method of selection of Trust members. The other two amendments form part of the Bill now before the House.

None of the provisions of the 1985 Bill concerning the accountability of the Trust, its objective and duties and its power to manage and invest the Superannuation Fund drew unfavourable reaction during debate in the Senate. The sole matter of contention was the proposed structure of the Trust. Criticism of that proposed structure focused on what the Opposition and the Australian Democrats wrongly characterised as Australian Council of Trade Unions control. That criticism failed to recognise that the proposed structure of the Trust did not provide for ACTU control but rather for the ACTU to act as a channel, a conduit, through which industrial organisations representing the bulk of the contributors to the Fund could put forward persons suitable for nomination to the Trust. The ACTU is the peak council of these organisations and it was cast solely in that co-ordination role.

As honourable members will be aware, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) issued a joint statement on 16 December 1985 concerning guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision and draft operational standards for superannuation schemes. The Government is seeking comment on the draft standards which are a framework for further discussion and development in co-operation with interested groups. One part of the draft operational standards proposes standards for control of new superannuation funds which envisage equal numbers of trustees nominated by members and employers, or unions and employer organisations where appropriate. It is also the Government's intention that, where the productivity award is paid into existing schemes, member-union representation should be encouraged in respect of those schemes. Until the details of the control aspect of the draft operational standards have been firmed up and there is general agreement on the most suitable structure for the controlling bodies of superannuation funds, it would not be appropriate to make any significant changes to the structure of the Trust. Accordingly, for the time being, the Trust will remain as presently constituted under the Act, that is, a full time member and two part time members-all members of the Trust being nominated by the Minister for appointment by the Governor-General.

One change, however, that is being made is to remove the provision that permits the part time position of members' representative on the Trust to be held by a pensioner and which requires pensioner organisations to be involved in the nomination process. Because members' accumulated contributions are paid out of the Fund on retirement, pensioners and their organisations have no further interest in the performance of the Trust and the Fund. For this reason this part time member position has, in practice, only ever been held by a contributor to the scheme and the amendment being made will ensure that this arrangement continues.

The Government recognises that, in today's intensely competitive business environment, the task of managing and investing the Fund, one of the largest superannuation funds in Australia, will demand all the skill and expertise of the members of the Trust. The Government is confident that the present Trust members are equal to this task. However, the question of the size and structure of the Trust will be re-examined in the light of both developments in operational standards for superannuation funds and the demands placed on the existing Trust members.

Other major features of the 1985 Bill relating to the Trust have been retained. The objective and the duties of the Trust are clearly defined. The Bill significantly enhances the accountability of the Trust both to contributors and, as a statutory authority, to the Parliament. The Trust will be required to inform contributors and organisations representative of contributor interests about the management and investment of the Fund, taking into account the need to protect sensitive commercial information. Members of the Trust will be required to divulge to their fellow Trust members any interests they may have that could impinge on their duties and responsibilities, whether of a pecuniary nature or otherwise, and whether direct or indirect.

The Trust will be required to consider the import of any statement of government policy relevant to its functions that may be provided to it by the Minister. Particulars of any such statement, the consideration given and the action taken, if any, will be reported in the Trust's annual report or any interim report. The Government expects that the Trust will endeavour to accommodate both the letter and the spirit of publicly stated government policies bearing on its functions but recognises also that the Trust has responsibilities to contributors. Accountability will be further enhanced by requiring the Trust to furnish to the Minister an interim annual report, together with financial statements, in any circumstance where it is unable to meet its obligation to report to the Parliament within the time specified in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. Interim annual reports and financial statements will be tabled in the Parliament.

The Trust's investment powers will also be significantly enhanced. Investment will be defined in the widest possible terms to include any expenditure designed to obtain a present or future financial return. The Trust will be empowered to utilise external investment management, if considered appropriate, to underwrite or sub-underwrite investments and to control, manage or to protect the value of its investments, or to enhance or protect the return from any investment.

In recognition of the nature of the Trust's operations and that the independence of that operation free from direction is essential, the Bill enables the Trust to employ the staff necessary to carry out its function under terms and conditions determined with the approval of the Minister. Trust staff not covered by the mobility provisions of the Public Service Act will be able to compete for all advertised vacancies in the Australian Public Service. The present staff attached to the Trust are officers of the Department of Finance. They will have the option of accepting offers of employment with the Trust or remaining as departmental officers. It is expected that there will be few, if any, of the present staff who decline offers of employment with the Trust.

In addition to the implementation of reforms essential to the efficient and effective operation of the Trust, the Bill incorporates a number of other amendments to the Superannuation Act 1976. The powers of a secretary to a department under the Public Service Act will be conferred on the Commissioner for Superannuation, who is charged with administering all elements of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme not relating to the management and investment of the Fund. An anomalous situation arising from a deficiency in the original drafting of the Act that has the effect of unintentionally making certain spouses and children of deceased pensioners ineligible for benefits will be corrected. This is one of the new amendments that may affect future appropriations.

The provisions relating to the issue, revocation and variation of benefit classification certificates are being amended following the recent decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to set aside the decision of the Commissioner for Superannuation to issue a benefit classification certificate in relation to Mr P. J. Bewley. The amendments are in accord with the intended purpose of the provisions and clarify that the provisions are to have the meaning attributed to them prior to the Tribunal's decision rather than the meaning adopted by the Tribunal. The amendments are to have effect from 1 July 1976, the date of commencement of the principal Act, but will not affect the Tribunal's decision in relation to Mr Bewley. The Bill also introduces a new provision to allow flexibility in arrangements where persons transfer from the Commonwealth superannuation scheme to another superannuation scheme without necessarily changing employment. This amendment may also affect future appropriations.
Finally, the Bill contains amendments to the cost recovery arrangements under the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976. The amendments will enable the Minister to:
Limit an employer's liability to the cost of the employer-financed share of any benefit that accrued under the scheme to an employee for service with that employer;
Determine that employers who, prior to 1 July 1981, were treated as if exempt from the requirement to meet the cost of superannuation benefits, are formally relieved of the pre-1981 liability; and
Require an employer to meet its liability to the Commonwealth on a pay-as-you-go basis as if the scheme were funded, rather than let the liability build up until benefits are eventually paid.

There is no financial impact on the Government as a result of the changes in respect of the Trust. By regulations made under the Act, all costs involved in the management and investment of the Fund, including staff costs, are borne by the Fund. The Government expects that removal of restrictions on the investment powers of the Trust as proposed in this Bill will enable greater returns to be generated by the Fund for the benefit of contributors. There are no implications for additional expenditure or revenue by conferring Secretary powers on the Commissioner for Superannuation. Minimal future additional costs will result from the changes correcting the anomalous disentitlement from benefits of certain children and spouses. To date, only one case of disentitlement has been identified.

The interpretation of the medical classification provisions adopted by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in its recent decision is not only contrary to the purpose of the provisions, but would have significant additional cost implications if allowed to stand. The Commonwealth would have little or no protection against the risk, and thus the cost, of premature retirement or death because of a physical or mental condition existing at the time a person became a contributor. Thus, the amendments will ensure that the cost of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme does not increase as a result of the Tribunal's decision.

While speaking of the cost of the Commonwealth scheme, the Minister for Finance has asked that I emphasise that, as indicated in this Press release dated 5 December 1985, allowances to be treated as salary for contribution and benefit purposes are to be confined to those presently contemplated by the Superannuation (Salary) Regulations. Where moves are made to have further categories of allowances recognised, immediate legislative action will be taken to ensure that they are not treated as salary. The proposed power to modify the Act by regulations in relation to contributors transferring to other superannuation schemes will not of itself have any financial implications. Additional cost, if any, will depend upon the particular arrangements adopted in specific cases.

The employers that, under the cost recovery arrangements operating prior to 1 July 1981, were treated as if exempt from any liability would, but for the proposed changes, technically have a legal liability to the Commonwealth for the unpaid amounts. However, in practice, because the employers concerned would require additional funds from the Budget to meet the unpaid contributions, the payments by, and to, the Commonwealth would balance out, leaving the budgetary situation no different from what will be the case under the proposed amendment.

All parties have acknowledged the urgency of the reforms in relation to the Trust incorporated in this Bill. To delay further their introduction will compound the damage already done to the interests of the more than 300,000 contributors to the Fund by the failure to pass the 1985 Bill. I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for major reforms to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to better suit the needs of the industry. The reforms are consistent with the Government's policy statement `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities' released as a white paper on 29 January 1986. The reforms will streamline the operation of the Corporation, make it more cost effective and will distribute the cost of funding its operation more evenly across levy payers. Associated with this Bill are the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill, the Grape Research Levy Bill, the Grape Research Levy Collection Bill and the Wine Research (Repeal) Bill. Together these form a package of measures for funding the Corporation, for bringing wine research into line with the provisions of the Rural Industries Research At 1985, thus providing a more stable funding environment, and for establishing grape research arrangements consistent with the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act. This package of legislation and the decision to establish as a separate entity a non-statutory Wine and Grape Industry Advisory Council was developed following some three years of consultations between the Government and the main organisations within the wine and grape industries.

The levy for funding the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation has remained unchanged for 13 years. Some meaningful activity has survived largely because erosion of the real value of the levy by inflation has been partly offset by increased vintages. However, when this Government took office some three years ago certain industry interests expressed concern that the Corporation's funding was totally inadequate for it to be effective, but Corporation moves to increase the levy were opposed by large winemakers. Against this background a committee which included leaders of major national organisations within the wine and grape industries was established to facilitate discussion with the Government on the future of the Corporation and other matters of major importance to the industry. Not all sectors of the industry support this package in full. Some of the large winemakers with the expertise to carry out their own export promotion, et cetera, are opposed to the existence of the Corporation and object to levies upon them being used to finance such a body. However, other sectors of the industry strongly favour continuation of the Corporation. These winemakers support the concept of general administrative backing for export promotion being funded from levy proceeds, with participation in export promotion being voluntary and on a fee for service basis.

The Government is firmly convinced that continuation of the Corporation is in the best long term interest of the industry as a whole. This Bill therefore provides for its continuation but introduces changes which the Government believes constructively address the concerns raised by the larger winemakers. The decision to legislate for funding grape research follows consideration of an industry request for this. Some grapegrowers have expressed opposition to proceeding with grape research at this time. However, they are very much in the minority. The Government believes that an industry-wide commitment to research is essential if the industry's full potential is to be realised. It is therefore fully prepared to play its part and respond to the industry request by providing a funding environment which will serve to achieve this. All interests favour placing wine research funding on a statutory basis. The proposals embodied in this and the associated Bills thus follow full consultation with the industry and very careful consideration of all relevant issues.

The Bill provides for the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to undertake a range of functions similar to those embodied in the principal Act. However, as production-oriented research is being catered for under the Rural Industries Research Act, clause 6 of the Bill provides for deletion of reference to this function. An important change is the way the Corporation will operate in future and its powers have been revised to reflect this.

The Bill provides the Corporation with maximum flexibility to apply the user pays principle in financing its operations. Explicitly, clause 7 empowers the Corporation to charge fees to recover costs associated with the control of exports and for the provision of services including co-ordinating export promotion activities. Thus the burden of payment rests on those using the service and the basic cost of funding the Corporation can be minimised. In keeping with the functions envisaged for the Corporation, the power of the Corporation to buy, sell or otherwise engage in trade in grape products on a commercial basis is removed. This power has not been used by the Corporation. In the past the Corporation has been the only forum in which representatives from the interdependent grapegrowing and winemaking sectors have met on a regular formalised basis. As a result there has been a tendency for it to be used as a forum for airing issues concerning industry or Government policy and it is arguable that the attention and effort of the Corporation have been diverted from its commercial functions.

The Corporation's role is dealing with commercial activities, essentially associated with export promotion and regulation. The Government believes that the commercial roles of statutory marketing authorities require an approach to the composition and selection of the corporation boards quite different from that which has applied in the past. It is not appropriate that the Board comprise persons to represent various sectors of the industry but rather that they have the skills appropriate to their corporate responsibilities. Clause 9 of the Bill reflects the decision to streamline the Corporation's membership, which will be reduced from 14 to eight. The membership will comprise an independent Chairperson, one Commonwealth Government member and six other members to be selected from a wide spectrum of business on the basis of their professional qualifications and work experience in one or more of the fields of winemaking, grapegrowing, marketing, finance, administration or business management. The term of membership will be for a period of up to three years but members will be eligible for re-appointment.

Part IV of the Bill provides for the establishment of a Wine and Brandy Corporation Selection Committee to identify and nominate persons for appointment as specially qualified members of the Corporation by the Minister for Primary Industry. The Selection Committee shall comprise a presiding member selected by the Minister and other members who will be appointed from nominations put forward by declared winemaker organisations. The industry, which provides the levy proceeds for funding the Corporation, will thus play a major part in determining who will sit on the Committee. At this time the relevant organisations are the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association, the Wine and Brandy Co-operative Producers Association of Australia and the Australian Winemakers Forum. Members of the Selection Committee will not be eligible for appointment to the Corporation for at least 12 months after the time their membership of the Committee ceased.

The Bill contains a number of requirements of the Corporation to increase its accountability to the industry it serves and to Parliament through the Minister. The main provision to make the Corporation more accountable to industry members is the requirement, covered in Part IVA of the Bill, for it to convene an annual meeting of representatives of the industry. The annual meeting is to provide an opportunity for industry representatives to consider the most recent annual report of the Corporation, to receive an address by the Chairperson with respect to the performance of the Corporation during that year and to question the members of the Corporation concerning any aspect of its activities. More than one meeting may be held if considered appropriate by the Corporation. Members of the executives of declared winemaker organisations would be invited to attend the meetings. As the Corporation is accountable to these bodies it would not be appropriate for the most senior executive members to be members of the Corporation. The presidents and deputy presidents, or equivalent office holders of national winemaker bodies, will therefore be ineligible for appointment to the Corporation while they remain in office.

Other arrangements to ensure that the Corporation carries out its functions in a business like manner and which also provide the basis for its relationship with the Minister are included in the Bill. For example, Division 1 of Part VA provides that the Corporation will be required to prepare corporate plans every three, four or five years, as appropriate, which will define the principal objectives of the Corporation and outline its intended strategies. In the development of the corporate plan, I would expect that the Corporation will consult with the industry to ensure that the industry's needs and priorities are taken into account.

Division 2 of Part VA of the Bill provides that the Corporation will be required to develop for each successive period of one year an operational plan setting out the particulars of the strategies to be pursued by the Corporation over that period in giving effect to the corporate plan. Both the corporate plans and annual operational plans are to be submitted to the Minister for Primary Industry for agreement. In this way the accountability arrangements focus on the strategies and longer term performance of the Corporation and free it from the need for constant reference to the Minister for detailed approval of each major activity. While key parts of the Corporation's corporate plans may be made widely known to the industry, the Corporation may wish to keep certain elements confidential for commercial reasons.

The Bill also brings into place a number of general reforms designed to provide the responsibility and authority necessary for the Corporation to perform its commercial tasks but within a properly accountable framework. Of significance are the new audit arrangements covered in clauses 21 and 22 of the Bill. Since the Corporation will now be required to convene an annual meeting of representatives of the industry and submit its annual report to those representatives, it is appropriate that it be able to give effect to a preference for a company auditor to audit its financial statements should it so wish. If the Corporation seeks to use a commercial auditor, the Minister for Primary Industry will be responsible for the appointment of the auditor, subject to the Auditor-General's agreement that the auditor is suitable and the agreement of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. On top of these safeguards, the Government will amend the Audit Act 1901 to enable the Auditor-General to set audit standards, to have access to the working papers and reports of the commercial auditor and to comment on the results of any such audits to the Minister and to Parliament. In addition, the Auditor-General will retain a discretionary power to audit the Corporation and report to the Minister and Parliament. This would not involve the certification of the Corporation's accounts if a commercial auditor had been used.

The Corporation will continue to be funded by a levy paid by winemakers on products used in winemaking, that is, fresh and dried grapes and grape juice. The basis of the levy will remain unchanged in that all wineries using the fresh grape equivalent of 20 tonnes or more per annum of grapes and/or juice will be required to pay levy. However, the rate of levy is to be varied and a maximum is to apply to the total amount of levy payable by a single levy payer. Spreading the funding of the Corporation more evenly across levy payers puts a greater share of the funding burden upon those who wish it to continue. The operative rate of levy and maximum payment within the respective maxima will be set by regulation. Initially, an operative rate of $3 per tonne levy and a maximum payment by any levy payer of $10,000 will apply. After allowance is made for those amounts previously provided by the Corporation for research, which will now be funded by a separate levy component, the new operative levy will generate around the same level of funding for the Corporation as before, that is, about $500,000 in a normal year. However, for a leaner operation and with the fee for service approach this amount of funding should be adequate at least initially. The first collections of the composite levy to fund the Corporation and wine research will not be made until 1987-88. Accordingly, the Bill includes transitional provisions for levy imposed under current arrangements to be applied in appropriate proportions for these purposes in 1986-87.

Restructuring the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation will involve no costs to the Commonwealth. Administrative savings could be expected associated with the Corporation having greater autonomy in its day to day affairs. These are difficult times for the rural sector. The continuation and reorganisation of the Corporation is part of a total package of measures designed to benefit the industry over the years ahead. I commend the Bill to honourable members, and table the explanatory memorandum.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on grapes and grape juice delivered to wineries and to other processing establishments, the proceeds of which will be used to finance research on wine grapes and other processed grapes. Administrative and organisational arrangements for the scheme, including establishment of a trust fund and research council, will be in accordance with the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. Specifically excluded from the scheme are those dried grapes in respect of which levy is payable under the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971. At present most grape research is carried out by State departments responsible for agriculture and by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Apart from activity associated with the dried vine fruits industry, which has in place well established arrangements, funding is ad hoc and research tends to be fragmented. The decision to establish a statutory research scheme for grapes and thus place funding on a secure long term basis followed a request by the Wine Grape Growers Council of Australia, detailed consultation with the industry and widespread support from the industry, including from winemakers involved in grape production.

The levy will be imposed on fresh grapes, dried grapes, and grape juice delivered to a winery or other establishment processing 20 tonnes or more of fresh grapes, or an equivalent amount of dried grapes or grape juice. The levy will apply from 1 July 1986, the beginning of the levy year as defined, and the grower of the leviable goods will be liable for payment of the levy. Grapes grown by a processor for processing in his or her own processing establishment will also be leviable. Levy will not be payable on grapes delivered to processors who use the equivalent of less than 20 tonnes of fresh grapes per year. It is estimated that only about 1,000 tonnes of grapes, or 0.2 per cent of an average vintage, will fall into this exempt category and the collection of such levy would not be cost effective. Levy is not payable on juice crushed from grapes which are leviable. The Bill provides for a maximum rate of levy of the equivalent of 50c per tonne for fresh grapes. This allows flexibility to increase the operative rate if industry so wishes. Operative rates of levy are to be set by regulations following consideration of recommendations to the Minister for Primary Industry by relevant industry organisations. After thorough consultation the industry agreed that an initial operative rate of 30c per tonne should apply. This is to commence on 1 July 1986 and will raise around $150,000 annually on a normal vintage. Some time will be needed to build up reserves and develop a research program. Therefore expenditure from the fund and the matching contribution from the Commonwealth are likely to be less in the first year than in future years. In 1987-88 Commonwealth government funds of the order of $100,000 only may be involved.

A Grape and Wine Research Council will be established under the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 to administer the Grape Research Fund and wine research funding arrangements which are the subject of a separate Bill. The Council will comprise an independent chairperson and a government member to be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry plus seven suitably qualified persons selected by a selection committee. The selection committee will consist of the core group appointed for all rural industry research councils plus three members nominated by relevant industry organisations. A co-ordinated research program operating within a secure funding environment clearly will contribute to the development of a more efficient grape and wine sector better able to meet competition from other wine producing countries. The need for such a scheme was recognised in the April 1985 report of the inquiry into the grape and wine industries and through its commitment to matching funding the Government is prepared to play its part in working toward ensuring the future well-being of the grape industry. It thus gives me a deal of satisfaction to bring this legislation before Parliament. I commend the Bill to honourable members, and table the explanatory memorandum.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to revise the levy arrangements for funding the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and to impose a specific levy on winemakers to provide an industry contribution for financing wine research. Proceeds from the current wine grapes levy are used to finance the activities of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, which in turn provides an annual industry contribution for funding research conducted by the Australian Wine Research Institute. Over recent years this industry contribution for funding research has been matched by the Commonwealth on an ad hoc basis. Amendments to the Wine Grapes Levy Act proposed in this Bill will provide for the levy to comprise two separate components. A marketing amount will continue to finance the activities of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, the operation of which is being reformed as provided for in the accompanying Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. The research amount of the levy will provide the industry contribution for wine research, the funding of which will be placed on a more secure long term basis under the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985.

The levy will continue to be payable on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice used in winemaking. The Bill provides for a maximum rate of $5 per tonne for the marketing amount of the levy and a maximum rate of $3 per tonne for the research amount. It also provides for the total amount of marketing levy payable by any single levy payer in any year not to exceed a ceiling of $20,000. Operative rates will be fixed by regulation. Initially, the marketing amount and the research amount of the levy will be $3 per tonne and $1.30 per tonne respectively and the operative ceiling on marketing levy payable will be $10,000. The operative rates of levy and ceiling on marketing levy payable will not be increased without full consultation with winemaker organisations and a reasonable degree of industry support.

The principal centre for the conduct of wine research in Australia is the Australian Wine Research Institute and its funding has been based on an ad hoc arrangement outside the normal statutory rural industry research funding arrangements. The Government fully supports the wine industry's objective of placing funding of the Institute on a secure long term basis so that it can better address the research needs of the industry. A secure funding environment for wine research will be achieved by prescribing the research amount of the wine grapes levy as a levy for the purposes of the Rural Industries Research Act and establishing pursuant to that Act arrangements for administering wine and grape research funding.

Separate Bills within this package of legislation provide for grape industry research funding arrangements. A grape and wine research trust fund will be established with separate accounts to receive the proceeds of the research component of the wine grapes levy and the grape research levy. The Government is prepared to match expenditure of industry money from the fund up to a maximum level of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the wine and the grape industries. Should industry so wish, and subject to normal Budget considerations, this level could be achieved over a period of five years.

A single Grape and Wine Research Council will be established to administer the distribution of funds for both wine and grape research. This is being done with industry support to provide administrative savings and to facilitate co-ordination of research in each of these sectors where appropriate projects are involved. In addition to an independent chairperson and a government member appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry, the Research Council will compromise seven members with appropriate qualifications. These members will be selected by a selection committee comprising the core group, which I have appointed for all rural industry research councils, plus three other members nominated by relevant winemaker and grapegrower organisations.

Each component of the levy will be collected under the Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act 1979 which provides for payment in two instalments at the end of September and the end of March in the financial year following that in which liability for levy is incurred. As the amending legislation will become effective on 1 July 1986, the first levy collections will not be made until 1987-88. It is estimated that in that year the cost to the Commonwealth by way of matching contribution to the wine account of the research trust fund will be about $660,000.

It will be necessary to provide for on-going matching financing of the Australian Wine Research Institute during 1986-87 as current ad hoc arrangements terminate at 30 June this year. Accordingly, provision has been made in the related Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill for an appropriate proportion of the existing wine grape levy imposed in 1985-86 but which will not be payable until 1986-87, to be deemed to be a research levy for the purpose of the Rural Industries Research Act. This will enable these funds to be paid into the trust fund and to be matched by the Commonwealth when expended from that fund.

Wine industry representatives have made it clear that the primary purpose of the new funding arrangements should be to secure the financial future of the Australian Wine Research Institute. Accordingly, it is intended that the bulk of the wine research levy proceeds be allocated by the Grape and Wine Research Council to meeting the Institute's research funding needs. At the same time, to the extent that availability of funds permits, other wine research projects could be considered for support from the fund.

In addition to the on-going cost to the Commonwealth of matching expenditure of wine research levy proceeds, there will be a one-off cost to my Department associated with changes which will be necessary to ensure efficient collection of the marketing amount of the modified wine grapes levy. This is estimated in the order of $20,000.

The measures proposed in this Bill will provide the basis for funding the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation in a way that address the demands and concerns of industry and will create a stable long term funding environment for wine research which will help the industry more fully to realise its potential. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I table the explanatory memorandum.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, for Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the Wine Research Act 1955 and provide for the disbursement of the moneys standing to the credit of the wine research trust fund established under that Act. The associated Bills within this package will bring the funding and administration of wine research within the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act and will establish, for the first time, grape research arrangements consistent with that Act. A new grape and wine research trust fund will be set up for this purpose.

A capital sum of $800,000 stands to the credit of the wine research trust fund. Interest on this amount has been paid in recent years to the Australian Wine Research Institute as a component of a Commonwealth contribution to match industry funding of the Institute. An extensive history attaches to the origins of the capital sum. Originally it was derived from the proceeds of an excise duty on spirit used in the fortification of wine. The duty was paid into a wine export encouragement account and used to finance a bounty on wine exported. In 1947 the bounty was discontinued and there remained a surplus in the encouragement account of some $2.2m. Under the Wine Export Bounty Act of 1947, about $1.2m was transferred to Consolidated Revenue and the balance of $1m was placed in the wine industry assistance account. Under this Act moneys in the trust fund could be expended at any time within 10 years for assisting the winemaking industry.

Following a subsequent Tariff Board recommendation, a government-industry investigation was conducted into extension of research in the wine industry. This led to the establishment of the Australian Wine Research Institute and the transfer, under the Wine Research Act 1955, of funds in the wine industry assistance account to the wine research trust fund established under the 1955 Act. A sum of $200,000 was allocated to the Institute for capital expenditure leaving the present capital sum of $800,000 in the fund.

The Commonwealth has contributed to the financing of wine research conducted at the Wine Research Institute since its inception in 1955. A five-year funding plan commenced in 1978-79 and since 1979-80 the Commonwealth has fully matched contributions provided by grants from the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation which itself is funded through a levy paid by wine makers on products used in winemaking. The five-year plan ended in 1982-83 and since then matching Commonwealth funding has been provided by the Government on an annual basis. From 1 July 1986 onwards matching Commonwealth funding for wine research at the Institute will be provided in accordance with the Rural Industries Research Act 1985.

Clause 4 of this Bill provides for an amount of $300,000 to be paid out of the existing wine research trust fund to the proposed grape and wine research trust fund for the purpose of grape research. It also provides for the balance of the moneys in the fund, including any interest, to be paid to the Australian Wine Research Institute. This apportionment between wine and grape research is approximately proportional to the annual gross values of production for wine and wine grapes respectively. The amount of $300,000, which will not be matched by the Commonwealth, will be equivalent to about one year's matched funding for grape research at a levy rate of 30c per tonne, the initial operative rate to apply for grape research.

The direct payment of funds to the Australian Wine Research Institute should help the Institute to meet certain capital and maintenance expenses not eligible to be met by grants from the proposed grape and wine research trust fund. This will constitute a one-off Budget outlay. The $300,000 paid into the grape and wine research trust fund will be a transfer within the public accounts system.

Clause 5 of this Bill provides for the repeal of the Wine Research Act 1955 on a day to be fixed by proclamation after the last payment is made from the wine research trust fund. The disbursement of funds to both winemakers and grapegrowers as proposed is equitable and will help to establish research under the new arrangements on a firm footing. I commend this Bill to honourable members and I table the explanatory memorandum.
