DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE PRACTICES (TRANSFER OF MARKET DOMINANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will ensure that section 50 of the Trade Practices Act does not apply to the mere transfer of a dominant position in a market from one person to another, commonly known as `bare transfers of monopoly power'. This Bill is virtually identical to provisions contained in the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985 which was passed by this House in November 1985. The Government is bringing forward these measures as a separate Bill having regard to views expressed in the Senate about the Bill in its earlier form and the particular attention which has been focussed on these provisions. Until the last few weeks, this provision, both before it was embodied in a Bill and afterwards, attracted no criticism and was widely supported to overcome an apparent anomaly in the existing application of section 50.

The Bill received the endorsement of virtually the majority of the Senate, but because it encompassed other provisions and the Liberal Party of Australia indicated it was going to vote against it, which would virtually nullify the intention of section 50 and certainly nullify the will of the Parliament, the Government has been obliged to bring it in in separate form. This anomaly arose when the original merger test was changed in 1977 to the present test of acquisition of market dominance. Prior to 1977, the Act did not affect bare transfers of monopoly power, and there was no public discussion at the time the Act was amended in 1977 to suggest that it should cover such situations. However, a decision by a single judge of the Federal Court held that the section did extend to bare transfers. The Act was not intended to, and should not, interfere with bare transfers of monopoly power, because it is a competition statute; bare transfers of monopoly power are, by their very nature, neutral in competitive terms. In other words, the change in ownership of an existing dominant firm, with nothing more, will normally have no effect on competition.

The practical difficulties arising from this anomaly were demonstrated in the acquisition in 1982 of the Swan Brewery Co. Ltd, a dominant firm in the Western Australian market, by Bond Corporation Pty Ltd. At that time the Trade Practices Commission decided not to take action against Bond Corporation, notwithstanding the apparent breach of section 50, because the Commission felt, as a competition authority, the acquisition was at worst competition neutral. The difficulties experienced by the Commission were exacerbated because, whilst Bond applied for authorisation of the acquisition, the Commission could find no public benefit to enable it to grant authorisation. This was because the authorisation test for mergers is predicated on mergers having an effect on competition, and is therefore inappropriate for bare transfers of monopoly power. In any bare transfer situation it is often difficult to establish a net public benefit. Bare transfers are normally neutral in this area. Thus whilst the Commission did not authorise the Bond/Swan merger, it also decided not to act against it. It is clearly unsatisfactory that this situation should continue and to this end this Bill recognises the reality that bare transfers of monopoly power are not appropriate to be dealt with by the competition authority under the Trade Practices Act.

This whole issue has been brought to a head by the recent offer by Bell Resources Ltd for shares in Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. There has been much confusion about what the Trade Practices Act does in this particular case, and it is appropriate that I give some explanation here. Whether the Bell offer, if successful, would amount to an acquisition by Bell of dominance in a market is a matter which only the court can determine. If it were held to be so, Bell would be in breach of the Trade Practices Act once the acquisition occurred, and it may be possible for the Trade Practices Commission to obtain an injunction to prevent such a breach of the Act taking place. Indeed, the Trade Practices Commission instituted proceedings on 26 February last seeking such an order and seeking interim restraining orders until the will of the Parliament is known; in the event the court required Bell to give the Commission two days notice of the issuing offer documents, which would enable the Commission to reassess its position at that time whether it wished to pursue an application for injunction.

In any such proceedings, there is no inquiry into the public benefits or detriments of the Bell bid. The only question to be decided by the court is whether the bid, if successful, would result in the acquisition of dominance of a market by Bell, and thereby breach section 50 and, if so, whether on the balance of convenience the court should grant an injunction restraining Bell from continuing with its offer. The only way that an inquiry into the public benefits of this offer could be undertaken by the Trade Practices Commission is if Bell chose to apply for authorisation of its acquisition. This it has not done. Nor is there any guarantee that it would do so, even if the Commission pursued its injunction proceedings; it is a matter entirely for Bell to decide. Such an investigation by the Commission cannot be initiated by the Government either. Therefore, if the Act continues to apply to bare transfers of monopoly power, that would not in any way guarantee that such transfers will be the subject of inquiry on public benefit grounds by the Trade Practices Commission or anyone else. On the contrary, the only result would be the very undesirable one that the Trade Practices Act would unintentionally make existing monopolies effectively takeover-proof because such takeovers would be prohibited by section 50, and the authorisation test would be virtually impossible to satisfy. The provisions in this Bill were first mooted quite some time ago and were embodied in a Bill, and passed by this House, in November last year, well before the Bell bid was made. The amendment will apply to any acquisition which takes place after the commencement of the legislation. Any acquisition which takes place before that date will stand to be considered under the present law. It could be argued that not to proceed with this amendment would in reality be changing the rules which could reasonably have been anticipated to apply by now. I commend the Bill to the House and I produce an explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is to strengthen and improve the working of the Trade Practices Act 1974 in significant respects. It provides for the amendment of key provisions directed at restrictive trade practices in order to increase their effectiveness. It includes important new provisions to extend the protection afforded to consumers by the Act. The Bill also clarifies the intended meaning of a number of provisions and effects other changes for which experience with the legislation has shown a need. This Bill supersedes the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985 which will be withdrawn from the Senate. It differs from the earlier Bill principally in that proposed sub-section 50 (2c), relating to what are commonly called bare transfers of monopoly power, has been deleted.

It has become apparent that the Trade Practices Amendment Bill was likely to have been rejected by the Senate, notwithstanding that the majority of senators support virtually the whole Bill, because the Bill contained sub-section 50 (2c). The Government is determined that the major reforms and improvements in this Bill should not be shelved or delayed as a bargaining chip in relation to the quite different question of government action concerning the current bid by Bell Resources Ltd for shares in Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. The Government will not abandon consumers and reputable, competitive businesses who need now the protection and assistance which this Bill provides. The Trade Practices Act is a most important piece of legislation for the regulation of business practices in Australia. It is now some nine years since the Act was last comprehensively reviewed and it is time to address a number of problems which have arisen.

The Government has demonstrated its sound economic management and its commitment to restoring the efficiency and vitality of Australian industry, with consequent benefits in increased employment opportunities and greater availability of reasonably priced commodities. The Trade Practices Act plays an important role in ensuring that the maximum benefits are obtained through an efficient allocation of our national resources, as well as protecting the interests of the consuming public and reputable businesses. The Government attaches great importance to ensuring that the Act is effectively and appropriately achieving its dual aims of promoting efficiency through competition, and thereby ensuring goods are provided to the consumer at the cheapest price, and providing consumers and business people with an appropriate measure of protection against unscrupulous traders.

This Bill together with its companion Bill, the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill, represent the outcome of a major review of both the competition and consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act which was commenced immediately this Government came to office. The review, which was undertaken without preconceived notions or entrenched attitudes, led to the issuing in February 1984 of a Green Paper entitled `The Trade Practices Act: Proposals for Change'.

The shipping provisions in Part X of the Act, administered by my colleague the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), are the subject of a separate review and are not dealt with in this Bill. That review has resulted in the recent release of the Liner Shipping Report. The introduction to the Green Paper indicated that it was intended to be a catalyst for public discussion and debate about the Trade Practices Act. The Green Paper succeeded in fostering debate, and 120 submissions were received from a wide range of groups including large and small business groups, representatives of other special interest groups, trade unions, consumer organisations, academics and other individuals. The original proposals were substantially reviewed in the light of these comments. Further changes were made following consultations earlier this year with key interest groups including large and small business, consumers and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The process of consultation was extensive and proved valuable. As a result of that process, a number of the provisions of the Bill differ in significant respects from the proposals which were put forward in the Green Paper. The Bill also contains some provisions, not foreshadowed in the Green Paper, to deal with specific problems that have come to light since that paper was published.

Proposals for recall of unsafe products were canvassed in a White Paper entitled `Recall of Unsafe Products` issued for public comment by the Office of Consumer Affairs in my Department in June 1985. The paper was the culmination of discussion over some years with industry and consumer groups on the options for an effective product recall system. The proposals in the Bill have been developed in the light of that process of consultation and of comments received on the White Paper.

As indicated in the Australian Labor Party platform, this Government is committed to the development of uniform consumer protection legislation throughout Australia. The Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers is actively pursuing this issue, and has created a special working party of officials. Together with the Green Paper, the Government released a list of amendments to the Act sought by the State and Territory governments to facilitate the achievement of uniformity by making the Act a suitable basis for mirror legislation elsewhere in the Commonwealth. Public comment was invited and extensive consultation with the State and Territory governments has taken place. Some of the amendments to Division 1 of Part V have been formulated specifically to make Division 1 a more suitable basis for mirror legislation. Several States have now indicated their willingness to enact legislation mirroring the majority of Division 1 of Part V and related provisions in Part VI of the Act as proposed to be amended.

I cannot overemphasise the importance of achieving uniform legislation in the consumer protection areas. Differences and conflicts between legislative provisions in force in the various jurisdictions can pose real problems for businesses and cause confusion on the part of consumers. By promoting uniform consumer protection legislation throughout the Commonwealth, it is expected that the costs of compliance for business, and ultimately the community, will be reduced. The Government will be actively encouraging those States which have not yet undertaken to enact mirror legislation to do so, and will be seeking to ensure that the uniformity is maintained in the future. Once the so-called mirror fair trading legislation is enacted, we will turn our attention to other areas of consumer protection law and will seek to promote uniformity in those areas also. The question of uniformity is not a major problem in relation to the competition provisions in Part IV of the Act since the States have not generally legislated in this area.

The Government, in its approach to business regulation, is committed to ensuring that unnecessary existing regulation is wound back, and adequate justification is put forward for new regulation. The Trade Practices Act lays down rules designed to preserve an environment in which the forces of competition can be effective and, at the same time, to protect consumers and reputable businesses from practices which are unfair. Beyond that, the Act does not seek to regulate the way in which firms carry on their businesses. Its aim is to enable businesses to make their own decisions in a free but fair market. Anti-competitive private regulation of business can be just as restrictive as, or even more inhibiting than, government regulation without being based on the same broad concern with public interest. In improving the effectiveness of the Trade Practices Act, we will ensure that anti-competitive private regulation of business is kept to a minimum, so that free and fair competition becomes the prime regulator for business.
Content of Bill

The more important features of the Bill, which I will now outline, represent significant advances in restrictive trade practice and consumer protection law. Mr Deputy Speaker, from here, the speech is the same as that which was delivered at the time of the introduction of the other Bill on 9 October last year, but it has to be read into Hansard.
Definition of `consumer'

The definition of `consumer' in section 4b determines the types of transactions to which the conditions and warranties contained in Division 2 of Part V apply. The current definition, which involves a monetary limit of $15,000 on some transactions, was set in 1977. The real value of that monetary limit has been significantly eroded since that time. It is proposed to increase the monetary limit to $40,000 to restore the protection given by the Act to consumer and small business purchasers. Also, the Government sees a need to provide protection for truck owner-operators whose business is directly affected by the dependability of their vehicles. After consideration of the recommendation of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry-the May report-section 4b is to be amended to provide to purchasers of commercial road vehicles the protection given to consumers under Division 2 of Part V of the Act.
Misuse of Market Power

A competitive economy requires an appropriate mix of efficient businesses, both large and small. Whilst large enterprises may frequently have advantages of economies of scale, there are many occasions when large size does not of itself mean greater efficiency. However, a large enterprise may be able to exercise enormous market power, either as buyer or seller, to the detriment of its competitors and the competitive process. Accordingly an effective provision controlling misuse of market power is most important to ensure that small businesses are given a measure of protection from the predatory actions of powerful competitors. Unfortunately, section 46 as presently drafted has proved of quite limited effectiveness in achieving that result, principally because the section applies only to monopolists or those with overwhelming market dominance. Even in those cases, it has been extremely difficult for a plaintiff to establish the requisite predatory purpose on the part of the defendant corporation.

The amendments proposed in clause 17 address these two problems and are designed to make section 46 much more effective. The test for the application of the section is to be reduced from that of a corporation being in a position substantially to control a market to a test of whether a corporation has a substantial degree of market power. As well as monopolists, section 46 will now apply to major participants in an oligopolistic market and in some cases, to a leading firm in a less concentrated market. The amendment will also make it clear that the court can infer the requisite predatory purpose from the conduct of the corporation or from the surrounding circumstances. Section 46 in its proposed form, which will be described as misuse of market power rather than monopolisation, is not aimed at size or at competitive behaviour as such of strong businesses. What is being aimed at is the misuse by a business of its market power. Examples of misuse of market power may include in certain circumstances, predatory pricing or refusal to supply.
Price Discrimination

I should mention that the Bill does not propose amendments to section 49, which deals with price discrimination. The Government has concluded that amendments of the kind which were canvassed in the Green Paper could have unintended and undesirable effects in particular leading to price rigidity. However, predatory price discrimination can be merely one manifestation of misuse of market power. The strengthening of section 46, and its more effective application to powerful buyers, will extend the potential application of that provision to predatory price discrimination.
Mergers

There has been much public debate recently about the level of merger activity in the Australian economy and the extent to which it should be regulated. Whilst the level of the debate has intensified recently following merger activity in the retail sector and in other markets, the public discussion was largely initiated by proposals in the Green Paper relating to section 50. Section 50 prohibits mergers which will result in a corporation being able to control or dominate a market, except where prior authorisation is obtained, on public benefit grounds, from the Trade Practices Commission. The Bill will close several loopholes which have come to light in section 50 in the last few years. The relevant provisions are directed to joint venture acquisitions and acquisitions by natural persons. Clause 19 inserts a new section 50A to deal with offshore mergers which affect a market in Australia.

The Government is firmly committed to the encouragement of efficient Australian industry and to increasing our competitiveness on world markets. It has been decided that the existing `dominance' test in section 50 should remain essentially unchanged. The coverage of section 50 will not be extended beyond those mergers which result in undue concentration in a market. The competitive conduct of firms which increase their market power as a result of other mergers will be subject to scrutiny under section 46 as proposed to be amended. At present the Act provides an opportunity for merger participants to seek authorisation from the Trade Practices Commission on public benefit grounds. Some business groups have claimed that the existing authorisation procedures are not adequate for dealing with industry restructuring. While the Government does not accept this view, this has resulted in reluctance to approach the Commission to ascertain its views on possible authorisation. The Commission has, however, made it clear that it regards desirable industry restructuring as a public benefit and has been prepared to authorise mergers for that purpose. In recognition of the reluctance and time constraints in merger cases, the Bill contains provisions designed to speed up considerably the authorisation process. In addition, the Bill widens the scope of directions which the Minister may give to the Commission pursuant to section 29. This will provide greater flexibility in relation to directions which can be given to the Commission in respect of particular issues to be taken into account or bodies to be consulted in authorisation cases. In this respect I am considering directing the Commission to consult the Industries Assistance Commission in such matters.
Other Changes in Competition Provisions

The Bill contains a number of other provisions which are of significance in relation to Part IV. By clause 51, the divestiture remedy in section 81 is being made more effective, particularly where the parties to the merger have conspired to breach section 50. To ensure Australia's international relations are not adversely affected, private proceedings which rely on the extraterritorial operation of the Act will require the Minister's consent. Provisions relating to the disclosure of financial interests by members of the Commission and the Tribunal are being brought into line with current practice. Also, it will now be made clear that the Court can grant consent injunctions and consent divestiture orders, and the Tribunal will be able to make consent determinations, without the need to have a full hearing of the matter.
Prohibition Against Unconscionable Conduct

The Green Paper proposed a prohibition on unconscionable conduct by corporations in relation to a contract or proposed contract. Following consultation with business, industry and consumer groups, the scope of this amendment has been refined and the proposed section 52a will now prohibit, on a civil basis, unconscionable conduct by corporations in relation to consumer-type transactions. Where a contravention is proved, remedies under section 87 will be available, and the Trade Practices Commission will enforce the section by seeking injunctions where appropriate. The section is directed at conduct which, while it may not be misleading or deceptive, is nevertheless clearly unfair or unreasonable. For example, a corporation which attempted to take advantage of a buyer's obvious lack of understanding of a transaction might fall foul of this section. The new provisions will supplement existing provisions of Part V and strengthen the protection afforded to consumers against unscrupulous trading practices.
Recall of Unsafe Products

The Act already contains provisions enabling bans to be placed on the supply of unsafe products. However, these provisions have no application to unsafe products supplied before a banning order is issued. There are at present no powers available to deal with the problem of unsafe products which have already reached the hands of consumers. The Government recognises that many industries have established voluntary procedures for the recall of unsafe products in the market-place, and it commends this responsible approach. However, to provide an adequate mechanism for remedial action across the range of potentially unsafe products, the Government considers it necessary to provide mandatory recall powers which can be used when necessary. Where no voluntary procedures exist, or the procedures are inadequate, these powers will be able to be exercised to ensure unsafe products are recalled from circulation or other remedial action is taken. Clause 35 proposes the inclusion in the Act of a new Division 1a in Part V. The new provisions, dealing with product safety and product information, represent a most important development in measures for the protection of consumers. The Division incorporates, with some amendments, the existing sections of the Act dealing with product safety and product information standards. It also includes new powers dealing with the mandatory recall of unsafe goods supplied after 1 July 1986 and notices to warn the public of goods that are under investigation.

I stress that the provisions for mandatory recall are designed to provide reserve powers which will be available for use where the safety of the public is threatened and the situation cannot be handled adequately by voluntary recall schemes or other means. In all cases, primary responsibility for ensuring the safety of consumer goods remains with manufacturers and importers. The Attorney-General will be relying on advice from his colleagues the Minister for Transport in relation to motor vehicles, and the Minister for Health in relation to pharmaceuticals, therapeutic goods and foodstuffs, who would undertake the appropriate consultative procedures within their areas of responsibility. Further, when the Government proposes to issue a mandatory recall order or banning order, there will ordinarily be an opportunity for suppliers of goods affected by the proposed order to seek a conference before the Trade Practices Commission before the order can be issued. In circumstances where there is an imminent risk of illness or serious injury the Attorney-General will be able to make an order without delay. In those cases which involve a declaration that the goods are unsafe, there will be an opportunity for a conference after the event to review the declaration. The review procedures will provide opportunity for full canvassing and testing of the issues consistent with quick action when necessary to protect the safety of the public.
Commission Action on Behalf of Consumers

Clause 55 provides for the amendment of section 87 to enable the Trade Practices Commission to obtain redress on behalf of particular named persons who have suffered loss or damage because of the conduct of a corporation or person in breach of the consumer protection provisions in Division 1 or 1a of Part V. One of the main obstacles preventing consumers from enforcing their rights under the Act is the high cost of litigation. By allowing the Commission to seek compensation on behalf of particular consumers in certain circumstances, consumers will more easily gain redress.

The amendment will be particularly useful where the Commission takes enforcement action in situations such as where a large number of consumers have each been defrauded of relatively small amounts, or where a small group of consumers have lost their savings as a result of a fraudulent representation.

This kind of proceeding will be a representative action rather than a so-called `class action'. The question of remedies for aggrieved consumers will only arise once the Commission has established a contravention of Part V in a prosecution or a proceeding for an injunction. The aggrieved consumers must be identified in the application and must have consented in writing to the Commission acting on their behalf. The Court is not empowered to make awards of damages to a class of persons, but only to particular named persons. The amount of the loss suffered by each individual by reason of the contravention will have to be established.
Other Amendments to Part V

The Bill also contains other amendments to strengthen the operation of Part V, and their enforcement under Part VI. I draw attention to amendments dealing with misleading representations about employment opportunities, to provide greater protection for unemployed people looking for work; and, with fraudulent claims for payment for unsolicited advertising, to ensure that small businesses have adequate protection against such claims. Further details of the amendments are given in the explanatory memorandum.
Financial Impact Statement

Generally speaking, this Bill will have only a minor impact on Government expenditure. This Bill does not involve additional staff or resources for the Trade Practices Commission. The only direct impact on Government expenditure concerns the administration of the reserve mandatory recall powers. This will require five staff in the Office of Consumer Affairs, to monitor industry product recall systems and advise the Attorney-General on the need to exercise the reserve powers when those systems are not adequate to arrange testing of allegedly unsafe goods, and to conduct advertising to notify the public of unsafe goods. The full year cost is estimated at $250,000. I expect that this Bill will enhance the protection offered by the Act to consumers and will promote fair business practices and competition, to the ultimate benefit of the whole community. Further, if, as expected, several of the State governments enact legislation mirroring the majority of Division 1 of Part V of the Act and repealing State legislation thereby rendered unnecessary, I expect that the costs for business and industry of complying with Government regulation in the consumer protection area will be reduced.
Conclusion

This Bill contains many important features aimed at promoting fair business practices and competition to the benefit of business interests and the broader community alike. In pursuing these objectives, the Government is demonstrating again its commitment to strong, efficient and internationally competitive Australian industry and to a fair market-place. I commend the Bill to the House, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted earlier, I was discussing certain matters relating to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has said that the Federal Government will not alter its policy prohibiting the export of Australian native birds. In a Press article he claimed that the Government would have to train staff so that it could station bird identification experts at international airports to prevent rare and endangered species which may be difficult to tell apart from common species from being taken out under cover. I disagreed with the Minister, saying that such staff should already be at airports. I questioned how much it would cost to educate someone to tell the difference between common birds, such as galahs and cockatoos, and some more exotic species.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister implied that there would be high export inspection charges. This would be nothing new as many rural Australians already languish under the high export inspection charges of this Government. The Coalition Waste Watch Committee will no doubt be looking at the Minister's Department. I am hopeful that we can reduce a lot of the wasteful expenditure there and that if the Minister insists upon imposing an export inspection charge on birds, should the policy change, the fee for that would be kept down as low as possible. When interrupted earlier I was raising the question of the morality of imposing export inspection charges. I was asking: What was wrong with a person who wants to export paying exorbitant export inspection charges? The Australian Labor Party, which has the shocking record of imposing high export inspection charges on rural producers, would have to say that there is nothing wrong with export inspection charges. On the other hand everyone on both sides of the House would have to agree that the imposition of export inspection charges on the export of non-endangered birds would be no more reprehensible than the charges already imposed. It is, therefore, difficult to see how the Minister can be serious in suggesting that the fact that a fee would be imposed on an exporter is a reason for refusing to permit the carefully regulated and humane export of non-endangered native birds.

I think that most Australians have a genuine concern about the misuse by this Government of the external affairs power. The Commonwealth enters into certain international conventions and then comes into this place and uses those conventions as a means of subverting the Constitution. We of the National Party of Australia are 100 per cent opposed to the Labor Party's undermining of the Constitution which has served this nation so well. Other members have pointed out the cruelty of the illegal export trade in Australian birds and the manner in which so many of those birds arrive at their ultimate destination dead. We believe, as the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who is the shadow Minister for Trade, pointed out, that there should be a change in the policy in this area. We believe that the Government should adopt the decision in the report I referred to earlier today, which pointed out to the people and to the Parliament that there should be a change in the policy in this area.

I shall reiterate a couple of the points made by the shadow Minister when speaking on behalf of the Opposition, because I do not want there to be any confusion and because honourable members opposite like, at every available opportunity, to misrepresent what we say. The shadow Minister said that there should be a lifting of the ban on the commercial export of non-endangered native birds. That is the first point to note. We are not talking about endangered species; we are talking about non-endangered native birds. The shadow Minister stressed that there should be carefully regulated and humane export. He was not suggesting that there should be open slather. He pointed out that the Government sponsored study had agreed that there could be the development of a potentially substantial and economically important export industry. One does not have to be an expert in economics to know that Australia needs every boost to its export industry that it can possibly obtain. A carefully regulated and humane export industry would avoid much of the cruel trapping and shipping practices which occur when these birds are smuggled overseas. Many of these birds are common birds, birds which people want to have overseas, but in this country they are in plague proportions and cause in the rural industries of Australia an inestimable amount of damage to crops and so on. If we could export a lot of these birds we would be, in fact, helping the economy and also helping rural industries. The Government seems to have a firm, hard-shelled, ideological approach to this matter. It does not seem to have resort to any reasonable argument. It is ignoring the views of this study. I hope that the Minister will look at this matter in the future.

As I mentioned earlier, we in the National Party and the Liberal Party of Australia do not oppose this Bill. I would, however, like to stress again that the Minister should consider the very many points raised by the Opposition speakers, because they are constructive, they are useful, and they should be helpful in encouraging this Government to adopt a more appropriate policy.

In conclusion, as time is short, it seems utterly crazy that people in this country are allowed to shoot and kill non-endangered species of Australian birds and yet it is illegal to export them. It would be very difficult for the Government to explain this complete lack of logic, this complete lack of humanity and this complete lack of common economic good sense to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1986, which amends the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, which was introduced by the former Government. It is to its credit that this Bill exists today. Credit is also due to the Opposition at the time, the current Government, for its support of the debate in 1982. In the debate we have had so far we have almost had a repeat of the debate of 1982 in many respects, particularly the feelings of members of the House on this matter, the only difference being that the parties have changed sides in the House. That 1982 Act consolidated previous import and export controls of flora and fauna which were formerly under the Customs Act 1901. We saw in this House recently the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill, which did the same things for other aspects of movable cultural heritage, and I would contend quite strongly that the flora and fauna we are talking about today are also very important parts of our cultural heritage. Unfortunately, too many of them have moved, and moved outside this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation extends the practicability and application of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, otherwise known by the acronym CITES. The amendments in the Bill arise as a result of looking at the progress and application of the original 1982 Act, which was put into force in 1984. Obviously, in the design of legislation there are occasions when fine tuning must occur to remedy unforeseen inadequacies or changed circumstances. As the Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) outlined in his second reading speech, the amendments can be grouped into four main categories. They are to make controls over the export and import of certain wildlife more appropriate to their status and the circumstances under which they enter trade; to simplify and improve administrative procedures which have been proven, in practice, to be unnecessarily complex or generally unnecessary; to clarify and strengthen certain enforcement provisions, which I will speak a little more about towards the end of my speech; and to increase protection for those who provide information leading to proceedings under this Act.

This Act is also being amended to allow more flexibility for private citizens who have to engage, for reasons of travel, in the bona fide importation of specimens acquired before their regulation under that Convention, especially people who have specimens which are part of their personal or household effects, gifts, in- heritances and so on. The basic intentions of the Act in general are to regulate the legitimate trade and movement in wildlife-flora and fauna-and, more importantly, I believe, to step up the fight against illegal trafficking in flora and fauna, be they Australian or exotic examples.

There is obviously a need for legitimate trade and movement, but honourable members opposite have extended that legitimate trade and movement too far beyond the spirit of reason. There is obviously a need for limited study for scientific or education purposes, and for control through Customs and wildlife officers. There is obviously a need for specimens as biological control agents. Also, this matter reflects on many areas of Australia's relations. I refer to government authorised exchanges with other countries and their zoos. I will return to that subject later if I have the time to do so. The area of greatest concern to me is illegal trafficking in flora and fauna. Honourable members will be under no illusion that this is a very serious situation. Figures are very difficult to pin down, but the illegal trade in Australia has been put at about $40m per annum. That can be easily understood if one sees the price which some of these poor suffering animals, and indeed plants, bring in other countries.

Our wildlife, of which we are very proud, is unique in the world. It is a constant source of attraction for visitors from overseas. It is an important part of our national identity. Wildlife is depicted on our coat of arms. It is a great joy to all Australians and visitors to Australia. Very importantly, it is an intrinsic part of our en- vironment and of an ecosystem that is often very finely balanced. Traffickers do not care for any of this. Hundreds of birds and other animals leave Australia illegally every week. Many of these are obviously species in abundance, but others are very seriously endangered. If a trafficker is going to take risks, the trafficker may as well make it worth his or her while. A dead rare bird or animal is, of course, of no more value than a dead common bird or animal, but a live one can be worth up to a hundred times that of a common species. It is really sad to reflect, when we see instances of this, that sometimes only one in ten animals packed away will eventually reach its destination, and from there who knows what happens to it?

I think it is worth while to look at the techniques some of these despicable people employ to make their money. We have all seen pictures of suitcases crammed full of birds and animals, usually doped with valium, in plastic pipes. It sometimes takes them a couple of days to reach their destination. There have been instances of 20 galahs being packed in a suitcase. If about 50 per cent are viable, on arrival, they will probably bring about $30,000. One single black cockatoo would be worth about $30,000 in Europe or the United States. A Major Mitchell parrot would be worth about $50,000. Obviously, our airports, harbours and so on are points of egress and ingress for this illicit trade. Other animals are stuck into nylon stockings or cotton bags. They have even been found in spare car tyres, in car door panels, stuffed in little boxes. It is really quite horrific when these poor animals are dragged out after these people are caught. Unfortunately, when these people are caught they are given pretty light sentences as far as I am concerned.

I draw the attention of the House to a couple of Press articles that have brought to the attention of the public in general showing how bird smugglers catch their prey. An article in the Age in June 1984 included an interview with a smuggler in north Queensland. The article states:

`Birds don't like lavatory paper', the fauna smuggler says, taking a sip of beer in a crowded lounge of a Cairns hotel . . . `You can get up on to the Cape (York Peninsula), find a nice valley and check out the waterholes. Then you stick a lot of twigs into the mud and lace them with lavatory paper. Always use the stuff on special in Cairns, it's cheaper than Sorbent.

`See, the birds don't know what the paper is and they won't come down for a drink. They're getting real thirsty after a day or so. But you've made a little waterhole for them so they start drinking there.'

The birds are then caught in a lobster pot. That is the way they go. They do not stop there. That is one way of catching birds. An easier way to get a bird out of the country is to take it out in an egg. An article in the West Australian of September 1984 states:
Illegal bird trappers have started to steal half-incubated eggs from nests in an effort to smuggle protected WA species to lucrative overseas markets.

The article states that there has been an instance of 29 galah eggs, three long-billed corella eggs and two from a red-tailed black cockatoo all being taken from nests in a tree. The people were caught cutting down the tree, cutting down the habitat, just to get these eggs. These people stood to make $175,000 out of those eggs when they got them to the United States, if they were able to be raised as chicks. They were fined a mere $1,200 and ordered to pay costs. That is quite sick. They would have taken them out of the country stashed in their T-shirts so that they could get them through Customs. Many of our species are threatened not only by the taking of the eggs, but by the interference in the whole breeding pattern. Some of these birds do not breed every year or a couple of times a year. They might breed every two or three years. So we can see the impact that that would obviously have.

Smugglers do not stop at birds. They go in for snakes as well. Customs officers have seized Australian reptiles concealed in cotton bags and in a whole manner of things. If I were a Customs officer, I certainly would not want to put my hand into someone's suitcase, thinking it contained a pair of trousers, to find that it happened to contain a venomous snake. Birds and snakes are not the only animals that come easily to mind. There are other animals as well, such as butterflies, fish, sea creatures, in some instances live coral, and, of course, our indigenous plants.

There is often disagreement in this House on matters concerning the environment, but it is important to realise that such animals and plants are not purchased from the supermarket shelf. They are an intrinsic part of our environment. They are part of our ecosystem. Australia's ecosystem has a very fine balance, as we all know. People who come from the outback and from areas that are very dependent upon a fine balance of human beings, animals, the weather and so on will recognise that this fine balance is very easily disturbed. This occurs in the micro-ecosystems as well as the macro-ecosystem of Australia.

I appreciate some of the points that were made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) on this side of the House and by many speakers on the other side regarding the export of animals, how that should be enhanced and how effective it would be in changing our balance of trade and so on. But what do they really hope to achieve as far as the animals are concerned? These are not sheep and cattle that are bred for domestic purposes. These are basically wild animals. What will we do with them? Will we stick them in cages in someone's living room in Brussels or Los Angeles? What is the whole idea of it? What are we really trying to achieve by the export of wild animals. These are not dogs or cats; these are wild animals and are part of Australia and its ecosystem. That environment-and those animals in that environment-are vital to the balance that we try to maintain. Obviously, there are distortions from time to time, but I do not think the simple fact of exporting animals will solve that problem. That is a rather simplistic approach and I hope that the Opposition does not persist with that rather simplistic line of solving that problem.

We talk about the habitats of these animals. There is no use in the Opposition coming in here and making fine noises and decrying the situation where many of the animals suffer great trauma and often death in the illegal trafficking, if the Opposition continually refuses to support the original environments from which those plants and animals come. We have seen that attitude in issues such as woodchipping, the Daintree and other rainforests and developments such as uranium mining. We have to recognise also the role of the Aboriginal people. Their knowledge of the environment and the ecosystem generally is almost a genetic understanding, compared with ours. They have been here for countless thousands of years. We talk in terms of decades and a couple of hundred years. The Aborigines have lived with this land and the animals for so long and we should respect and try to learn from what those people have to offer in terms of management of this land.

Another animal that is in the news from time to time, quite sadly, is the crocodiles. The simple solution for many people is to go out and blast away and kill them all and do whatever they like with the skins, but certainly eradicate them because they have killed animals and, on notable and recent sad occasions, they have attacked human beings. We have to realise that, as sad as that situation may seem, basically it is the crocodiles' environment and we need to be aware of that environment when we go there. The needless slaughter of those animals, whether it be for revenge or other forms of control, is a dangerous interruption of the food chain. We have to be more aware of the delicate balance, especially in those areas, and the role of crocodiles.

As far as koalas are concerned, I am prepared to support limited well researched interchanges between governments, whether it be gifts to zoos or whatever. Koalas are very sensitive animals. This Government and previous governments have worked with State bodies as well as within their own Federal departments to learn more about koalas. People can learn more about those animals and the better control of their conditions by taking part in such exchanges. I urge the Government, while we are talking about koalas, if it is concerned about wildlife in general, as I believe it is, to consider the effect that the disease caused by chlamydia psittaci is having upon the koala population. I call upon the Government and the Opposition to make research into this disease, which is seriously affecting our koala population, a priority in animal welfare and animal research in the next Budget.

In the few minutes remaining I pay special tribute to the many conservation groups that exist in the community. While it is fine for us to stand here and talk about what is happening-about people bringing wildlife in and taking it out of Australia-the fact is that without the conservation groups which are active in the community there would be much less available. Some people may agree with the conservation groups and some may not, but they perform a very important role in our community. I refer to the Tasmanian Wilderness Society, Australians for Animals, Friends of the Earth and the many small local groups which exist in our communities, towns and regions. I pay particular attention to those people in the Friends of the Earth and the Wilderness Coalition in Diamond Valley, Heidelberg and Eltham in my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I know that my friend, the honourable member for McEwen, supports that as well. The other day I was at the Heidelberg Festival. A variety of groups were there, including the Scouts and others. I went into a tent of one of the groups-the Warringal Conservation Society. That Society has listed all the special local flora and fauna in that area. The flora and fauna may not be the most startling examples of Australian wildlife that one has ever seen, but they are important and it is important that we know exactly what is around us. It is easy to go around chopping down trees without knowing what value that tree has as a species and what habitat that tree provides for various animals in the area. The Warringal Conservation Society has done a tremendous job in bringing to the attention of the people of Heidelberg and surrounding areas the need for protection of the environment, for public education, for the creation of a register of assets and for a watch-dog on errant people who cut down trees with chainsaws or councils which bulldoze and knock down trees. There is a need for the protection of our environment and the species.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to this Bill will lead to far less destruction of our wildlife and better controls in legitimate exports. The increased penalties mentioned are not sufficient when one considers the money people make out of illegal trafficking. A penalty of $5,000 is meaningless to those people who are earning big money, hundreds of thousands or millions of dollars. The trafficking is linked to organised crime and it should be treated in that way. The amendments clarify the powers of inspectors, and I support that proposal. I support the Minister and the shadow Minister and people on both sides of the House in supporting the general principles of this Bill, regardless of some of the more extreme suggestions that have been put forward. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Privilege, as recognised by parliaments following the Westminster traditions, traces its history to the reign of William and Mary, beginning in 1396. Notwithstanding the general recognition of the privilege of the Parliament, the Crown and the House of Commons were not always agreed upon its limits. Against violation of the privilege under forms of law, the Commons evolved a safeguard which was given final expression in the Bill of Rights. This consisted of claiming superiority for the lex parliamenti over the common law and, for the high court of Parliament, independence of the courts in Westminster Hall. This recognition by law of the privilege of the freedom of speech received final statutory confirmation after the revolution of 1688-the so-called glorious revolution. This period of English history is seen as the time the Parliament exerted its authority over the Crown and the common law, and the Bill of Rights was the statutory vehicle which enshrined the sovereignty and independence of Parliament. By the ninth article of the Bill of Rights it was declared that the freedom of speech and debates or proceedings in Parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court or place out of the Parliament. Yet it should not be forgotten that the Bill of Rights and the privileges which flowed from it were not at the time seen to create rights as they are known today. The history of the mother of parliaments up to 1688 was one of conflict between the rights of the people to exert their authority, through the Parliament, over the Crown and the courts. Today, however, the rights attached to the notion of privilege are such that members of parliament, within these four walls, can escape the normal limitations of speech imposed on other Australians. The expression `cowards castle' is an apt description of the misuse of the privilege often seen in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to direct my attention to the double standards of the Opposition. The Bill of Rights of 1688 was established to create rights for the Parliament against the failure of the common law both to create and enforce those rights. The Bill we are debating today-the Parliament (Powers, Privileges and Immunities) Bill-is in the same tradition. This Parliament is debating a parliamentary Bill of Rights introduced by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and the Opposition. The Bill creates rights not just for the Parliament as a whole but for the individuals who collectively make up the Parliament. It asserts the supremacy of the Parliament over the common law. It creates the rights that individual Australians do not have. Unlike the Australian Bill of Rights introduced by the Government, this Bill is not a shield but a sword, and a very sharp sword. So the double standards become apparent. Whilst the rest of Australia is told by the Opposition to find their rights in the common law, if they can find such rights, members of the Opposition come into this House supporting privilege-their privilege. If the common law gives all the rights, all the protection, that the honourable member for North Sydney says it does-I refer honourable members to his speech on the Bill of Rights as reported in Hansard-this Bill is unnecessary. What strange logic members of the Opposition have.

Let me make it clear at this point that I am not opposed to the notion of privilege as it applies to this place. I wonder, however, at the abuses it protects. It is common knowledge that the ordinary Australian is often ashamed of the behaviour of members of this place and the unbridled personal attacks that so often mar proceedings. For many years I was a councillor of the Shire of Diamond Valley. Councillors do not have privilege or protection in regard to the normal things they discuss in council chambers. They are subject to the same laws as every other Australian. They have no protection from action for defamation; no shield. One could argue that councillors should not be allowed the right to go within the four walls of their council chamber and use the privilege of that place to abuse the rights that flow from it. In all of my years as a councillor I did not find that I needed the protection of privilege. I found that I could operate effectively as a councillor without that shield. However, I am the first to concede that there is a big difference between our role in this place and the role of a municipal councillor.

The point I make is that the privilege enjoyed is accepted by members as a right and not as a privilege. It can be abused in many ways. Media reports of the Parliament are also able to rely on the privilege of the House. A member may, on information supplied by the media, raise in this House matters otherwise not reportable, thereby circumnavigating an otherwise actionable report. One can question whether this should be allowed and whether a matter raised under privilege in this House should not be actionable outside its precincts. If ever there was an example of how the Parliament can be used as a star chamber, the use of illegally obtained tapes, now commonly known as the Age tapes, stands on its own. The shameful use of the privilege of this House and the unsubstantiated allegations made against decent and defenceless Australians are by themselves sufficient reason to call into question the limit which should be placed on this right now being debated.

In many areas this House takes upon itself certain rights and privileges and we rely on those rights and privileges based on section 49 of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights of 1688. But we never question in any serious way what sorts of proceedings we ourselves should use to stop members from abusing those rights. The Bill we are now looking at on any reasonable examination simply suggests that the only enforcement proceedings against abuse of that privilege are proceedings of the House itself. So we have the situation, as we have seen so recently in the past, in which a member can raise in this place totally unsubstantiated material, no doubt supplied by a media group, and use the privilege of the House to get that recorded so the media can then use it and not be subject to defamation laws or other attacks. Yet there are no investigatory procedures. There is no means by which an aggrieved person outside of this place can seek redress. I find that a very strange and sad situation. If there is one defect in this Bill, it is in that area. There should be some way in this Bill, some way within the procedures for the use of privilege, for people who feel offended by what they see as a misuse of that privilege to go outside this House and seek that redress. Let us face it, what is the use of coming to the House itself when whichever party is in government is in control of the numbers and can use those numbers to deny the person that right? I do not think that the history of this place over the years is such that individual rights have been protected by the political system. That is my principal concern. I believe that the rights of the individual outside this place are not protected by this Bill.

I should congratulate the members of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege who prepared the report printed on 3 October 1984. There is probably no better collection of information about the history of privilege as it applies to this country and its potential role in the future. It is another great example of how our founding fathers back in the pre-1901 days thought that they could by the use of section 49 provide for privilege and simply say that, whatever the House of Commons was doing as at 1901, we would adopt it automatically and from that day on that would be the rule for privilege in this House. I find that a bit tragic. It would have been far better had we had a Bill of Rights as provided for in the American Constitution and if the role of privilege had been part of our overall Constitution. I would like to think that this Bill and the Australian Bill of Rights could be considered in this context as complementary legislation.

While not agreeing entirely with the Bill of the honourable member for North Sydney, I compliment him on his effort. At least he is raising the matter by presenting the Bill. I certainly agree with most of it. I would like to see it go back to a joint committee so that some of the matters which I discussed and which worry me personally could be looked at further. On the whole, I recommend the overall thrust of the Bill and look forward to further discussions on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Parliament (Powers, Privileges and Immunities) Bill, I am drawing on my many years of experience as a Federal and State parliamentarian. I do so with deep concern for the maintenance of Parliament's privileges and paramountcy and to strike a balance between the past and the present. Much has changed since Parliament's powers, privileges and immunities were established over 200 years ago in circumstances, of course, quite different from the present. We should make changes, not for the sake of change but to mirror, in our practices and our law, the needs of today's Parliament in a way that seems to us, and to the Australian people, to take account of the great changes in parliamentary and national life and to strike a wise and just balance between the claims of Parliament and the overriding consideration of Parliament's supremacy with other claims.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us for a moment, as parliamentarians, reflect on the vast changes that have taken place since our privileges were established and, indeed, since Federation. Let us also reflect on the increasing scrutiny which the institution of parliament and we, as parliamentarians, are under. I stress again that I would never advocate or support reform for its own sake. However, in my view the case for reform is compelling. The reality is that if we are to change and improve our system, this Bill could very well be the only opportunity that many of us will have to do something during our parliamentary lifetimes. Such has been the record of attempts at reform of Parliament's privileges that the last attempt was made as long ago as the 1930s.

I should now like to take up the three main items in the Bill: The abolition of defamatory contempts; the abolition of the power of the Houses to expel members; and the limited, and extremely mild, form of review capacity to be given to the High Court of Australia. Honour- able members will recall that it was the Oakes case that sparked the formation of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege on whose report the Bill of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) is based. This matter was taken up the the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) and ultimately formed the subject of report by the Committee.

I venture to suggest to members of the House that the time is well overdue for us to abandon a privilege which, in effect, allows us-should we wish-to place fetters on criticisms of this House, its members, or its committees. As an institution, and as members, we are in my view uniquely well placed to deal with ill-founded or malicious attacks. No one would really suggest that there should be a muzzle on freedom to criticise members or the House. Nor would anyone really suggest that these days we would ever consider imposing penalties on any journalist or media outlet that did so, regardless of how intemperate the language employed.

To those who would suggest that it is possible that we could be placed under an attack of such force and organisation that it would undermine the institution of Parliament itself, I give two simple replies. First, let us concern ourselves with realities, not with fantasies. Secondly, if such an extraordinary unlikely set of circumstances arose, we retain the power, under the Constitution, to reinvest ourselves with whatever privileges we think necessary. Speaking from my own experience, and my knowledge of our parliamentary history, I would be content to rest my argument on the lack of need for this so-called protection, and its being completely out of keeping with the needs of Parliament. I point out that this privilege does not exist in the United States Congress and never has.

Turning to the power of the Houses to expel, members will recall that this power has been exercised once only, and on that occasion by the House of Representatives. The year was 1920 and the member expelled was Mr Mahon. The Joint Select Committee was clearly of the view that Mr Mahon should not have been expelled. A very troubling feature of the Mahon case-aside from the peremptory way in which he was dealt with by the House-is that the motion to expel was carried on party lines. Honourable members will recall that the privileges which were established in the House of Commons, were established under a system bereft of a written constitution. Our position is quite different, and we have by our Constitution specifically provided for the disqualification of members.

Recalling that it is fundamentally for the people to determine who would represent them in Parliament, that our Constitution has laid down specific rules for disqualification, that the Mahon case itself is the sole and a very troubling precedent, that one can never exclude the arbitrary and party use of the power to expel, that the full penal powers will remain in the House to discipline any member who requires discipline, it is my view that we should dispense with this power.

Last, I turn to the limited form of review which is to be vested in the High Court. The first point to be made is that this right of review is to apply only when the decision of the House is to imprison someone for an offence against it. The effect of the Bill is that the particulars of the facts as found by the House, by virtue of which the House has found a person guilty and for which that person is to be imprisoned, should be stated in the resolution imposing punishment or imprisonment. Of course, the House cannot in fact be compelled to state these particulars but surely it should do so, as it would be quite wrong to imprison without knowing the precise basis upon which imprisonment was being imposed.

Where imprisonment is to be imposed it would be open to the High Court to hear an application on the part of the imprisoned person and to declare that no breach of privilege in the strict sense is established by these particulars, such as an infringement of a member's right to freedom of speech and that a recognised category of contempt-that is one established by the practice of the House or of the Commons-has been made out. The Court could do no more than that and it would then be open to the House, where any declaration is made, to make its own decision as to what it should do. Effectively, this right would be a substitute for the writ of habeus corpus which is, to all intents and purposes, a dead letter when the House makes an order for commitment because the practice is to make the order in general terms and the courts have long decided that they will not look at the facts on which the order is based.

I support this extremely limited power of review. In the end, the decision remains one for the House and the will of the House is paramount. Hence, the supremacy of the House is maintained while at the same time the citizen is given a right of review. This provision in the Bill would not have my support if it did not preserve the supremacy of the Parliament. Frankly, I think it is unlikely that we are ever going to face again the necessity of imprisonment in the vindication of our privileges. Honourable members will recall that there is only one instance when this course was adopted-the Browne and Fitzpatrick affair.

All of the matters in the Bill are matters for individual members to consider. Some will support parts of the Bill and oppose other parts. Importantly, these matters are now being considered by Parliament. The members of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege are to be commended for the detail and time-consuming work undertaken, in particular, the honourable member for North Sydney for giving the House the opportunity, by way of a private member's Bill, to consider the question of reform the first time in approximately 50 years.
