TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March 1986 Australia abolished any jurisdiction by the United Kingdom Parliament over our laws. It also abolished appeals to the Privy Council. This was in legislation agreed to by all the States and the Commonwealth and approved by the Queen of Australia in person. When the Queen signed the proclamation for the Australia Act in 1986, she observed that this ended outmoded links and reflected Australia's status as an independent and sovereign nation. With the passage of the Parliament (Powers, Privileges and Immunities) Bill, I hope in the same month, we will establish for the first time the privileges of the Commonwealth Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 49 of the Commonwealth Constitution provides:

the powers, privileges and immunities of the Senate and the House of Representatives, and of the members and the committees of each House, shall be such as are declared by the Parliament, and until declared shall be those of the Commons House of Parliament of the United Kingdom, and of its members and committee, at the establishment of the Commonwealth.

Eighty-five years, two months and 18 days later, the powers and privileges of the Parliament have still not been declared by the Parliament. We are still bound by the privileges of the House of Commons as on 1 January 1901, the first day of the twentieth century, just three weeks before Queen Victoria died. In privileges the House of Commons has moved and is no longer bound by the precedents of 1901, but we are still frozen in the Victorian era. Our failure to act under section 49 has been in sharp contrast to section 48 of the Constitution, which provided that salaries for members should be set at #400 per year `until the Parliament otherwise provides'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are just reducing them.
—Yes, the Parliament has provided otherwise repeatedly. It is true that section 49 of the Constitution has been modified somewhat by Standing Order 1 of the House of Representatives, which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: In all cases not provided for hereinafter, or by sessional or other orders or practice of the House, resort shall be had to the practice of the Commons House of the Parliament of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in force for the time being, which shall be followed as far as it can be applied.

I had the experience of serving on the Standing Committee of Privileges and then later serving on the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege which was set up in the Thirty-first Parliament. When the Committee was set up and the Liberal Government was still in office, the honourable member for North Sydney, Mr John Spender, QC, became the chairman and Senator G. J. Evans was the Deputy Chairman.

After the change of government in 1983, when the considerations of the Joint Select Committee were not yet completed, it continued its work with two changes in personnel and the final report came down in October 1984. There was just an outside chance that in those last frenzied moments of that Parliament it might have been considered so that when the new Parliament took its seat in early 1985 the Parliament would have declared itself. So far it has not happened. We now have the opportunity to discuss it. I hope that the report will be adopted.

Much of the pressure for declaring this came because of concern about the Oakes case. When the Standing Committee of Privileges reported on a complaint made in the House of Representatives on 8 September 1981 about a printed reference in an article by Laurie Oakes, this was examined exhaustively. There was a general feeling on the Committee that the existing law of privilege was not adequate, that it broke down. A number of criticisms of the existing method of dealing with privileged reports were put in a dissenting report by the Hon. M. J. Duffy and myself which was printed in the proceedings.

Several attempts were made to try to bring the law of privilege up to date. In 1908 a joint select committee on procedure in cases of privilege met under the chairmanship of Sir John Quick, who was a member of the House of Representatives for Bendigo, a distinguished constitutional lawyer and co-author of the famous text on the Commonwealth Constitution, Quick and Garran. The Quick Committee made fundamental criticisms of the law of privilege and recommended that, instead of members of the Parliament being judge in their own cause, complaints should be transferred to the High Court of Australia. No action was taken on this request until a draft Bill called the Offences Against the Parliament Bill was prepared in 1934 by the then Attorney-General, J. G. Latham, who was soon after translated to the High Court. However, no action was taken on the Quick report or the Latham Bill. Although there had been a number of criticisms of the existing law of privilege, it has taken a long time before we have got to this stage.

Historically, the law of parliamentary privilege was aimed at protecting the institution of Parliament and its members from practices which prevented members of parliament from carrying out their duties without fear or favour, or which provided inducement of some kind which encouraged members to act in some particular way, or discouraged them from acting at all. Thus, the law of privilege covered intimidation, solicitation, molestation and bribery and, of course, conferred freedom from suit for actions performed and words spoken in the Parliament.

The law of privilege, certainly as it was in Britain on 1 January 1901, has been static for nearly three centuries while the world of politics has changed dramatically. In 1704, May reports in the nineteenth edition of Parliamentary Practice page 72, the Lords communicated this resolution to the Commons at a conference:
That neither House of Parliament hath any power, by any vote, or declaration, to create to themselves any new privilege, that is not warranted by the known laws and custom of Parliament;
That was assented to by the Commons. May comments:
It is agreed that by itself neither House can create a new privilege.

Prima facie, it would be a strange way to protect the Parliament to say that no new element in politics, administration and the media which has arisen since 1704 can be raised as a breach of privilege. The vexed question of the relationship between Parliament and the public service is a far more fundamental issue than the action of journalists who figuratively thumb their noses at Parliamentarians.

This came out in the Berthelsen case, probably the most important case of privilege dealt with for many years in this Parliament, but a case which was not given, I think, the degree of consideration in the House for its serious implication. If privilege is to survive, it has to be re-examined, renovated and its administration must always be subject to the application of natural justice, open procedures and the right to defence by counsel. In the dissenting report that the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) and I wrote we, at that stage, took the view that privilege ought to be referred to a competent court and that, because of the special problems involved where parliamentarians were protecting their own interests, it ought not to be dealt with by them. This was one area on which I gave way as a member of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege. My overwhelming concern was that the Parliament should declare where it stood on the matter of privilege. We should bring the Constitution up to date, to look at contemporary practice and be bound not by what the members of the House of Commons felt in the late Victorian era but by what we in the last quarter of the twentieth century felt about our privileges in own country.

I was anxious that there ought to be a unanimous report from the members of the Committee. This was one point on which I was prepared to give way. I gave way on this basis: It was better to have an Act before the Parliament to have it enacted and to have both Houses of the Parliament declare their privileges. Then, if in two or five years time it needed to be amended, it could be. The important thing was to break the ice. The worst thing that could happen would be if this legislation were not enacted. The second worst thing would be if it were to be enacted and it remained frozen in the ice for another 85 years, two months and 18 days without ever being revised.

It is appropriate, perhaps, that I should express my satisfaction with the work done by the Committee. In particular, I praise its Chairman, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) as well as the other members of the Committee. The Committee comprised: Mr J. M. Spender, QC, MP and Senator the Honourable G. J. Evans QC-Chairman and Deputy Chairman-the Honourable A. E. Adermann, MP; Senator George Georges; Mr Alan Griffiths, MP; the Honourable Clyde Holding, MP; and Senator D. S. Jessop, the Honourable Barry Jones, Senator M. J. Macklin and Senator Peter Rae, as he was then. He is now the Honourable Peter Rae. I also thank the Secretary Mr Bernard Wright for the work that he put into the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that in the Thirty-second Parliament?

—No, that was in the Thirty-third Parliament. That was the group which prepared the report actually tabled. There were one or two changes in the Thirty-second Parliament. Senator Kilgariff and Mr J. R. Porter were in the Committee during the previous Parliament. Essentially, the cast was the same.
—The quality remained.

—Absolutely. The major objection to the present law of privilege cases relates firstly to the secrecy of the transaction and the denial of representation by counsel. As I say, the third objection that I used to have-that is that the Parliament act as a judge in its own cause-is something that I forgo the luxury of criticising because I am satisfied with the report that we have in front of us. It was unanimously agreed to by the members of the House of Representatives involved, but with some dissent from Senators Jessop and Peter Rae. Nevertheless, they had some queries relating to eight of the total number of recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: In practice the Committee on Privilege operated as a secret committee. In my experience, explicit warnings were given by the Chairman both to witnesses and to Committee members that they were not to divulge any details of evidence or of procedures adopted or resolutions that were debated to any other person. There was no standing order declaring the Committee on Parliamentary Privilege to be a secret committee, but it seemed to be a matter of practice of long standing for all Committees of Privilege to hear witnesses in secret. It may be assumed that historically this was the practice in the House of Commons.

As a matter of practice persons accused of breaches of privilege were not entitled to put an argument as to why they should be represented by counsel, although in the 1955 Bankstown Observer case-the case of Fitzpatrick and Browne-and the Laurie Oakes case counsel were entitled to put an argument as to why they should be entitled to act in the proceedings. In both cases the Committees concluded that the operation of section 49 of the Constitution and Standing Order 1 of the House of Representatives precluded legal representation. However, it is worth noting that in the House of Commons counsel have not been permitted to appear before the House of Commons Committee of Privileges to defend persons accused of breaches of privilege during the hearing of evidence since the 1770s.

I said that historically three elements-that is the holding of hearings in secret, including the cross-examination of witnesses; people being summonsed and being denied the right to be assisted by counsel; and, members of parliament taking roles as prosecutors and judges-between them constituted a denial of natural justice. I believe that parliamentary privilege is and ought to remain a powerful weapon. I agree with the words of the 1967 House of Commons Select Committee report that the power to punish be exercised as sparingly as possible and only `to provide reasonable protection . . . from such improper obstruction . . . as is causing, or is likely to cause, substantial interference with the performance of their respective functions by the House, its Members or its Officers'.

Over-use of the powers of privilege would lead to undesirable results. If the Parliament acts arbitrarily and in secret and overrides natural justice, the whole justification of parliamentary privilege will be overturned. Similarly, if no new development in society since 1704, such as the invention of television or the rise of the over mighty public servant within the bureaucracy, can be raised as a matter of privilege, parliamentary privilege will be reduced to the status of a mere exhibit in a museum of parliamentary practice.
I apologise that I missed the earlier debate, owing to my preoccupations in another place.
I note that the most important parts of the Committee's report deal with the question of penalties and procedures. I applaud in particular the recommendation on page 6. The report states:

(a) The hearings of the Privileges Committee shall be in public, subject to a discretion in the Committee to conduct hearings in camera when it considers that the circumstances are such as to warrant this course;

(b) The whole of the transcript of evidence shall be published, and shall be presented to its House by the Committee when it makes its Report, subject however to a discretion to exclude evidence which has been heard in camera and to prevent the publication of such evidence by any other means;

(c) Issues before the Committee should be adequately defined so that person or organisation against whom a complaint has been made is reasonably apprised of the nature of the complaint he has to meet;

(e) A person against whom a complaint is made, and an organisation through its representative, should have the right to be present throughout the whole of the proceedings, save for deliberative proceedings and save where in the opinion of the Committee he or she should be excluded from the hearing of proceedings in camera . . .

One of the penalties that will be abolished is expulsion from the House. That penalty has been invoked only once in the history of the Commonwealth Parliament in the entirely deplorable case of Hugh Mahon back in 1920. That case, perhaps the nadir of the parliamentary system in Australia, was never referred to a committee of privilege. In the absence of the honourable member, because he had broken his leg and was not in the House on the day, his expulsion was moved without any prior warning by the then Prime Minister, Mr W. M. Hughes, and despite protests from some members of the Opposition it was despatched forthwith and Mahon was eliminated from the House.

We believed that the power of expulsion should be abolished. First of all, we thought that realistically it was very unlikely that it would ever be invoked. We might privately think some of our fellow parliamentarians are pretty dodgy, but it is very difficult to conceive of a situation where any party would chose to use its numbers. It is very difficult to think of any circumstances under which a committee of privilege would be disposed to use its numbers. There would be great public revulsion. If a member were convicted of a major offence, of course, under the provisions of Section 44 of the Constitution, that person would lose his or her right to sit. However, the capacity to impose a fine was introduced. That is a novelty, but it was thought to be important because in many cases the malefactor in an offence would not be some wretched journalist who was hauled before the Bar of the House, but some malefactor of great wealth and power and it seemed to us appropriate that a fine should be imposed with a penalty of imprisonment in default thereof.

The final point, which is particularly important, is the abolition of the offence of defamatory contempt. In other words, to say that members of Parliament generally are a whole pack of bludgers seems to us to be just in the category of vulgar abuse and not worth the resources of the Parliament to proceed with such an offence. However, if individuals are identified and subjected to unreasonable pressure, that is when the power of privilege needs to be invoked, and invoked strongly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege which was charged with investigating matters associated with parliamentary privilege and reporting to Parliament, I strongly support the general philosophy of the Parliament (Powers, Privileges and Immunities) Bill presented by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I commend the work of that Committee and the chairmanship of the honourable member for North Sydney. When I first sat on that Committee, I was somewhat apprehensive, as the Leader of the House (Mr Young) may well understand, because I saw around me so many eminent men of the law. However, I found it a very good Committee and one which gave very special attention to the matters with which it was charged.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been pointed out by the honourable member for North Sydney, the Committee's recommendations fall into three groups: First, those requiring implementation by statute; secondly, those requiring amendment of the Standing Orders; and, thirdly, those requiring resolutions by both Houses of Parliament. This Bill deals specifically with those requiring implementation by statute. However, in many ways, unless attention is given to the amendment of the Standing Orders, this legislation will advance us but partially along the track. It would be unfortunate if the Parliament did not consider the totality of the recommendations if we are concerned about the definition and scope of parliamentary privilege. If we are to go along the path of statute legislation without any resolve to consider our Standing Orders, I can foresee a committee being set up to cover the same range of inquiry as this Committee has covered, bringing in much the same type of recommendations. If we are to define the rules of parliamentary privilege governing our Parliament, as distinct from the practice of relying on the precedent of the House of Commons, let us attend to the matter in some sort of totality rather than just fiddle around the edges and go a little way. While supporting the thrust of the Bill and endorsing what the honourable member for North Sydney has said-that this Bill has been brought in for debate and consideration and perhaps for amendment-I believe that this Bill alone, even if it were passed as presently presented or as amended, would not complete the task unless we attended to the other recommendations of the Committee.

The important aspect of the Bill which should be understood is that it does not erode the rights of members of the Parliament. That very necessary situation which guarantees privileges and immunities is not disturbed. If those privileges and immunities are circumscribed or reduced, they are destroyed and that would be a tragedy for our parliamentary system and our democratic processes. This Bill does not set out to disturb that situation. If it did, we would not be supporting it.

The Bill confers a very limited and highly circumscribed power on the full High Court of Australia to express an opinion that a resolution of the House to commit an offender to prison is in some way deficient. The Parliament can accept or reject that advice. Indeed, in our discussions in the Committee, there was a lot of debate on whether decisions of the Parliament to punish offences against the House should be referable to a court, particularly as to the appropriate penalty. My view from the outset-and, happily, it was the view also of the Committee-was that that proposition was untenable, that Parliament must be the controller of its own operations. Parliament must have the capacity to adjudicate and to accept the responsibility and even the odium, if necessary, for its decisions. If a judge decides in a court that a person is guilty of contempt of court, he passes the sentence that he deems appropriate on the offender. He does not ask Parliament to consider the appropriate sentence, nor does he refer it to some other court. He does this because he knows the circumstances of the particular action being tried, the influence the contempt could have upon the case and the degree of seriousness which applies to that contempt. Why then should the Parliament ask a court to determine the penalty for what it judges to be contempt when the Parliament is the institution which is best equipped to judge the seriousness of the contempt upon its own operations and its own integrity?

I have no fundamental objection to the limited power which this Bill would ascribe to the High Court. However, I would-and I believe the Committee would-have opposed any move to grant to the courts any greater power than that. We discussed at length the rights of the accused to be heard in their defence and we felt it would be preferable for that defence to be made before the Parliament than in some court remote from the circumstances and the situation.

The Bill also provides that the Parliament should not have the power to expel a member for contempt. As we have heard, on the only occasion when the Australian Parliament used that power, it was very debatable that that was the correct action for the Parliament to take. In the history of the Australian Parliament since that time-indeed, since I have been in the Parliament-there have been many statements and interjections which, by the same yardstick, could equally have been adjudged treasonable or seditious. This is a power which has the potential for being used capriciously, vindictively and politically. A member is here because the Australian people in his electorate have elected him. They have the power at election to endorse or dismiss him. If Parliament takes upon itself the right to expel a member, unless under the provisions of the Constitution he becomes disqualified, a cardinal plank in the democratic edifice is, I believe, removed.

The Parliament itself has the power to suspend a member and I have thought seriously about this power. I believe-and I speak for myself, because members on this side of the House may not necessarily agree with me-that that power should only be used by the Speaker or the Chairman of Committees. I say that because they are the two officers who are elected by this House to those positions. I believe, too, that there should be a procedure of warnings set down very clearly and the member should be made aware that he or she is incurring the wrath or the ire of the Chair. I have never been very much attracted to the situation in which the Leader of the House or someone else has to move a motion. I have never been attracted to the situation in which the Speaker, having named a member, requires a vote to be taken. I say that without any inference against the occupants of the chair. I have always felt very much for those who occupy the chair in this House. We had an incident-and I pass no comment on it-where a member was named in this House and yet the House did not vote for the suspension of that member.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has happened twice.

—Yes. I am not making a political point of that but it has always seemed rather strange to me that a Speaker or Deputy Speaker, who is elected to that position, can name a member and say that the member should be suspended, but the matter then goes to a vote. In the political atmosphere, a vote is taken and that seems to be rather strange. I believe that once we have elected the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, those persons should have the authority on their own, without requiring the motion, to make such a suspension, provided they give the necessary warnings. The Parliament has a redress if it is not happy with the action or the attitude of a Speaker. It can move a vote of no confidence against the Speaker. While the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker enjoy the confidence of the House, our present procedure seems unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring that aspect of it into the debate only because I believe that, when we are looking at the Standing Orders, matters such as this ought to be looked at. I believe too that the House has a right to expect the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker not to wait until somebody objects to a statement-for instance, when there is an inference of mental incompetence or something like that, or some insulting remark is made against a member-before asking for a withdrawal. That is a matter for Standing Orders, but I do endorse very much the thrust of this Bill which takes away from the House of right to expel a member-something that this House ought never to do. The Bill legally supports protection to members, officers of the Houses, and witnesses before committees against liability for defamation. That is both sensible and necessary if committees are to be effective. I think that requires little further amplification beyond the comments of the honourable member for North Sydney. The Bill also provides, and I think very necessarily provides, under item 7 of the explanatory notes for the creation of the offence of interfering with a witness by reason of the fact that he or she is about to appear before or has appeared before or has given particular evidence before a House or parliamentary committee. I think it is very necessary that that offence be established, otherwise the work of our committees and the course of inquiry that they are required to take could be very much jeopardised.

A sensible amendment limits the duration of immunity from arrest on civil process and compulsory attendance as a witness to five days before and after the sitting of the House or committee. As the honourable member for North Sydney points out, that 40-day immunity may have been appropriate when travel was exceedingly slow and arduous, but it is not appropriate today. The immunity is necessary if a member is to attend to his responsibilities in attending the Parliament or a committee. It is also useful against any capricious attempt to prevent his attendance by some frivolous suit. But that can be ensured within this Bill without frustrating his availability where his testimony as a witness might be of some import.

Other than the right to expel and to imprison, the existing powers of the Parliament are indeed limited. Both powers are extreme and are not always appropriate. This Bill, for the first time, introduces the capacity to levy a fine. I am not sure whether the suggested quantum of fines is the most appropriate. Certainly the necessity for this lesser sanction is evident and it commands support. The other major change envisaged by the Bill and upon which constructive debate could ensue is the abolition as a head of contempt of the offence known as libels on parliament or defamatory contempts. I believe the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), who spoke just before me, covered that very adequately. The Bill maintains the power to deal with such situations as intimidation coupled with defamatory comment and does not interfere with the existing right of a member to sue for defamation at law. On balance, I favour that change, but I believe that if this course is adopted it will be all the more necessary to ensure that the Standing Orders are reviewed so that the quality and standards of parliamentary behaviour are enhanced.

I commend the honourable member for North Sydney and those who were on that Committee. It was a very difficult subject and problem that was handed to it. I believe that this Committee, as have many committees I have served on, has shown a remarkable degree of bipartisanship. I commend the honourable member for his dedication to the examination and handing of the charter to which we were given, I commend his handling of the inquiry and I commend the great amount of research and input that he contributed. I also commend the Bill that he has brought forward and his attitude that it should be brought forward in the spirit that it should be considered, debated and perhaps amended if we can arrive at a better Bill. He said that it could be amended without causing any affront to him. What he has done is to ensure that the Parliament carefully and soberly considers the important matter of privilege. For that I think he deserves the thanks of this Parliament. The consideration he has asked for should continue and not cease or be shelved with any decision on this Bill.

Let me again state that this Bill is intended to redress only those aspects which require amendment by statute. That is but part of our considerations and I believe that, through discussion in both Houses and through the Standing Orders Committee, there is very much more to consider. From this Bill we can and should progress to this wide and comprehensive consideration of parliamentary privilege and the appropriateness of our practices, procedures and rules pertaining to this question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is for me a rather unusual contribution to parliamentary debates because it is not a matter that I have given a great deal of thought to in recent times. However, the opportunity to speak has presented itself and, being a relatively new member of the Parliament, I would like to make a number of comments with respect to the Parliament (Powers, Privileges and Immunities) Bill as proposed by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender).

SPEECH.PARA: The first comment I make concerns what I see as the nature of parliamentary privilege and parliamentary contempt. It seems to me that parliamentary privilege is all about power, and of course no section of the community readily gives up power that it has exercised for any period. It is perhaps not to be unexpected that members of Parliament have been equally reluctant to give up the powers that they have possessed through the law of contempt of Parliament and parliamentary privilege. Indeed, as the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) indicated, after some 85 years we are still stuck with the rather moribund and totally inadequate powers that we had conferred on us as a new nation by section 49 of the Australian Constitution. Soon after I came into the Parliament I was given the opportunity to be appointed to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Privileges. No one asked me before I was appointed or elected to that position for my views on the subject of parliamentary privilege. Perhaps if my views had been known I would not have been permitted to go on that Committee because I stand unashamedly as a supporter of the view that members of parliament should not confer on themselves, other than in extremely narrowly defined and circumscribed circumstances, powers and authorities that are not conferred on members of the outside community. I do not believe that we can readily justify having one law for members of parliament and different laws for the members of the community who do not have the opportunity to sit on these green leather benches.

I believe that the Bill put forward by the honourable member for North Sydney is a commendable first step in reframing the law of contempt and parliamentary privilege as it exists in Australia today. However, as I will indicate in my contribution to this debate, I believe that it falls well short of what the Parliament ought to accept as a revised law. The debate that has proceeded so far has been to a very large extent of academic interest, and it is a tragedy that this debate is unlikely to be even reported in the media at all, given the fact that I do not think there is one single journalist in the Press Gallery. That is also regrettable because it has been members of the media who have felt the brunt of the law of contempt of Parliament. I would have thought that it was in their interests, as working journalists, and in the interests of their proprietors that the matter of contempt of Parliament be a matter for public debate. I think that the greater the public debate that occurs at this time the more likely we are to have a law and practice that reflect wider community standards rather than simply reflecting the rather narrow and cloistered view that I think we will ultimately reach here because of the vested interests that members of Parliament have in the final outcome of this debate.

I have a unique contribution to make in this debate because I am one of the few people who have been accused of having committed a contempt of Parliament before becoming a member of the Chamber. When I was formerly a solicitor working with the Aboriginal Legal Service, I had cause to be critical of what I believed to be the deficiencies of the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs when it was conducting its inquiry into the former asbestos mine at Baryulgil in New South Wales. I made comments that were very mild and could easily have been made with impunity when addressing the inadequacies of any other members of the community in equivalent circumstances. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) raised the matter as a concern and as at least a suggestion of a breach of parliamentary privilege and it was not proceeded with. I think that that provides a rather good example of someone-as I then was-acting in the course of my employment, raising concerns which I was paid to do in the course of my employment as a solicitor with the Aboriginal Legal Service, yet finding myself at least the subject of an allegation, albeit a misplaced one, of having committed a breach of privilege. So I can speak, although a new member of parliament, at least with some very practical and direct experience of the law of contempt of parliament.

Before I deal with what I believe to be some of the inadequacies of the Bill, I would like to compliment the honourable member for North Sydney and the Minister for the very bi-partisan and fair way in which this matter is being conducted in the Parliament. It is a credit to the honourable member for North Sydney that he remained the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege following the change of government. Frankly, I believe that is one easy way, I would hope, to achieve some social change in this country in regard to matters on which there is common agreement: We do not always have to be pitted against each other when clearly there is a need for reform, when times have changed and when this Parliament ought to move with those times.

With the assistance of the contribution by the honourable member for North Sydney, I would like briefly to trace some of the major initiatives that form the basis of his Bill. The chief provision of the Bill is to put beyond argument the protection given to members and officers of the Houses, and witnesses before committees, against liability for defamation in those areas where there is doubt. I must say, as a member of the Public Accounts Committee of the Parliament, that I believe it vital that we ensure that anyone who gives evidence before a parliamentary committee, whether it be a committee of the House of Representatives or any other parliamentary committee, can do so with the full protection of that committee and of the privilege of the Parliament in giving that evidence.

The second major initiative in the Bill is to limit the duration of the protection given to members of parliament with respect to immunity from arrest on civil process and also immunity from compulsory attendance as a witness. Again, I think that there can be no criticism of that provision. It is a reform that clearly is at least a century overdue. The third initiative in the Bill is to abolish as a head of contempt, and hence of punishment, the offence known as libels of parliament or defamatory contempts. Again, I hope there would be common ground in this area. I would like to return to this area in speaking about what I believe to be some of the deficiencies that have yet to be remedied, despite the general support given to this Bill.

The fourth effect of the Bill is that it removes the power of Houses to expel members. Of course, as the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) pointed out, that power has not been exercised for 65 years. On the one occasion on which it was exercised, it was exercised in a rather brutal and partisan manner. It occurred because arguably a member of parliament, acting in his capacity as a member of parliament, made some comments that were unacceptable to the members of the then governing party and, to put it brutally frankly, they then sought retribution. As a result of that, the member, Mr Hugh Mahon, lost his seat in the Parliament. I commend the honourable member for North Sydney for removing yet another anachronism.

Another effect of the Bill is that it confirms a very limited and highly circumscribed-to use the words of the honourable member for North Sydney-power in the full High Court of Australia to express an opinion that a resolution by a House to commit an offender to prison is in some way deficient. Again, I think this is an important initiative but, as the honourable member pointed out in his contribution, the court cannot go behind the facts stated in the resolution and, regardless of the court's views, the decision remains entirely that of the House concerned, which may entirely reject those views. Honourable members can see from that that the Parliament continues to maintain its overwhelming and substantially untrammelled power to be able to execute the law of contempt of parliament.

I note that clause 5 of the Bill provides a substantial restatement of section 49 of the Constitution which is, of course, to the effect that until parliament provides otherwise the powers, privileges and immunities of the House of Commons as at 1901 continue to apply to this House. Of course, in my view that is one of the major deficiencies of the Bill. I believe that we can find common ground to be able to take the moves for reform a lot further. What I am proposing is not in any way, I believe, a radical reform. I believe that what I am proposing is in accordance with the public opinion of mainstream Australian society today. It simply will not accept members of parliament conferring on themselves rights, powers and privileges that do not belong in the wider community, unless we can produce very good reasons in the broader public interest why those powers ought to be maintained, as I think we can in the case of the various parliamentary committees.

I will briefly discuss two of the major controversial cases that have spirited the movement for reform. First, there is the Fitzpatrick and Browne case. This case, of course, is now an integral part of Australian legal and political folklore and one which, I think it is common ground, does not reflect well on the House at that time. I commend that aspect of the Bill which would seek to remove the defamation of the Parliament, to use the phrase that was at least in part, but not entirely, behind the Fitzpatrick and Browne case. Despite that, there are other aspects of the Fitzpatrick and Browne case that, as I understand it, would not be remedied by this Bill. There was, for example, in that case an attempt by Mr Fitzpatrick before the committee to seek legal representation. One of the great ironies, of course, is that the committee in its wisdom saw fit to permit him the right to address the committee on that question. Having heard from him, it then refused any right to legal representation. It is also a matter of continuing concern that, despite the enormous lapse of time that has occurred since that case, we still really do not know what happened before that committee because the evidence cited by the committee in its report is only a small portion of the transcript and the full transcript has never been made public. Of course, because the hearing was held in camera there have been no Press accounts of it.

When Fitzpatrick and Browne came before the Bar of the House, again there was a denial of the right to legal representation. Subsequently, the Prime Minister moved that each respondent be committed to the custody of the Chief Commissioner of Police in Canberra or to the custody of the keeper of the gaol, and were there to be kept in custody until 10 September or until earlier dissolution of the Parliament, unless the House earlier allowed their discharge. Despite an attempt to secure their discharge, the majority did not support that view and as a result they languished in gaol.

It seems to me that this case raises some extremely important matters. If we, as members of Parliament, would defend the right to legal representation in courts of law when people are charged with criminal offences, if we defend the right of the people to a fair hearing, if we defend as we all would, the presumption of innocence, and if we all oppose retrospective criminal offences or penalties, as we all would, in my view there can be no place at all for allowing the procedures that currently exist in this Parliament for dealing with contempts of Parliament and breaches of privilege to stand. We might have a difference of opinion in this chamber about whether a Bill of Rights is required in this country, but the matters of which I spoke a moment ago, relating to the principle of natural justice and the right to a fair trial, are in the Bill of Rights.

We as a government-I speak as a member of the Government-have an obligation not to be prepared to let double standards prevail. We as a government cannot in good conscience promote views on natural justice and human rights that are supposed to apply in the courts of the land and throughout the States of Australia if we do not apply consistently those same basic rights of fairness in this chamber. Although I commend the honourable member for North Sydney for his initiative, I believe that we must go further and apply in this chamber those standards of fairness that we expect to apply right throughout this country. I repeat that, although there may be differences about the Bill of Rights, there would be no difference of opinion-except for the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper)-on the paramountcy of the rights to which I have referred.

I mention briefly the Oakes case, because that is relevant also. Although one of the consequences of the Spender Bill will be to remove this aspect of contempt of Parliament, it is very important that we reflect on the case involving Laurie Oakes and the Daily Mirror. Although the report concerned was reprehensible-perhaps no more reprehensible than many other reports which appear in the Daily Mirror-it ought not to have been the subject of any action for breach of privilege. As other members have said, what happened was that a story in the Daily Mirror suggested that it was not all hard work or stress for Australia's Federal members of parliament and that many have little or nothing to do other than sit around the members' bar boozing and whingeing. The article went on in similar terms. That incident occupied a great deal of the time of this Parliament. Finally the Committee of Privileges found that there had been a contempt of the House of Representatives by the author, editor and publisher. However, the Committee was of the view that no further action should be taken.

Many things happen in the wider community where members of parliament are subjected to a great deal of personal abuse. I must say that I am not sure whether I have the temperament to be a long term member of parliament, because some of the criticisms made of members of parliament are ill-informed, baseless, malicious and can be very hurtful to not only the members of parliament but also their families. I saw a doctor in a hospital the other day wearing a badge which said: `Trust me, I'm a doctor'. I thought that one step further in the audacity stakes would be for members of parliament to walk down the corridors wearing a badge which says: `Trust me, I'm a politician'. Such is the standing of members of parliament, quite unjustly, I think.

While I deplore many of the views of the Opposition, I cannot think of one member of parliament who does not work extremely hard. The hours of attendance alone in this place are more than most people in the wider community would be prepared to endure. Be that as it may, my point is that we must have broad shoulders. Part of the price we pay for living in a democracy is that people have the right of freedom of speech. If people want to attack members of parliament, doctors or any other member of the community, they ought to be able to do so. I believe that our shoulders have to be broad enough to accept that criticism and to be able to carry on the process of democracy.

I conclude by echoing the call made by the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones). This is 1986 and in the course of this Parliament we have seen the passage of the Australia Bill, for which there was bipartisan support. Let us see some bipartisan support for reforming the antiquated and unacceptable position with respect to parliamentary privilege.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The high interest rates of the Australian Labor Party are starting to cripple the lives of ordinary Australians. Tonight I join with my colleagues from all over Australia to highlight the human suffering caused by Labor's economic mismanagement. We present to the House evidence which we were told last week by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) did not exist. John and Alice are a young couple who will remain anonymous. They have enough problems without having the Press on their doorsteps. The tragedy of their story is being repeated across the country. This is their story.

SPEECH.PARA: John and Alice have one child and Alice is pregnant with their second. They live in my electorate and John works locally. They listened to the 1984 election rhetoric of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he said that a further interest rate fall is ahead of us. They heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saying that the economy was in great shape and they heard of government grants for first home buyers. So with this encouragement they looked at lots of houses until at last they found the home that was to fulfil a lifetime's dream-the family home. It was new and had a nice kitchen, but no floor coverings, electric light fittings or garden. But that was no problem because they looked forward to saving for their home and John would enjoy the satisfaction of getting the garden going and putting up fences to keep in the dog and the kids.

John and Alice's home cost $51,000, plus expenses of $2,500. It was funded by a loan of $46,500, the Government grant and their own savings. Their monthly payments were $414.23. After 12 months, before the garden had started to take shape. Labor's high interest rates were starting to bite. With Alice's pregnancy, a cut back in John's overtime, a general dissipation of confidence in the economy, and increasing State and Federal taxes, the massive increase in the monthly house payments-up $195.77 to $610-finally awoke them to the reality that their lifetime dream was quickly turning into a nightmare. They have been sensible. They have cut their losses and have voluntarily given up the dream, but not without financial and emotional cost, because the residential market is also entering a horror patch. Last week John and Alice sold their home for $50,600. That was a net drop of over $6,000; ironically, a similar figure to the amount provided under the first home owner's grant scheme.

One of my local agents told me that from January-February 1985 to January-February 1986 house sales had dropped by two-thirds; for another agent the drop has been 50 per cent. People are not buying houses because they are uncertain about our future and big money is needed to support the shandy loans or cocktail loans that are available. A $50,000 loan last week cost one Frankston couple $164 per week-$81 per week for $30,000 over 25 years and $83 per week for $20,000 at 17.75 per cent per annum over 10 years.

John and Alice's problems are still not over. They will move out in the next few weeks into the rental market, where once again Labor has put hurdles in their way. The capital gains tax, the removal of negative gearing and high interest rates have jacked up rents and restricted the number of houses and units for rent. If they can find a place to rent in Hastings, they will pay $110 per week for a three bedroom house-up from $70 per week in 1985-or if they take a two bedroom unit, the figure is up 37 per cent from 1985 to around $115 per week. It is no wonder that the Victorian builder Spaceline Homes Pty Ltd went into receivership last week, nor is it any wonder that the Socialist Left member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) said recently that under Labor homelessness was increasing. The Government is oblivious to the fact that, in the words of one agent in my electorate, the building industry is in a state of financial paralysis.

It is time the Government realised that it is crushing the hopes and aspirations of increasing numbers of Australians who merely want to own their own homes. John and Alice are not alone. Their immediate neighbour is a young mother who is living on her own and paying an extra $90 a month. Further down the street another couple is struggling to pay the additional $130 a month. Across Australia the story is being repeated, in every street and in every suburb.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that in association with the Federal legislation the States will need to remove the speed differences between trucks and cars and provide truckies with some consumer protection. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Labor Government's high interest rates policy is like a black hole in outer space, consuming everything and everyone before it so that they are never to be seen again. Farmers, home buyers and small businessmen everywhere in the electorate of Gilmore are falling into the Government's high interest rates black hole. I raise the case tonight of a farm machinery retailing company in the western portion of the electorate of Gilmore. The founder of that company was one of the great pioneers of the western districts of my electorate. He formed the company in 1934 and sold some of the most modern farm machinery of that time, when farmers were still using horse-drawn ploughs and breaking sods with their bare hands. Since 1934 the company has survived the Great Depression and one world war. It has been gradually passed down through the family. Today it is managed by a grandson of the founder. However, the grandson fears that this company, which has been in his family for more than 50 years and served the farmers of the south-western district of New South Wales, will follow the path of other small business and be sucked into the Government's high interest rates black hole. He cannot sell his farm machinery because the farmers he relies upon for his business cannot afford to buy new or used machinery or accessories and spare parts because of the high cost of interest under the hire purchase and lease arrangements that they have to undertake. No matter what deal this machinery dealer offers, even if it means he will lose money on the deal, nobody can afford to buy or replace farm machinery at the moment. The story is the same with other farm machinery retailers in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular gentleman has been forced to sack staff. When times were good he employed 19 local residents but now he employs only seven. Sacking staff was the hardest thing he had to do. How does a man who lives in a small community where everybody knows everybody else and knows each other's business sack his neighbours and friends, sack the long term employees with whom he has built up a degree of trust, when everybody in that town needs a job? Most of those workers had families to feed, clothe and house. They had bills to pay on their homes, cars and other simple necessities that we all think that we would like to enjoy. For some of those families the prospect of living on the dole and being forced to seek assistance from charities was too much to bear in a small community. Four families were forced to sell their homes, pack up and move to Sydney in search of work. What has become of them is unknown. Two other former employees of that farm machinery company were also forced to leave their homes, relatives and friends in search of work in another part of the State.

This small community cannot afford to lose residents, their spending capacity and their general expertise and input into the lifestyle of the community. It has a negative effect on that community because the stores and other businesses where those people once shopped or sought entertainment are now minus their custom. One worker who also lost his job found new employment at a nearby retirement village as a caretaker. He is engaged in menial tasks compared to the high responsibilities he once held with his previous employer. The rest of the people who lost their jobs with this farm machinery retailer are believed to be on the dole while searching for work. The future of those who remain with the company appears no brighter. The plight of this farm machinery retailer is indicative of the disastrous state of the rural economy brought about the policies of this Government.

Another small business that reels under the same pressures of high interest rates is a new and used car yard in the eastern portion of my electorate of Gilmore. It is a well-known yard that has been operating in the area for many years. The hike in interest rates has forced the owner to lay off staff, cut back on costs and go to the extent of selling some of his personal possessions. Under a floor plan used to finance the cars in his business, the interest bill on money he has borrowed has increased from $11,000 a month to $16,000 a month-that is, $5,000 a month more or $60,000 a year more because of this Government's interest rates policies. He has had to sack employees and has had to sell his own personal possessions in order to keep his business going, to keep employment and some sort of economy going in his own area. All of these things have a negative impact on the community. There is no question that the interest rates policies of this Government are causing unemployment, hardship and personal disruption to family life right throughout country New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday I spoke during the grievance debate about criticism of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace document entitled `Working for a Just Peace'. We correct it by educating Australians to the reality of underdevelopment. It is too easy just to give money with no challenges to our lifestyle, to our duties as citizens of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: To continue what I said in the House last week during the grievance debate, the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace questions in its document the morality of spending so much on waging war and so little on making peace. I join with the Commission in asking these questions. I put it to the House that these are questions which must be asked. To decry world hunger and the poverty of millions of people in the Third World and not ask these questions-questions about expenditure on defence and questions about lifestyle-is to sink into the depths of stupidity, criminality and total hypocrisy. This, of course, is not the first time the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace has been criticised, nor, I hope, will it be the last. When it ceases to be criticised I know it will no longer be performing its role of challenging on moral grounds the status quo and the conventional wisdom of Australian society.

Some years ago, the Commission was attacked for challenging the conventional wisdom that supported the minority white regime of what was then called Rhodesia, and is now called Zimbabwe. Then, in August 1977, Bishop Lamont arrived in Australia from Zimbabwe and what he had to say thoroughly vindicated the Commission and its attackers fell silent. More recently, the Commission was attacked for daring to criticise the repressive regime of ex-President Marcos of the Philippines. Suddenly, the attacks stopped. Why did this happen? This happened because suddenly it became fashionable to be anti-Marcos and pro-Aquino. Thus, once again, history has vindicated the stand taken by the Commission.

Although I said the criticism stopped, an article in yesterday's Melbourne Age by Michael Barnard said that Australian Catholic Relief co-operated with the anti-democratic revolutionary groups in the Philippines, that is, they co-operated with anti-Marcos forces. Michael Barnard argued about Australian Catholic Relief's readiness to place trust and credibility in the far left Filipino groups. Really, where did he expect it to put its trust? Did he expect it to put its trust in Marcos and his cronies?

I have visited the Philippines several times. I first went to the Philippines some years ago and when I worked with Australian Catholic Relief. I went to the Philippines to see and to experience the realities of aid. I did not go to the fleshpots of Manila. The only place I visited in Manila was the Tonda area. In the Philippines I saw wealth and luxury like I had never seen before. I also saw unbelievable poverty. I then went to Samar for a couple of weeks. In fact, I believe I was the first Australian to raise the question of the northern Samar integrated pro- ject. However, at that time no one wanted to know; that is, no one except the Catholic Church, especially Australian Catholic Relief and the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace. I have mentioned the Commission's role in raising the consciousness in regard to Zimbabwe and the Philippines.

I could speak for hours regarding Sri Lanka, Ethiopia and other countries to which aid is given. But I put it to this House: Will the Commission be subsequently vindicated for its stand on nuclear disarmament and the arms race? If the human race somehow survives these dreadful and perilous times, I believe it will. I congratulate the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace for asking these questions. I also congratulate it for providing the sane and moral context within which those questions need to be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join my colleagues in the concerted attack on the Government's current policy of high interest rates and on the impact this policy is having on small Australians, small businessmen and workers across the country. Much has been made in this House and much has been said about the fallacy of high interest rates. But there has been no action from the Government to provide any sort of relief for those who are currently suffering and are being sent bankrupt by the existing policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up the remarks of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). Madam Speaker, I want to take you to a little town in my electorate known as Bute at the top of the peninsula. This is a small town which is set in one of the favoured areas of Wakefield. It is set in a 14-inch rainfall area where large farmers are generally insulated from the reality of economic dilemmas that easily touch small operators. I visited some farm retailers in Bute and was astonished to discover that one of them had to put off six people. This is what has happened in a small town like Bute. However, he said to me: `If you think that is bad, Neil, go around the corner and have a chat to my competitor'. I discovered that that man was the grandson of the originator of a business which normally from January to March would have sold six farm tractors and eight four-wheel drive utilities. But this year he has sold nothing. Why has the firm sold nothing? It is not because the season is bad or because the farmers are going bankrupt in the area but because the area is captured by pessimism. Farmers do not believe that there is a future in farming in one of the most reliable areas of my electorate.

It is fair to say that if things are not beaut in Bute, they must be bad. Faced with the reality of high interest rates, there are farmers in sure areas of Australia who are no longer investing in farm equipment because they are pessimistic. Let me refer now not to a farm retailer but to a farmer at Melrose near Mount Remarkable in the north of my electorate. This farmer farms 1,200 acres. I guess that land is conservatively valued at $600 an acre. Because his son works with him, he in fact has a share farming operation. Two years ago this farmer chose to buy 580 acres from a neighbour at a cost of $320,000. The loan which was negotiated at an interest rate of 12.75 per cent was to cost $35,700 a year. With interest rates now at 20.6 per cent the loan is costing $57,680 a year to discharge. The loan has gone up by $1,832 a month. In the face of that sort of economic reality this good farmer who is energetic and who has a reliable labourer in the form of his son, faces foreclosure not because the seasons have been bad but because the policies of this Government of high interest rates make that an inevitable reality.

If a moderate farmer in my electorate worth that sort of money does not appeal to the people on the other side of the House, let me refer to the plight of a grape grower in the Cadell irrigation area who came to Australia with his wife from Yugoslavia. As a new immigrant he went with friends into a fish and chip shop and then into a corner delicatessen. These people finally bought their own home in the city. They discovered that they could buy a property for $92,000 and have the joy of being, as it were, their own boss. They sold their home in the city and borrowed $32,000 to buy this property.

In January 1984 they negotiated the loan, being encouraged by the promises of the Hawke Government. By January 1986 interest rates had gone from 12.75 per cent to 20.6 per cent. Their repayments rose by $209 a month. While we sit in air-conditioned comfort, this couple is currently harvesting a grape crop, unable to afford the labour that they need. Marty and Angelina are taking off the crop themselves in 40-degree heat because the policy of this Government has effectively forced them out of the dream that they hoped would be realised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues the honourable member for Flinders--

—I rise on a point of order. I ask that the interjection of the honourable member for Denison-I know I am wasting the time of the honourable member for Forde-be withdrawn. —I rise to support my colleagues the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I can testify that the plight of the average Australian family extends to my electorate. I refer to a local newspaper of mine-not the Australian or the Australian Financial Review or something like that, but my local newspaper which had a headline a couple of weeks ago `Own Home Dream Now Nightmare- Battlers Go Under to Interest Rates'. My colleagues and this newspaper have identified the critical factors affecting small business and families in Australia-namely, increasing inflation and increasing real interest costs. These two economic conditions are totally the responsibility of this Labor Government and are the total responsibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

SPEECH.PARA: Let us return for a moment to the last days of the coalition Government and examine the record on these two issues. We have heard the Treasurer and the Prime Minister-we heard it from the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand)-saying that the economy was left in a mess by the Fraser-Anthony Government and that somehow only the Keating-Hawke duo saved Australia. Let us look at the record, for example, on inflation. The coalition left government with the inflation rate falling and an inflation rate which continued to fall in the early months of this Government because of the policies established under the Fraser Government. The facts are clear. The quarterly changes in inflation rates were 3.5 per cent in September 1982, 3.1 per cent in December 1982, 2.2 per cent by March 1983-election time-2.1 per cent by June 1983 and 1.6 per cent by September 1983. The underlying inflation rate at the time, as shown by the Treasurer's own Department in chart 4 of its February 1986 `Round-up of Economic Statistics' peaked in June 1982 at a little over 3 per cent and continued to fall until September 1984 to a little over 1 per cent.

There are other statistics which show that inflation was falling. The quarterly increase in average weekly earnings slowed from 2.4 per cent in September 1982 to about 0.7 per cent by June 1983. Nominal and real labour costs in the non-farm sector were falling when the coalition left office. The wages pause had these positive effects and it is these effects which provided the basis for the job creation program of the Labor Government.

Let us turn to interest costs. Every Australian who owns a home or is buying a car, refrigerator or television set or trying to run a small business knows all about interest rates. All Australians know that when the coalition left office at the end of February 1983 trading bank interest rates were 14 per cent per annum and falling, that building society interest rates were 14.5 per cent and falling and that savings bank interest rates were 12.5 per cent per annum and falling. They had been falling for six to 12 months before the coalition left office.

What have we today? We have the highest nominal interest rates since 1902. We have the highest real interest rates since the Depression years of the early 1930s. We have double digit real interest rates-for the first time since 1933. We have the highest nominal interest rates in the Western world and these compare very unfavourably with our major trading partners. By March of this year we had savings bank interest rates of 13.5 per cent, building society interest rates of 15.5 per cent and trading bank interest rates of 19 per cent. This Government has the average Australian on the ropes. This Government, this Treasurer and this Prime Minister provided the good old one-two knockout punch. They drain the average Australian family and business with increasing inflation and increasing costs and then they knock them down to the floor with high interest rates. The average Australian family is calling for the referee to end the fight. The average Australian family and businessman wants this Government to get out of the economic ring. Tonight we have heard the cries from Bute in South Australia, from Hastings in Victoria, from the Western Plains of New South Wales and suburbs such as Acacia Ridge in Brisbane. This Government is squeezing the home buyer, destroying the farmer and ruining small business. Average Australians have had enough with this Government's utter indifference to their plight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to the case of Jennifer Sigaras, who is a constituent of mine. She is a tertiary education student who has been asked to repay $864.89 of her tertiary education allowance which she was paid last year. The facts of the case are as follows: Jennifer was completing her final year of a Bachelor of Education degree at the Victoria College Rusden Campus in 1984. During the second term Jennifer became ill. She eventually required a hospital operation. While she was able to continue with her other subjects she was unable to carry out her teaching rounds until the first part of the following year. This meant that in her final year her subject load fell below the required two-thirds workload required for qualification under the tertiary education allowance scheme. Jenny claimed that she had not in fact discontinued her course, but the Victoria College insisted on recording her as undertaking intermittent studies. However, she was informed by the student's record office that this was only a formality necessary for accurate college records.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that Jenny also receives a widow's pension. So it is possible that if her tertiary education allowance is adjusted she may be able to receive a compensatory adjustment on her pension, but that, of course, is not certain. However, she lost her right to a rent rebate on her Housing Commission home while she was receiving TEAS. Presumably, the rent rebate is not recoverable.

In terms of the TEAS guidelines, Jenny has received an overpayment of her allowance during part of 1984 because she was recorded as an intermittent studies student by the Victoria College, despite her continuation of the non-teaching subjects during the third term. It must be appreciated that the withdrawal of the allowance rebates relates to the second term when Jenny was supposed to carry on her teaching rounds but was advised against taking on such duties by her doctor because of the stress involved on her health. Initially Jenny was asked to repay $2,259.11. I quote from a letter she received from the Department of Education and Youth Affairs:

In accordance with Section 22 (4) of the Student Assistance Act, you are advised that the primary decision made in your case has been considered and subsequently upheld under Regulation 37 (1) on the following ground-
You discontinued your course on June 18 1985. Once a student has officially discontinued from College payments cannot continue even though a student may have attended in some unofficial capacity.

I am attaching a Statement to assist you should you wish to seek review of the decision by a Student Assistance Review Tribunal. A decision of a Student Assistance Review Tribunal may be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Both the Department and Tribunals in making their decisions are bound by the Act and its Regulations.
Requests should normally be lodged within 30 days from the date of receipt of this letter, but late requests may be considered.
Subsequently, on appeal, the amount was reduced to the figure of $864.89 that I mentioned. Another letter was sent to Mrs Sigaras which said:
This amount replaces the overpayment previously advised of $2259.11. I have advised this Department's Recoveries section of the amount of your outstanding 1984 overpayment.

Please repay this amount . . . within 14 days to the Collector of Public Moneys, Department of Education, at the address given above. Payment can also be made at this Office in normal working hours. A receipt will not be issued unless requested.
I should point out that all decisions must be made in accordance with the Student Assistance Act and Regulations.

The Department enclosed a leaflet with that letter. It is interesting to note that under the eligibility requirements of TEAS set out in paragraphs D (e) and (v) on page 9 in the information for applicants booklet, if Jenny had failed third year she would have been eligible to apply for a concession and possibly repeat benefits the following year. One also should look at page 8 of the information booklet, which specifies that in the event of illness the Department of Education must be notified within 14 days. There is no doubt that the application of the TEAS regulations has been inflexible in the case of Jennifer Sigaras. I call on the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to re-examine the unfair and bureaucratic treatment of Jennifer Sigaras.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard several honourable members tonight speak about interest rates. I do not particularly want to speak about that topic, but a myth is being perpetrated by the Government on the Australian people. We should look at some of the figures over the years. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) like to go back and look at the past record. I thought I might do the same very briefly. If one looks at inflation under the coalition Government for the last 15 years, one will find that we come out ahead of Labor governments. If one looks at unemployment one will find that we come out ahead of Labor governments. In Budget deficits we come out ahead. Even in housing we come out ahead over that time. Over the last 15 years under Liberal governments, average new housing starts have been 132,000. Under Labor governments the average has been 141,000. They are the raw figures, but when we consider that the population of Australia has increased over that time we find that, on a standardised measure, the Liberals are just as good at managing housing for this nation as is the Australian Labor Party.
—Better.

—In fact, slightly better, as the honourable member for Denison says. I wish to speak tonight about an issue of particular concern to me, the welfare system, because I believe that it needs a total overhaul. In my electorate there are people on award wages, for example mill workers on $240 a week. The Federal pastoralist award in Australia at the moment is $238, yet the disposable income for a married man with two children is equivalent to just over $250. That is a problem for genuine hard-working people because the bread winner of the family-whether the wife or the father-out working for these wages is put in an invidious situation when he or she knows that the family would be better off if he or she went on the dole. Yet for such people to do so would be to lose their dignity, their sense of worth and any sense of purpose and contribution that they feel they should make to the nation. They try to hold their families together knowing that they are worse off working. The welfare system is creating more people who are poor and homeless.

SPEECH.PARA: The President of the Australian Labor Party in Victoria has said that under this Government there has been an increasing number of people on the poverty line and people who are homeless. Figures show that in 1974, 13 per cent of the nation was poor. In 1984, 25 per cent of the population was poor. The welfare system is creating poverty and not solving it. This nation must come to grips with our welfare system. It is totally unsatisfactory and is putting many hard-working families in an invidious situation.

Of course, many others are benefitting from Government benefits. Many people are worse off by being in a family. Another illustration of people on the dole getting more benefits than those in the workforce is that of a family where a daughter received $150 a week and another group of people living together on the dole were living a much more pleasant lifestyle than she was able to do on $150. We have to look at this matter and bring about some changes, otherwise in the next few years we will find that a greater number of people are homeless and poor.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
